question_text: The newborn eye is usually .
explanation: A newborn is usually hypermetropic by +2D to +3D. The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the eyeball at birth is about 16.5 mm, which is about 70% of the adult size. This reduced axial length causes light to converge behind the retina, leading to hypermetropia. Additionally, the corneal diameter at birth is 10 mm. The adult size (11.7 mm) is attained by 2 years of age. The orbit is more divergent (50°) as compared to adult (45°). Note: The lacrimal glands are underdeveloped in a newborn and, hence, do not secrete tears.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: At what age would a child attain full visual acuity?
explanation: Full visual acuity is attained by the age of 6 years. Important milestones in visual development are: At birth, there is no central fixation, and the eyes move randomly. By the first month of life, the fixation reflex starts developing and becomes established by 6 months. By 3 months, binocular vision is established. By 6 months, macular stereopsis and accommodation reflex are fully developed. By 6 years of age, full visual acuity (6/6) is attained.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 45-year-old lady presents with the abnormality as shown below. She is diagnosed with uveal melanoma. What is the embryological origin of the cells involved?
explanation: Uveal melanomas arise from uveal melanocytes. Uveal and conjunctival melanocytes are derived from the neural crest cells.

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the development of the eye?
options: The macula is fully developed at birth.
The cornea attains normal diameter by 2 years.
Full visual acuity is attained by 6 years of age.
explanation: The macula is fully developed by 4–6 months of age. Apart from the macula, the rest of the retina is fully developed at birth. Postnatal Development of Eye: 3 Months - Binocular single vision develops. 4-6 Months - Macula fully develops. Fusional reflexes, stereopsis, and accommodation become well developed 6 Months - Fixation, which had started developing in the first month is now complete 2 Years - Cornea develops to the normal adult diameter 6 Years - Visual acuity fully develops and reaches 6/6 The lens, however, continues to grow throughout the life

question_text: By how many weeks of embryonic development does the optic groove appear?
explanation: The optic groove appears by 3 weeks. By approximately day 22, 2 small grooves appear on either side of the developing forebrain in the neural folds, these are called optic grooves. As the neural tube closes, these grooves develop outpouchings called optic vesicles. These optic vesicles extend from the forebrain to the surface ectoderm.

question_text: After conception, the canal of Schlemm appears by .

question_text: What is the anteroposterior diameter of the adult eyeball?
explanation: The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the adult eye is 24 mm/2.4 cm. At birth, the average axial length of the eyeball is 16.5 mm. By 3 years, it grows rapidly to approximately 23 mm. From 3 to 14 years of age, the axial length gradually increases by a further 1 mm, bringing it to the adult size of 24 mm. This overall adjustment in the eye size, including the refractive power, is called emmetropization.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A college student comes to the OPD for refractive error testing. Her eyes are dilated using tropicamide. Which of the following statements is false about the structure this drug acts on?
options: It is triangular in cross section.
There are around 30-40 processes in pars plana and pars plicata
Its epithelium is derived from the anterior edge of the optic cup.
The pars plana is approximately 4.5 mm from the limbus.
explanation: Tropicamide is a cycloplegic drug that acts on the ciliary body to cause mydriasis for refractory error testing. The ciliary body is a triangular structure that contains 60-70 ciliary processes in each eye, present on the pars plicata. The pars plana is 4.5mm from the limbus while the distance between the equator and the limbus is 14mm. The ciliary epithelium is derived from the optic cup (neuroectoderm) by the continued growth of the outer lip's anterior edge.

question_text: A 12-year-old girl you examined in an outreach camp is found to have this abnormality. What is the most common site where the condition is seen?
explanation: The condition depicted in the image is a coloboma of the iris, and the most common site of coloboma is the inferonasal quadrant. A coloboma is a congenital malformation in one of the structures in the eye, such as the iris, retina, choroid, or optic disc, due to the failure of embryonic fissure closure. Coloboma of the uveal tract may be typical (seen in the inferonasal quadrant) or atypical (occasionally found in other positions). Typical coloboma is of two types: Complete: Extends from pupil to optic nerve, causing a corresponding lens indentation. Incomplete: May involve iris alone, or iris and ciliary body (more common), or iris, ciliary bod and a part of choroid. Other embryonic remnants in the eye: Mittendorf's dot - Remnant of the anterior end of the hyaloid arter Bergmeister papilla - Remnant of the posterior end of the hyaloid arter Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) - Failure of fetal vasculature to regress The image below shows a fundoscopy view of persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous.

question_text: A child was brought with complaints of decreased vision. Fundus examination shows a developmental anomaly as shown below. What is the cause of this anomaly?
options: Incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure
Faulty migration of neural crest cells
explanation: The image shows a coloboma of the optic disc, accompanied by a large chorioretinal coloboma located below the optic disc, which is caused by incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure. This developmental anomaly may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris. Coloboma of the optic disc can present in two forms: a minor effect often associated with refractive errors like hypermetropia and astigmatism and a fully developed coloboma that appears as a large inferonasal whitish excavation resembling the optic disc. Defective vision and superior visual field defects are typically associated with fully developed coloboma. Additionally, this condition may be associated with chorioretinal coloboma, a congenital anomaly where the developing optic cup fails to fuse completely, leading to abnormal choroidal and retinal development. Note: Faulty migration of neural crest cells results in anterior segment dysgenesis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The optic foramen is situated between the:
options: Lesser and greater wings of the sphenoid
Lesser wing and body of the sphenoid
Greater wing and body of the sphenoid
Two roots of the lesser wing of the sphenoid
explanation: The optic foramen is situated between the two roots of the lesser wing of the sphenoid. The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is formed medially by the body and laterally by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's apex to the middle cranial fossa. The optic canal transmits the optic nerve with its meningeal coverings; the ophthalmic artery, which is below the nerve, is embedded in its dural sheath, and a few twigs from the sympathetic plexus accompanying the artery.

question_text: During a game, a 26-year-old baseball player is hit in the head by a baseball, which fractures the optic canal. Which of the following pairs of structures is most likely to be damaged?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, a fracture of the optic canal is most likely to damage the ophthalmic artery and optic nerve, as these are the primary structures passing through it. The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is a short cylindrical structure bounded medially by the body and laterally by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's apex to the middle cranial fossa, serving as a pathway for the aforementioned structures along with its sympathetic plexus. Optic canal fractures, often associated with basilar skull fractures, can lead to optic neuropathy. The intracanalicular and intracranial portion of the optic nerve is most commonly affected in head trauma. Note: The greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bound the superior orbital fissure.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following structures is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle?
options: Check ligament of the medial rectus
Check ligament of the lateral rectus
explanation: Check ligament of the lateral rectus is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle. Lateral orbital tubercle or Whitnall's tubercle is a small elevation on the orbital surface of the zygomatic bone, just within the lateral orbital margin. It is about 11 mm below the fronto-zygomatic suture. Four structures are attached to it: Check ligament of the lateral rectus Lockwood’s ligament (Suspensory ligament of the eyeball) Lateral palpebral ligament Lateral horn of the levator aponeurosis The Whitnall's ligament or the superior transverse ligament of the eye, is attached to the superior tarsal plate and the orbital bone.

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the tarsal plates?
options: They give structural support to the eyelid.
LPS aponeurosis is attached to the superior border of the upper tarsal plate.
Their medial and lateral ends form the medial and lateral palpebral ligaments, respectively.
explanation: The tarsal plates are not cartilaginous structures but firm, dense connective tissue (fibrous tissue) plates. The tarsal plates serve as the structural support of the eyelids. The height of the upper tarsal plate is about 10 mm, and that of the lower tarsal plate is 4 mm. Both plates have a thickness of about 1 mm. The ends form the medial and lateral palpebral ligaments (medial and lateral canthal tendons). The levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) aponeurosis is attached to the superior border of the upper tarsal plate. The meibomian glands are located within the tarsus. These are holocrine-secreting sebaceous glands that are not associated with lash follicles.

question_text: A 6-year-old child complains that she cannot see anything on the whiteboard clearly. On ophthalmological examination, she is found to have a 2 mm shortening of the axial length of the eyeball. How much eye power will this lead to?

question_text: You are studying the optics of a patient with regular astigmatism. Identify the point at which the clearest image is formed?
explanation: The given figure is a Sturm's conoid. It represents a bundle of light rays formed by a regularly astigmatic surface. The image is clearest or least confusing as point D, the circle of least confusion. When light passes through a regularly astigmatic surface(surface with toric curvature), vertical and horizontal rays converge at different points. The distance between the points of convergence (focus) of the vertical and horizontal rays is called the focal interval of strum. (distance between points B and F). The circle of least confusion/ circle of diffusion lies at the mid-point of this interval. F r the given Sturm's conoid, At point A, a horizontal oval is formed because vertical rays converge more rapidly than horizontal rays. At point B, vertical rays come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging; so, it will be a horizontal straight line. At points C, D, and E, the vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging. At point D, the vertical rays have diverged as much as the horizontal rays have converged; so, we get a perfect circle called the circle of least confusion. At point E, a vertical oval is formed. At point F, a vertical straight line is formed At point G and beyond, both rays are diverging, and we always get a vertical oval/prolate ellipse.

question_text: What is the Stiles-Crawford effect?

explanation: The Stiles–Crawford effect refers to the greater sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than the oblique rays. explanation: Metarhodopsin II is responsible for phototransduction. It activates transducin member of G proteins. This leads to the closure of Na+ channels and hyperpolarization, thereby inducing phototransduction (signal transduction in the retina).

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the physiology of photoreceptors?
options: Phototransduction results in closure of c-GMP-gated cation channels.
Chromophore regeneration occurs in the outer segment of photoreceptors.
Photon absorption induces photo-isomerisation of 11-cis-retinal to all-trans-retinal.
11-cis-Retinal is bound to opsins by covalent bonds.
explanation: Chromophore regeneration occurs in the retinal pigment epithelial cells. Phototransduction: Rhodopsin is a G-protein-coupled receptor found in the outer segments of rod photoreceptors. 11-cis-retinal (a chromophore) is covalently bound to opsins via a lysine residue on one of the transmembrane domains. The receptor is activated by photo-isomerization of prebound 11-cis-retinal t ALL-TRANS-retinal. Activation of the receptor causes binding and activation of the G protein, transducin, with signal transduction via cGMP phosphodiesterase, resulting in a decrease in the intracellular cGMP levels and closure of the cGMP-gated Na channels. This causes hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell, which modulates neurotransmitter release at the synapse with bipolar cells. This entire process triggered by the activation of rhodopsin is phototransduction, which occurs in the outer segment of photoreceptors and converts light energy into an electrical signal. Chromophore regeneration: All-trans retinAL is converted to all-trans-retinOL. All-trans-retinOL gets transported by interphotoreceptor retinoid-binding protein (IRBP) to the retinal pigment epithelial cells, where it is reconstituted into the 11-cis retinal isoform.

question_text: What is the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum of the human eye?
explanation: The visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum for the human eye is 400–700 nm. Theories of color vision: Trichromatic theory (Young–Helmholtz theory) assumes that there are three types of color receptors. Each receptor is assumed to respond to all wavelengths, however, each has different spectral sensitivities. Opponent process theory, also known as the Hering theory, assumes three sets of receptor systems—red-green, blue-yellow, and black-white. Each one of these functions as an antagonistic pair (e.g., red light stimulates the red receptors and, at the same time, inhibits the green). Edwin Land's theory has three separate color systems (retinexes). Each is an analog to a black-and-white picture.

question_text: What is the characteristic visual defect in deuteranomaly?
explanation: In deuteranomaly, the perception of green color is defective. It is the most common disorder of color vision. Monochromacy: Only one of the three primary colors (red, blue, or green) can be appreciated. Dichromacy: Two primary colors are appreciated. (anopia = absent). Protanopia: Red color is not perceived. Deuteranopia: Green color is not perceived. Tritanopia: Blue color is not perceived. Trichromacy: All the three primary colors are appreciated, but one of them can be defective (anomaly = defective). Protanomaly: Red color perception is defective. Deuteranomaly: Green color perception is defective. Tritanomaly: Blue color perception is defective. Achromatopsia: No color perception due to the absence of cones. It may also occur in the lesion of area V4 or V8 of the visual cortex.

question_text: What is the angle subtended by the optotype on the second line of Snellen’s chart when viewed from a distance of 6 meters?
explanation: The angle subtended by the optotype (individual letters on the chart) on the second line of Snellen’s chart in the above case would be 30 minutes of arc. The second line on Snellen’s chart corresponds to a distance of 36 meters. When viewed from a 6m distance, it is denoted as visual acuity 6/36. Where, The numerator (6) denotes the distance from which the patient is actually viewing it The denominator (36) denotes the distance at which it should be ideally viewed. It denotes the distance at which each stroke of the letter would subtend the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) of one minute of arc. MAR = 1/Visual acuity Each letter is shaped such that it can be placed in a square, the sides of which are five times the breadth of individual limbs of the letters. Hence, the angle subtended by the optotype= MAR x 5 F r eg: At exactly 6 meters distance from the patient, the letters on the 6/6 line shall subtend 5 minutes of arc (such that the individual limbs of the letters subtend 1 minute of arc). The equation to calculate the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) is given as follows: F r the given question, MAR = 1/ 6/36 MAR = 36/6 MAR = 6 minutes of arc Hence, the angle subtended by the entire letter is 6 × 5 = 30 minutes of arc.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 42-year-old man with monocular aphakia wears contact lenses. What is the approximate percentage of aniseikonia in his eyes?
explanation: The approximate percentage of aniseikonia in a person with monocular aphakia wearing a contact lens would be 8%. Aniseikonia is defined as the difference in image size between the two eyes and can lead to disturbances in stereopsis. The tolerable limit of aniseikonia is 5–8%. It is reduced with contact lens (8%) compared to glasses (25–30%) in aphakia. However, the percentage of aniseikonia is least with an intraocular lens (IOL) (1–3%), thus secondary IOL implantation is the most preferred management of unilateral aphakia.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which cerebellar nucleus controls the ocular saccade?
explanation: The Floccular nucleus of the cerebellum controls ocular saccades. A saccade is a rapid ballistic movement to change the point of fixation. It is the fastest of all eye movements and is initiated by the contralateral frontal lobe. Smooth pursuit is a slow tracking movement to keep the target on the fovea. It is controlled by the ipsilateral parieto-occipital lobe. F llowing an object from the right to left is left pursuit and is controlled by ipsilateral (left) parieto-occipital lobe, and the corrective movement is a saccade (in this case, left to right) termed right saccade and is controlled by the contralateral (left) frontal lobe. The floccular nucleus is found in the lobule HX of the cerebellar vermis. Its functions include matching pulse-step, gaze holding, and sustained smooth pursuit. Bilateral lesions of the flocculus result in the following: Post-saccadic drift- saccadic movements do not stop, but there is a brief, several hundred milliseconds drift of the eyes after each saccade. Saccadic pursuit- smooth tracking is replaced by simultaneous rapid jerking motions of the eye to follow an object toward the ipsilateral visual field. Gaze-evoked nystagmus- impaired ability to hold the eyes in the eccentric position, resulting in gaze-evoked nystagmus towards the affected side of the cerebellum. Emboliform and globose nuclei: Generation of vertical saccades Fastigial nuclei: Pursuit initiation
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Purely depolarizing cells in the optic pathway are .
explanation: Amacrine cells are the cells that produce purely depolarizing potential and spikes.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
Most afferent fibers from the lateral geniculate body terminate in the primary visual cortex in
.
explanation: Most afferent fibers from the lateral geniculate body (LGB) terminate in the primary visual cortex in layer 4. Both the magnocellular and parvocellular pathways from the LGB terminate in layer 4 of the visual cortex. Only the interlaminar pathway terminates in layers 2 and 3.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
What is the mean value for outflow facility of the aqueous in the normal eye?
2.3 µL/min/mm Hg
explanation: The aqueous outflow facility is about 0.28 µL/min/mmHg. Aqueous humor is produced at an average rate of 2.0–2.5 µL/min. The ease with which the aqueous humor leaves the eye is called an aqueous outflow facility. The outflow facility is measured using tonography. The normal range is between 0.22–0.28 µL/min/mmHg. A juxtacanalicular portion of the trabecular meshwork is the primary limiting factor for the utflow facility. Uveoscleral outflow accounts for 10% of the total aqueous outflow facility. Aqueous outflow facility decreases with aging. Trabecular outflow facility is reduced in glaucoma. Laser trabeculoplasty reduces intraocular pressure (IOP) in open-angle glaucoma by increasing the trabecular outflow facility. Myopia and Hypermetropia
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The term ametropia refers to all except .
explanation: The term ametropia refers to conditions of refractive error. Emmetropia refers to an optically normal eye. The term ametropia includes conditions such as Myopia (shortsightedness) Hypermetropia (longsightedness) Astigmatism
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A small kid is brought for examination due to difficulty reading from the board at school. Visual acuity was 20/60 in both eyes. His vision got corrected with concave lens spectacles. Which of the following is the most common cause of this refractive error?
options: Increased anteroposterior diameter of the eye ball
Increase in the refractive index of lens
explanation: Poor vision for distance (difficulty reading from board) that is corrected with concave lens spectacles suggest that the child has myopia. The most common cause of myopia (shortsightedness) is increased anteroposterior length of the eyeball. Myopia is a type of refractive error seen when the parallel rays of light from infinity are focused in front of the retina when accomodation is at rest.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following range defines moderate myopia?
explanation: Moderate myopia is defined when the refractive error is between -3D and -6D. Note: Myopia according to age of onset: Congenital: Present at birth Youth onset: 2–20 years of age Early adult onset: 20–40 years of age Late adult onset: >40 years of age
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following myopias is not associated with high degree of refractive error?
explanation: School myopia or simple myopia is associated with a low to moderate degree of refractive error. Simple myopia is the most common type of myopia. It results from a normal biological variation in the development of the eye i.e. increased anteroposterior diameter of eyeball or increased curvature of the cornea. Other options: Options A and D: Pathological/Degenerative/Progressive myopia occurs due to degenerative changes in the retina, leading to a high degree of refractive error. Option B: Congenital myopia is associated with congenital anomalies of the eye, and a high degree of refractive error. Note: Other types of myopia include: Nocturnal myopia: Accommodation is induced by low contrast in dim illumination Induced myopia: Temporary and reversible myopia due to external agents (e.g., pilocarpine-induced accommodation spasm)/variations in blood sugar levels Pseudomyopia: Inappropriately excessive accommodation due to overstimulation/ciliary spasm.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A woman comes to the ophthalmology OPD because of having vision difficulties for the last 3 months. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows a fundus typical of pathological myopia due to the stretching of the retina. The tigroid appearance or tessellated appearance of the fundus can be appreciated. As the eye enlarges, the retinal pigment epithelium becomes thinner, resulting in: A tessellated (checkered) appearance of the fundus Increased visibility of the choroidal vasculature Other features of the myopic fundus are as follows: Lacquer cracks are spontaneous ruptures of the elastic lamina of Bruch’s membrane. It appears yellowish-white. it is usually located in the posterior pole. Annular gray shadow around the optic disc Lattice degeneration Foster Fuchs spots Cystoid degeneration Total retinal atrophy
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A woman with pathological myopia visits the ophthalmology OPD for an annual eye check-up. What is the least likely finding to be seen on her ophthalmologic examination?
explanation: The shallow anterior chamber is not a feature of pathological myopia. Signs of pathological myopia include the following: Prominent eyeballs Large cornea Deep anterior chamber (AC) Fundus picture Large, pale optic disc with the temporal myopic crescent Degenerative changes in retina and choroid Foster Fuchs spots (blackish spots due to retinal pigment epithelial hyperplasia) Lattice degeneration Cystoid degeneration Total retinal atrophy Posterior staphyloma Degenerative changes in the vitreous—posterior vitreous detachment
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is true about degenerative myopia?
options: It is seen in less than 6 dioptres of myopia.
It is more common in males than in females.
Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment.
The condition has no racial prediliction.
explanation: The statement that is true for degenerative myopia is that myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment. Degenerative myopia is seen in more than 6 dioptres of myopia. It is more common in females as compared to males. The condition has a racial predilection; it is more common in Jews and Japanese people, and most cases are of genetic origin. Changes seen in degenerative myopia are myopic crescent, rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (due to degenerative changes in the periphery of the retina with subsequent tear) and floaters (due to degenerative changes in the vitreous).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common complication of pathological myopia?
explanation: Macular degeneration is the most common complication of myopia, followed by rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. Complications of pathological myopia include the following: Macular degeneration Retinal detachment Complicated cataract Vitreous hemorrhage Choroidal hemorrhage Strabismus fixus convergence Primary open-angle glaucoma, which is not a complication, but reported to occur in association with pathological myopia.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: While performing the following procedure on a 35-year-old male at a distance of 1 meter, you found out that the red reflex was not moving with the movement of the instrument. How will you interpret your findings?
explanation: The above image shows the procedure of retinoscopy (skiascopy) being performed. As the red reflex is not moving with the movement of the retinoscope, the patient is interpreted as having myopia of 1D. Retinoscopy is an objective method of determining the error of refraction. It is based on the principle that when light is reflected from a mirror into the eye, the direction in which tlhe light will travel across the pupil depends upon the refractive stale of the eye. Interpretation of retinoscopy done at 1m is: No movement of red reflex: Myopia of 1D Movement of red reflex with retinoscope: Emmetropia, hypermetropia, myopia less than 1D Movement of red reflex against the retinoscope: Myopia more than 1D
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A worried mother brought her son for vision examination when she noticed him reading a book too closely. She says he also narrows his eyes while watching television. Examination revealed myopia. Which of the following lens should be prescribed to correct this child's vision?
explanation: Concave lenses are used for correcting myopic errors. Other options: Option A: Convex lenses are used in the correction of hypermetropic eye and presbyopic eye. Option C: Cylindrical lenses are used in the correction of astigmatism.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statement about the management of myopia is false?
options: In high myopia, it is better to slightly under-correct for distance.
Concave lens is used to correct myopia.
Contact lens provides a wider field and larger image size as compared to glasses.
Myopia must never be under-corrected with spectacles.
explanation: The false statment is that myopia must never be under-corrected with spectacles. In fact, it is better to slightly under-correct cases of high myopia. Concave lens are used to correct myopia. In high myopia, it is better to slightly under-correct to avoid the problem of near vision and that of minification of images. Contact lens are preferred in high myopia as they provide a wider field and larger image size as compared to glasses.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A college student is fed up with wearing spectacles for her myopia. During her annual eye checkup, she asks the ophthalmologist for eye surgery to get rid of the glasses. Which of the following is not a surgical option to correct her refractive error?
explanation: Conductive keratoplasty is a cornea-based surgical procedure used in the correction of hypermetropia. Surgical procedures are undertaken after the stabilization of myopia which usually occurs after 18 years of age.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following laser is used in the treatment of myopia?
explanation: Excimer laser is used in the treament of myopia. Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is the most popular treatment modality for myopia. It is performed using an excimer laser. Surgical correction is only done in individuals who have a stable refractive error for at least 1 year. Corneal thinning disorders must be ruled out prior to this procedure.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A mother asks for LASIK surgery for the correction of her 15-year-old daughter's myopia. Which of the following is not an eligibility criterion for this procedure?
options: Stable refraction for the past 1 year
explanation: Age of 15 years is not a criterion for LASIK surgery. LASIK surgery is performed after 18 years of age. Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser in individuals aged > 18 years who have a stable refractive error for 1 year. It is done in individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment. Corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus must be ruled out before this procedure.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is false about the refractive error in which the image is formed behind the retina?
explanation: Hypermetropia is the refractive error where the image is formed behind the retina. In hypermetropia, near point becomes distant. The near point or punctum proximum is the nearest point at which small objects can be seen clearly. It recedes with age. Hypermetropia is also called long-sightedness since patients are able to focus distant objects more easily than near objects. Accommodative convergent squint in children is a complication of uncorrected long-standing hypermetropia. The fundus may show pseudopapillitis. Hypermetropia is classified into the following types: Latent hypermetropia: Masked by the tone of the ciliary body Facultative hypermetropia: Masked by the voluntary accommodative effort of the person Absolute hypermetropia: Apparent/manifest
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: You have been asked to perform fundoscopy by your senior resident in one of his patients diagnosed with hypermetropia. Which of the following options represent the findings that could be seen in this patient?
explanation: Shot silk appearance with pseudopapillitis can be seen on fundal examination of the hypermetropic eye. Hypermetropia is a refractive error of the eye in which parallel rays of light from infinity focus behind the retina when accommodation is at rest. Fundoscopy findings in hypermetropia include shot silk appearance (retina may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections) and pseudopapillitis (optic disc is small, hypervascular, with ill-defined margins without disc edema). Other signs of hypermetropia include small eyeball, small cornea and short anteroposterior length of the eyeball. Convex lens (plus lens) is used for the correction of hypermetropia.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following grades of error defines high hypermetropia?
explanation: High hypermetropia is defined as an error of >5D.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 50-year-old man wants to undergo surgery for hypermetropia. All of the following are options to treat his refractive error except?
explanation: Photorefractive keratectomy is not the surgical modality of the treatment of hypermetropia. Photorefractive keratectomy is a laser ablation technique for the correction of myopia. An excimer laser is used to cause flattening of the central cornea.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions?
explanation: The given image shows convergent squint or esotropia, which is commonly seen in children with hyperopia, also known as hypermetropia. Esotropia results due to increased accommodative effort in cases where there is under correction of hypermetropia. The condition may be prevented by full hypermetropic correction. If the child is unable to wear the glasses due to flat nasal bridge or if the child is less than 2 years old, the accommodation may be treated with drugs. Miotic drugs with anticholinesterase activity such as di-isopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) or echothiophate can be used in these children. Further treatment may include orthotropic training or surgical correction of the squint.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A boy was brought by his parents for an eye exam. He has been having headaches, nausea, and visual discomfort since he started school. His ophthalmological examination revealed a refractive error of + 2D in the right eye and -1 D in the left eye. His fundus appears to be normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: A child with refractive error of + 2D in the right eye and -1 D in the left eye has anisometropia. Anisometropia is the condition wherein the total refractive power of the two eyes is unequal. A difference of up to 2.5 D between two eyes is well tolerated. If the anisometropia exceeds 2.5D, ambylopia may develop. Contact lenses are preferred for treatment due to less optical defects as compared to glasses.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
What is aniseikonia?
Difference in the axial length of the two eyes
options: Difference in the size of the image formed by the two eyes
Difference in the size of the pupil in the two eyes
Difference in the curvature of the cornea in the two eyes
explanation: Aniseikonia is a condition in which there is a difference in the size of the image formed by the two eyes. Up to 5–8% aniseikonia is well tolerated. Treatment includes contact lens in patients with phakia and intraocular lens implantation in patients with aphakia. Astigmatism and Errors of Accomodation
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 20-year-old girl started having frequent headaches and blurring of vision while studying for college exams. She says she feels better when she closes her eyes. On examination, she is found to have astigmatism. Which of the following is the most common cause responsible for this condition?
options: Irregularity of the curvature of the cornea
Irregularity of the curvature of the lens
explanation: Abnormalities of the curvature of the cornea is the most common cause of astigmatism. Astigmatism is a refractive error in which the rays of light entering the eye are refracted differently in different meridia of the eye. Meridia of the eye correspond to the lines of longitude on a globe. There are two types of astigmatism. In regular astigmatism, refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. In irregular astigmatism, there is irregular change of the refractive power in different meridia. It can be caused by corneal scars. Etiology of regular astigmatism: Corneal: Most common cause. Occurs due to abnormalities of curvature of the cornea Lenticular: Occurs due to abnormalities of lens curvature and position Curvatural: Seen in lenticonus Positional: Due to tilting or oblique placement of the lens or subluxation of lens Retinal: Due to oblique placement of the macula Note: Spherical aberration is a high-order refractive error of the eye. It is seen when light rays passing through the periphery of the cornea and lens focus at a slightly different location than ight rays passing through the center of the cornea and lens. It improves on using a pinhole.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which among the following is normal astigmatism seen in eyes due to the pressure of the eyelids?
explanation: With-the-rule astigmatism is normally seen in the eyes due to the pressure of the eyelids. In with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is more curved. This is more common and often occurs due to the pressure of eyelids on the eye. In against-the-rule astigmatism (ATR) (option B), the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian. In both these types, the principal meridia are vertical and horizontal (90 and 180°) and are at right angles to each other. The other types of astigmatism include oblique and bi-oblique astigmatism. In oblique astigmatism (option C), the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical meridians, although they are at right angles to each other. In bi-oblique astigmatism (option D), the two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other; for example, one may be at 40° and the other, at 100°.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding with-the-rule astigmatism?
options: The horizontal meridian is more myopic.
The vertical meridian is more myopic.
The vertical meridian is more hyperopic.
The horizontal meridian is more hyperopic.
explanation: In with-the-rule astigmatism, the curvature of the vertical meridian is more than the horizontal meridian. Greater the curvature of the meridian, more the myopia of that meridian. Hence, the vertical meridian is more myopic in with-the-rule astigmatism. With-the-rule astigmatism is the type of astigmatism wherein the vertical curvature is always more than the horizontal curvature. Thus, irrespective of the type or cause of with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is always more myopic (curved) than the horizontal meridian.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Match the images shown with the refractive errors they represent.
explanation: The correct answer is 1 - d, 2 - b, 3 - c, 4 - a. Astigmatism is a refractive error in which the rays of light entering the eye are refracted differently in different meridia of the eye. Meridia of the eye correspond to the lines of longitude on a globe. There are two types of astigmatism - regular and irregular. In regular astigmatism, refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. Thus, two principal meridia are present. The rays of light from infinity form two focal points due to the difference in curvature of the two principal meridia. Based on the relation of the two focal points to the retina, regular astigmatism has the following types: Simple astigmatism: One focal point lies on the retina. In simple myopic type, the second foca point lies in front of the retina while in simple hypermetropic type, the second focal point lies behind the retina. Compound astigmatism: In compound hypermetropic type, both focal points lie behind the retina. In compound myopic type, both focal points lie in front of the retina. Mixed astigmatism: One focal point lies in front of while the second focal point lies behind the retina. Imag e Refractive error 1 d. Simple hypermetropic asti gmatism 2 b. Simple myopic astigmatis m 3 c. Compound myopic astigma tism 4 a. Mixed astigmatism
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In compound myopic astigmatism, with parallel rays of light entering the eye in relaxed accommodation, the image(s) formed is/are .
options: One focal point in front of the retina
Two focal lines in front of the retina
Two focal lines behind the retina
Two focal lines, one behind and the other in front of retina
explanation: In compound myopic astigmatism, parallel rays of light entering the eye in relaxed accommodation form two focal lines in front of the retina. Option A: One focal point in front of retina describes myopia. Option C: Two focal lines behind the retina describes compound hypermetropic astigmatism. Option D: Two focal lines, one behind and one in front of the retina describes mixed astigmatism.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?
explanation: Among the above options, -1.00 DC × 180° is the correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism (SMA). There are 3 components for prescription of glasses. The first number is the refractive power of the spherical component. It is represented as convex (+) or concave (-) dioptre sphere (DS). The second number denotes the power of the cylinder, represented as convex (+) or concave (-) dioptre cylinder (DC). The above two components are followed by an x representing the axis (orientation) of the cylinder. In the most common type of SMA - with-the-rule astigmatism - meridian A (represented by 90°) is more curved than meridian B (represented by 180°). The light rays refracting from B focus on the retina, whereas those refracting from A focus in front of the retina. To correct this error, a negative cylindrical lens (DC) is used to focus the myopic rays of meridian A on the retina. This correction needs to occur at 90° (meridian A). The axis of a cylindrical lens is perpendicular to the required correction and thus, the spectacles will have an axis of 180°. There is no spherical refractive error since the light rays from meridian B lies on the retina. Thus DS is 0.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The PARK procedure is used in the correction of which of the following?
explanation: PARK is a technique used for correcting astigmatism. Photo-astigmatic refractive keratotomy (PARK) is performed using excimer laser for the correction of astigmatism. The other surgical procedures used for correction of astigmatism are astigmatic keratotomy, LASIK and SMILE.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An 80-year-old man is reading a newspaper in his backyard. His accommodation while reading a newspaper is due to .
explanation: Near vision accommodation is due to the contraction of the ciliary muscle. Accommodation is the phenomenon of increasing the convergence power. This occurs by increasing the refractive power of the lens and increasing its curvature. The capsule of the lens is more elastic than the lens itself and plays a role in increasing the curvature of the lens. When the circular fibres of the ciliary muscles contract, the ciliary body approaches the lens. This slackens the zonules so that the capsule, relieved of its tension, is able to mould the lens to its accommodative form.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: During a routine school eye examination camp, a 5-year-old boy is able to read everything written on the board. Which of the following mechanisms aids in establishing normal distant vision in this child?
options: Shortening of the focal length of the lens
explanation: Relaxation of the ciliary muscles would aid in establishing a normal distant vision. Relaxation of the ciliary muscles keeps the zonules in a taut state and maintains the radius of curvature of the anterior lens surface at 10 mm. Thus, the focal length is maximum and distant objects are most clearly visualized. Option B: The pupils constrict during accommodation to increase the depth of focus. Option C: During accommodation, ciliary muscles contract causing relaxation of zonular fibers, rounding of the lens, and shortening of the focal length. Option D: The radius of curvature of the anterior lens surface becomes 6 mm i.e rounder during accommodation.
subject: Ophthalmology

subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the accommodative amplitude of a patient with a near point at 20 cm and a far point at infinity?
explanation: The amplitude of accommodation for the above patient would be 5. Near point of accommodation (NPA) is the closest distance at which the near object is clearly focussed without blur. Amplitude of accommodation is the maximum power of the lens that permits clear near vision without blur. Its unit is dioptre (D). The amplitude of accommodation is the reciprocal of NPA in meters. 20 cm is 1/5th of a meter. Therefore, accommodative amplitude is its inverse, that is, 5D. The NPA is measured clinically using a scale device such as the Prince, Berens, or Royal Air Force (RAF) ruler.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 45 year old woman complains of an inability to read books and stitch garments for the past few months. Which of the following is false regarding her condition?
options: Decrease in elasticity and plasticity of the crystalline lens
Age-related decrease in the power of ciliary muscles
It is corrected with a concave lens
explanation: A 45 year old woman presenting with an inability to do near vision work (reading, stitching) likely has presbyopia. Presbyopia is corrected by the use of a convex lens (weakest convex lens). Presbyopia can be caused by an age-related decline in the ciliary muscle power or age-related change in the lens including: • Hardness (sclerosis) of the lens substance, which is less easily molded Decrease in the elasticity of lens capsule
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 51-year-old woman comes for an ophthalmological examination. She says she is unable to thread a needle and is facing difficulty making a sweater for her grandson. She never had vision problems in her youth. What power of glasses would roughly correct her vision difficulties?
explanation: The power of prescription glasses for a 51-year-old woman should be +1.5D. Presbyopia is the condition of decreased near vision. It is due to an age-related decrease in the amplitude of accommodation or an increase in punctum proximum (near point). For correction of presbyopia, convex lenses are used. Roughly, the power of prescription glasses age-wise is as follows: Age Power 45 ye ars +1 to +1.25 D 50 ye ars +1.5 to 1.75 D 55 ye ars +2 to +2.25 D 60 ye ars +2.5 to +3D
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: During your morning jogging routine, you found a pair of spectacles lying on the sidewalk. The spectacles are shown below. What type of presbyopic lens is present in these spectacles?
explanation: The given lens in the image is a typical example of progressive lenses. Progressive lenses are identified as such due to the absence of the line of demarcation on the lens. They are gradually optimized for reading vision, distant vision, and for intermediate vision, such as computer work.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A 55-year-old male with limbal scar presents to the ophthalmology clinic with marked defects in both near and far vision. Clinical examination reveals a wide and deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and a dark pupillary reflex. A vision of 6/6 is achieved with correcting lens of
+11D. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: A limbal scar with defective near and distant vision, a wide and deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and dark pupillary reflex suggests aphakia. Aphakia is the condition in which the lens is absent from the pupillary area. Signs of surgical aphakia include limbal scar, deeper anterior chamber than normal, iridodonesis (tremulousness of the iris), jet black color of the pupil. On Purkinje's test, only the first and second images are seen. A small disc is seen on fundus examination and high hypermetropia is seen on retinoscopy. The best treatment option is secondary intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is used to differentiate pseudophakia from aphakia?
explanation: Pseudophakia shows 4 images in the Purkinje image test, whereas aphakia shows only 2 images. Other features can be seen in both. When aphakia is corrected with an intraocular lens implant (IOL), the condition is referred to as pseudophakia. Signs of pseudophakia with posterior chamber IOL include: Surgical scar Anterior chamber slightly deeper than norma Mild iridodonesis (tremulousness) of the iris Purkinje image test shows 4 images Pupil blackish in color but when the light is thrown in the pupillary area, shining reflex is observed Purkinje images are reflections of objects from the structure of the eye. They are also known as Purkinje reflexes or Purkinje–Sanson images. Normally, 4 images are formed from four different reflecting surfaces i.e. Imag e Location Directi on Imag e 1 Anterior surface of the corne a Erect Imag e 2 Posterior surface of the corne a Erect Imag e 3 Anterior surface of the lens Erect Imag e 4 Posterior surface of the lens Inverte d In aphakia, as the lens is absent, image 3 and image 4 are absent.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Roving–ring scotoma is seen after the correction of aphakia by which of the following?
explanation: Roving-ring scotoma is seen in the correction of aphakia with spectacles due to prismatic effects at the edge of the lens. The difficulties in the correction of aphakia by spectacles include the following: Image magnification by 25–30% Spherical aberrations producing a “pin cushion effect” Jack-in-the-box phenomenon from the prismatic effects at the edge of the lens Reduced visual fields Physical inconvenience For aphakia, the best correction is obtained by an intraocular lens (IOL). Roving-ring scotoma: The edge of a convex lens acts as a prism. The greater the angle of the prism, the more will be the bending. In aphakic spectacles, the angle of the lens is large. Thus, the light falling at the edge of the lens bends towards the center of the lens and does not reach the pupil. This results in a ring-shaped scotoma as this prismatic effect is present all around the edges of the lens. The position of this scotoma is not fixed in the visual field because the eye keeps moving (or roving) in relation to the aphakic spectacle. Hence, the result is a roving ring scotoma.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which among the following is not an advantage of contact lens?
options: It helps in eliminating peripheral aberrations.
It is helpful in dry eye.
explanation: Contact lenses decrease corneal oxygen supply. The cornea obtains its O2 supply from the atmosphere. The use of contact lenses decreases the O2 supply from the atmosphere. Contact lens eliminate peripheral aberrations and can correct irregular astigmatism. Although dry eye is caused by wearing contact lenses, lenses made of hydrogel which are high in water content are beneficial in dry eye. Rigid gas-permeable/semi-soft contact lens are used for keratoconus. Toric contact lens are used for astigmatism.

Presbyopia
explanation: The given image shows spectacles made of lenses with two different optical power. Thus, it is a pair of bifocal spectacles which is not used in hypermetropia or myopia. Bifocal glasses have different corrective powers in the upper segment for distant vision and lower segment for near vision. Thus, they are useful in conditions where both distance and near vision are affected, like the following: Presbyopia (option A): It is a definitive indication. It is used to correct age-related near and far vision defects. Aphakia (option B): It provides both near and far vision correction when intra-ocular lens insertion is contraindicated. Paediatric pseudophakia (option C): It is used to correct refractive errors or accommodative fluctuations post intra-ocular lens (IOL) insertion. question_text: Which of the following characteristic features would you expect to see in a histopathology slide of conjunctiva?
options: Amacrine cells within non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Goblet cells within non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Goblet cells within keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Amacrine cells within keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
explanation: The presence of goblet cells within the non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium would help identify the conjunctiva. Goblet cells are involved in the secretion of mucin. Amacrine cells are a type of retinal interneuron, and hence would be found in the retina, not the conjunctiva.

question_text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis?
explanation: Moraxella species, a type of gram-negative diplobacilli, are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis which is a type of chronic conjunctivitis. Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis where there is inflammation of the conjunctiva at the lid margins and the inner and outer canthi of the eyes with red, scaly, excoriated, macerated and fissured skin at the canthi. This is because of the proteolytic enzymes secreted by the Moraxella species. Patients with angular conjunctivitis usually experience eye irritation, a burning sensation and collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles. These patients can also have associated blepharitis and papillary and follicular conjunctivitis. Causative organisms are Moraxella lacunata, Moraxella axenfeld and Staphylococcus aureus (Rare cause). The source of infection is typically the nasal tract or the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs. Treatment includes oxytetracycline 1% ointment for 10 to 14 days, and zinc oxide as it inhibits proteolytic enzymes. The image given below shows the eye of a patient infected with angular conjunctivitis. Other options: Option B: Haemophilus influenzae causes acute conjunctivitis. Option C: Adenovirus is the most common cause of viral conjunctivitis and it most commonly causes follicular conjunctivitis, pharyngoconjunctival fever, and epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. Option D: Coxsackie B virus is known to cause aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, pericarditis, and myocarditis. There are no known mentions of ocular disease caused by the virus. question_text: A child presents with irritation and redness of the left eye at a primary health center. There are no previous immunization records. Examination showed a greyish-white membrane over the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva which bled on peeling. What is the likely etiology?
explanation: The of a child with irritation and redness of the eye with no previous vaccination records is suggestive of a case of membranous conjunctivitis and among the given options, Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the most likely etiological agent. Membranous conjunctivitis presents with irritation and redness of the eye and is characterized by the formation of a greyish-white membrane that bleeds on peeling. Vaccines are routinely used to prevent diphtheria infection and hence, unvaccinated status increases his susceptibility to the bacteria. Moreover, the bacteria thrive in crowded populations and poor hygienic surroundings, hence a background of low socioeconomic context, such as an orphanage, acts as a risk factor in this case. This condition is associated with the formation of fibrinous exudates on the surface and into the substance of the conjunctival epithelium. The causes include beta-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus pneumonia, Haemophilus aegyptius, Corynebacterium diphtheria, and Neisseria gonorrhea The image given below shows the eye of a patient with pseudomembranous conjunctivitis. It differs from membranous conjunctivitis in that the membrane can be easily peeled off in this condition leaving an intact underlying epithelium.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A child with pharyngitis, and fever subsequently develops conjunctivitis. Initially, the left eye was affected, followed by the right eye's involvement in 2 days. Epiphora, conjunctival
hyperemia, and chemosis are noted. What is its most likely etiological agent?
explanation: This child with pharyngitis and subsequent involvement of the eyes most likely has pharyngoconjunctival fever. This condition is commonly caused by adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, and 7. Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute and highly infectious illness characterized by fever, pharyngitis, acute follicular conjunctivitis, and regional lymphoid hyperplasia with tender, enlarged preauricular adenopathy. Within the classical triad, symptoms may vary in severity. It is usually bilateral, with one eye typically having onset 1-3 days prior to the second eye. It is a self-limiting disease and treatment is mainly symptomatic, as follows: Cold compresses several times per day for 1-2 weeks. Artificial tears 4-8 times per day for 1-3 weeks. Newcastle conjunctivitis is usually clinically indistinguishable from this condition and is derived from contact with diseased fowls. Another conjunctivitis caused by adenovirus serotypes 8, 19 and 37 is known as epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. The image given below shows the eye of a patient with pharyngoconjunctival fever. Significant conjunctival hyperemia, petechial subconjunctival hemorrhages, and conjunctival follicles are noted.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
options: The condition is commonly associated with a benign course.
It can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension.
The blood gets absorbed gradually in 6-8 weeks time without treatment.
Use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.
explanation: The image given above shows a subconjunctival haemorrhage in the eye. In this condition, the blood gets absorbed gradually in 1-3 weeks time without treatment. A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension or after local trauma. The condition is commonly associated with a benign course but, if the posterior limit of the hemorrhage is not seen, one should check for the base of the skull fracture. Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukaemia. The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A UNICEF volunteer presented with a bilateral red eye of 2 days duration beginning on a return flight from Ghana. The infection spread among all her family members within a day of her return. Initial examination revealed lid edema, serous discharge, and severe
sub-conjunctival hemorrhage. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient with bilateral red-eye and a rapid spread of infection to family members points towards a likely diagnosis of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Examination findings of lid edema, serous discharge, and subconjunctival hemorrhage further consolidate this diagnosis. Causes: Enterovirus 70 (most important) Coxsackievirus 24 Echovirus 34 Adenovirus Pneumococcus Haemophilus There is no treatment currently available. The infection generally resolves itself within a five to seven-day period. The use of steroids can actually cause a corneal microbial superinfection which then requires antimicrobial therapy to eliminate. The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the cause of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
explanation: Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by picornoviruses namely enterovirus 70. Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis also known as "Apollo conjunctivitis" is caused by picornoviruses such as enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus A24. Rarely it is also caused by adenovirus type 11. It manifests with severe conjunctival congestion, chemosis, subconjunctival hemorrhages, painful follicular conjunctivitis, tearing, lid edema and pre-auricular lymphadenopathy. The cornea may demonstrate a fine punctate keratopathy. The disease is usually self-limiting, running a course of 3-7 days. The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Enterovirus 71 (Option D) is associated with fatal meningitis, encephalitis, and paralysis. It is also implicated in Hand-Foot-Mouth disease(HFMD) and Herpangia which is papulo-vesiculo-ulcerative rash in oral cavity.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A tribal farmer, presented with a three-day history of right eye redness with pain. He had spent the prior week trekking up a mountain in order to travel to the nearby town and takes such trips frequently. The following lesion was observed on examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of right eye redness with pain, and findings of a raised whitish-yellowish lesion surrounded by mild erythema, points toward a likely diagnosis of pinguecula. A history of trekking, along with chronic sunlight exposure as a farmer, acts as a risk factor because it increases the exposure to the stronger UV radiation in the mountains. Pinguecula has a fatty appearance and is usually bilateral. They are more often located nasally than temporally. It has horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area. They are associated with a 2- to 3-fold increased incidence of age-related macular degeneration. It is seen in most eyes by 70 years of age and in almost all by 80 years of age. Pingueculitis responds to a brief course of NSAIDs or topical corticosteroids. Simple excision may be warranted in rare cases, wherein pingueculae may be chronically inflamed or cosmetically unsatisfactory.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below?
explanation: The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium. Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is a degenerative condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue and is never inflammatory. It occurs due to exposure to UV-B radiation and the most common site is the nasal. It is made up of three parts, "cap" (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head, and a body. Clinical features: Astigmatism with the rule - most common finding Stocker's line - deposition of iron on the advancing edge Fuchs islets - small, discrete, whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells, often present at the advancing edge. The differential diagnosis is pseudo pterygium. The treatment for pterygium is usually excision. To prevent a recurrence, mitomycin C or 5 fluorouracil is used. Other methods: Auto-grafting- Conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAG) from the superior limbal conjunctiva is the best method. Bare sclera technique- high recurrence rate of 30 to 80%. PERFECT surgery- zero rates of recurrence. (PERFECT stands for Pterygium Extended Remova Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant) Pterygium Pseudo-pterygium Degenerativeprocess Inflammatoryprocess Occurs inelderly Can occur at any age Situated at thepalpebral aper ture Can occur at any site Either progressive, regressive, or stationary Always stationary Aprobe cannotbepassedunde rneath A probe can be passed under the neck

question_text: The excision of a pinkish, triangular tissue growth at the 1 o’clock position of the eye is being performed. The patient had a history of blurry vision and persistent redness in both eyes for a month. In order to secure the graft in the scleral bed, which of the following will not be used?
explanation: The given clinical vignette, with symptoms of blurry vision and persistent redness, along with findings of an abnormal triangular mass of thickened conjunctiva, is suggestive of pterygium. Cyanoacrylate is not used for pterygium surgery. The various glues used in ophthalmology are as follows: Cyanoacrylate glue- Mainly used as a corneal patch to seal acute corneal perforations and improve visual outcomes, with reduced enucleation rates and need for tectonic keratoplasty Fibrin glue- It is a biological adhesive, which reduces the total surgical time. It is used in cornea and conjunctival surgeries, squint surgeries, cataract (to fix the haptics of intraocular lens [IOL] to the tissue in place of sutures in glued IOL), refractive surgeries, trabeculectomy, and even retina surgeries. Newer tissue adhesives like bio-dendrimers and photo-cross-linkable adhesives- Bovine serum albumin-based bioadhesives: used in squint surgery Riboflavin-based bioadhesive activated on exposure to ultraviolet A: used in post-LASIK ectasia, infectious keratopathy, pseudophakic bullous keratopathy Hyaluronic acid-based photocatalytic glue activated with argon LASER: used in the repair of corneal lacerations
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A man presented with red eyes associated with a sandy, gritty sensation. He was diagnosed with conjunctivitis last week, however, his symptoms persisted. He has had multiple sexual partners in the past. Examination revealed palpable preauricular nodes and a follicular
reaction involving the bulbar conjunctiva and semilunar folds. Conjunctival scrapings were sent for culture. What is the likely organism involved?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of red eyes, along with the examination findings of palpable preauricular nodes and follicular reaction involving the bulbar conjunctiva and semilunar folds, is suggestive of inclusion conjunctivitis. It is also known as chlamydial conjunctivitis, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D–K. It is a sexually transmitted disease occurring commonly in young adults. The modes of transmission include orogenital activities and hand-to-eye spread of infective genital secretions. Hence, it is important to treat all sexual partners simultaneously to prevent re-infection and to rule out other venereal diseases, such as gonorrhoea and syphilis. Treatment includes a single 1g dose of azithromycin or doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 7 days. The image given below shows the eye of a patient with chlamydial conjunctivitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following conditions is closely related to mucus fishing syndrome?
explanation: Mucus fishing syndrome is closely related to giant papillary conjunctivitis. In Mucus fishing syndrome, patients develop a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manual removal of mucus. The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC). It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). The increased risk in contact lens users is because of the build-up of proteinaceous deposits and cellular debris on the contact lens surface. It may be also be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A young man presented with watering, redness and photophobia. He had similar complaints in the past which improved with self-medicated topical drops. His best-corrected visual acuity is 6/36 improving to 6/24. Slit-lamp examination revealed a 3 mm × 2 mm epithelial defect in the paracentral part of the cornea that stained positive with fluorescein dyes. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of spring catarrh. Slit-lamp examination finding of shield ulcer is typical of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or warm weather conjunctivitis (another name of VKC). Shield ulcers are transverse ulcers seen in the upper cornea due to epithelial macroerosions in VKC. It is a rare complication of VKC and should always be kept in mind for patients suffering from vernal conjunctivitis. Corneal signs in VKC: Shield ulcers Vernal plaques Subepithelial scarring Pseudo-gerontoxon- resembles arcus senilus; has a cupid's bow outline Treatment of VKC is mainly with allergy avoidance and lid hygiene. Cool compresses, topical antihistamines, topical NSAIDs and topical steroids can be used to reduce the intensity of symptoms. The image given below shows a shield ulcer in a patient with VKC.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: While browsing through the news channels, Geeta came across a panel discussion on public health diseases celebrating the elimination of a peculiar condition of the eye. It was known as the most important cause of corneal blindness in India and shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva is seen in trachoma. It was the most important cause of corneal blindness in India affecting young children. question_text: A young girl has been brought in by her grandmother because she has constant pain, photosensitivity and discharge from her eyes. From the notes, you see that the child has had multiple presentations for prior eye infections. You observe severe scarring on the palpebral conjunctiva, as well as trachomatous trichiasis. Which McCallan stage will this be classified under?
explanation: The clinical vignette of a young child with pain, photosensitivity and discharge, having repeated infections, along with findings of scarring and trichiasis is suggestive of trachoma. Cicatrising trachoma is stage 3 of trachoma and is characterized by scarring of the palpebral conjunctiva. Cicatricial trachoma is the end result of scarring that occurs in individuals who suffer from severe, persistent infections in childhood. Trachomatous scarring is recognized by the presence of easily visible white bands on the underside of the upper eyelid. Severe scarring can result in contraction of the tarsal conjunctiva which causes the lid margin to roll inwards. This results in buckling of the lid so the lashes rub on the eye known as trachomatous trichiasis. These lashes can lead to corneal opacities and scarring and eventually blindness. The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows: Stage 1: Incipient - Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious. Stage 2: Established - Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring. Stage 3: Cicatrising - Scarring along with active infection. Stage 4: Healed - Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet. The image below shows trachomatous trichiasis with severe scarring-
