question_text: What is the drug of choice under the SAFE strategy for trachoma management?
explanation: Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in the SAFE strategy of trachoma management. The adult dose is 1 g while 20 mg/kg body weight is given for children. Oral azithromycin is slowly replacing tetracycline eye ointment as the first line drug used in trachoma treatment. The experience of Morocco, the first country that used azithromycin in a large-scale, nationwide elimination programme, has paved the way for the worldwide application of azithromycin as part of the SAFE strategy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 21-year-old man presented with the following lesion in his eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image depicts Bitot's spot, a pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia. Hence, the likely diagnosis in this 21-year-old man presenting with the above lesion is xerophthalmia. Bitot's spot is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva which is usually bilateral. The most common site is temporal.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 10 year old malnourished boy is brought with a 2-month history of diminished night vision. His dietary history revealed a restricted diet, consisting of mainly chips and nuggets, and he would refuse to eat green leafy vegetables. What is the conjunctival change seen in this deficiency?
explanation: The given clinical scenario indicates that this patient has nyctalopia (diminished night vision) most likely due to vitamin A deficiency, suggested by his poor consumption of vegetables. Changes seen in the conjunctiva in vitamin A deficiency is hyperkeratosis of the squamous epithelium. This occurs due to the metaplasia of the non-keratinized epithelium to keratinized epithelium.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Ophthalmia nodosa occurs due to which of the following?
explanation: Ophthalmia nodosa occurs due to irritation due to caterpillar hair. It is often mistaken for tuberculosis. On examination, small, semitranslucent, reddish and yellowish-grey nodules are formed in the conjunctiva, cornea, and iris. Microscopy contains caterpillar hair surrounded by giant cells and lymphocytes. Treatment includes excision of the nodules in the conjunctiva. The image below shows a patient's eye infected with ophthalmia nodosa.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 28-year-old woman with redness and photophobia of the left eye was seen in the OPD. An image of a characteristic lesion of her eye is as shown below. Identify the lesion.
explanation: The given image shows a white-pinkish nodule surrounded by hyperemia on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus with associated symptoms of redness and photophobia most likely has phlyctenular conjunctivitis. The given finding is referred to as a phlycten. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is characterized by the following: Phlycten that may eventually form ring ulcers Shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten known as scrofulous ulcer Fascicular ulcer with a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels that heals leaving a band-shaped opacity Treatment: Topical steroids; atropine if the cornea is involved. Note: This can be differentiated from pinguecula by the following points: Pinguecula is a yellow triangular patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus. It usually remains free from conjunctival congestion. The following image shows a yellow patch with tortuous blood vessels. There is no congestion as seen with a phlycten.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following should not be considered in the differential of a patient who presents with the following finding?
explanation: The given image shows symblepharon, which is not seen in phlyctenular conjunctivitis. It is a partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva of the eyelid to the bulbar conjunctiva of the eyeball. Causes of symblepharon: Chemical injuries (especially alkalis) Burns Ocular cicatrical pemphigoid (OCP) Steven–Johnson syndrome Erythema multiforme Pemphigus bullosa Membranous conjunctivitis Management: Lubrication Sweeping of fornices Symblepharon ring Symblepharon release and amniotic membrane graft
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?
explanation: Chlamydia is at present the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatarum in developed countries. Ophthalmia neonatarum also called neonatal conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva occurring in an infant <30 days after birth.It should be ruled out in any infant having discharge or watering within the first week of birth. Causes include: Chlamydia(Option A): neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by serotypes D-K is at present the most common cause in developed countries. Gonorrhoea(Option B): effective prophylaxis against gonococcal infection and its subsequent decline has almost eliminated it's incidence in developed countries. Staphylococcus aureus(Option D), Haemophilus species, Streptococcus haemolyticus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae are other less commonly seen causes of ophthalmia neonatarum Herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatrum rarely occurs and is caused by Herpes simplex type 2 virus from the mother. Chemical conjunctivitis(Option C) is caused by the application of prophylactic antibiotics or silver nitrate at the time of birth. Time of presentatio n Causative agent Within 48 h Chemical, Gonorrhoea 48–72 h Staphylococcus aureus,Strept ococcus pneumoniae 5–7 days Herpes simplex II >1 week Chlamydia Prophylactic treatment: 1% tetracycline or erythromycin eye ointment is applied to the eyes, if the mother is suspected to have gonococcal or chlamydia infection. Curative treatment: Chlamydia trachomatis (D– K)- Erythromycin eye ointment Neisseria gonorrhoeae- Ceftriaxone injection, gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment The below image shows an infant presenting with ophthalmia neonatarum.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An 8-year-old boy had to miss school because the matting of his eyelids made it difficult to open them in the morning and caused severe pain. His agonized mother rushed him to the hospital and reported that he had a fever and red eye for 4 days. Which group of lymph nodes is likely to be enlarged?
explanation: The clinical scenario of fever and red eyes, associated with matting of eyelids and pain, is suggestive of conjunctivitis. Lymph from the conjunctiva drains directly into the submandibular and preauricular nodes and hence, these group of lymph nodes are likely to be enlarged. The lymphatic drainage of the conjunctiva is as follows- From the medial side, one-third of the superior and medial two-thirds of the inferior conjunctiva  Submandibular nodes From the lateral side, two-thirds of the superior conjunctiva and lateral one-third of the inferior conjunctiva  Preauricular nodes Specialized collections of T and B lymphocytes underlying a modified epithelium is known as conjunctiva-associated lymphoid tissue (CALT) present in the stroma (substantia propria). It is critical in the initiation and regulation of ocular-surface immune responses. Note: The stroma also consists of the accessory lacrimal glands of Krause and Wolfring which are exocrine glands responsible for the basal secretion of the middle aqueous layer of the tear film. The image given below shows the lymphatic drainage of the conjunctiva.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The image of the eye of a 32-year-old woman having superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis is given below. Which of the following is commonly associated with it?
explanation: Superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis has a definite association with thyroid dysfunction. It affects one or both eyes of middle-aged women and about 65% of patients have abnormal thyroid function (usually hyperthyroidism). It is a chronic disease of the superior limbus and the superior bulbar and the tarsal conjunctiva. Clinical features: Papillary hypertrophy of the superior tarsal plate, often having a diffuse velvety appearance. Hyperemia of a radial band of the superior bulbar conjunctiva that stains with rose bengal. Superior filamentary keratitis that develops in about one-third of cases. Management: Preservative-free lubricants Topical acetylcysteine 10% to 20%, four times daily to break down filaments Topical rebamipide
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is not characteristic of pterygium?
options: Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue.
Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen.
Destruction of Bowman's layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea.
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctiva occur.
explanation: Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the conjunctival connective tissue occurs in pinguecula (and not pterygium). In pterygium, there is elastotic degeneration of collagen with fibrovascular proliferation. It is important to distinguish a pterygium from a pinguecula. A pterygium, while histologically similar to a pinguecula, is distinguished by fibrovascular tissue that grows onto the cornea. Pingueculae do not have vascularized tissue and do not cross the limbus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. On examination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen. Vernal conjunctivitis is also called spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis. It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years. It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. Classical features of the conjunctiva in VKC: Palpebral VKC - Cobblestone papillae are present in the upper tarsal conjunctiva associated with ropy discharge. Maxwell–Lyon sign is present which is a pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat Limbal VKC - Horner – Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. The image given below shows Horner-Trantas spots. Treatment of this condition is with topical steroids and mast cell stabilizers such as cromolyn sodium. Topical cyclosporine can be used in patients who do not respond to first line treatment modalities.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Your professor has assigned you to proofread a seminar on the anatomy of the conjunctiva made by a junior. In the explanation of conjunctival follicles, you spot a wrong statement that needs revision. What is that statement?
options: Conjunctiva of new born does not produce follicles before 2-3 months of age.
Slit lamp may be necessary to differentiate between follicles and papillae.
Follicles are a hyperplasia of the normal vascular system.
Follicles are found in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer of the conjunctiva.
explanation: Papillae (not follicles) are hyperplasia of the normal vascular system, with glomerulus-like branches of capillaries growing into the epithelium in inflammatory conditions. On the other hand, follicles are yellowish-white, round elevations of 1-2 mm diameter. Follicles are a localized aggregation of lymphocytes present in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer of the conjunctiva. Image: Conjunctival papillae (hyperplastic epithelium and capillaries) shown in the first image followed by conjunctival giant follicles (round yellowish-white elevations) shown in the second image.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
In the grading of trachoma, the follicular stage is defined by the presence of which of the following?
5 or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva
options: 3 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
5 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
3 or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva
explanation: In the grading of trachoma, follicular stage is defined by the presence of 5 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva. Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of blindness worldwide. It is caused by an obligate intracellular bacterium called Chlamydia trachomatis Serotypes A–C. The infection is transmitted by direct or indirect transfer of eye and nose discharges of infected people, particularly young children who harbour the principal reservoir of infection. The image below shows the follicular stage of trachoma - Sclera
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the innermost layer of the sclera?
explanation: Lamina fusca is the innermost layer of the sclera. Lamina fusca faces the choroid. It is the transition zone between the sclera and the choroid. It consists of a delicate meshwork of elastic fibres, fibrocytes and melanocytes, traversed by long posterior ciliary nerves and vessels. Layers of the sclera from outside to inside include episclera, sclera proper, and lamina fusca, in that order.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The sclera is the thinnest at which of the following locations?
options: Anterior to attachment of the superior rectus
Posterior to attachment of the superior rectus
explanation: The sclera is the thinnest posterior to the insertion of the rectus muscles. The sclera is 1mm thick posteriorly, with maximum thickness around the optic nerve, 0.66 mm at the insertions of the rectus muscles and 0.33 mm beneath the rectus muscles and thinnest behind their insertions
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient sustained a severe blow to the right eye from the lateral side during a fistfight. The eyeball is soft to touch and a rupture of the sclera is suspected. What is the least likely site of rupture?
explanation: The lateral limbus is the least likely site to be involved in a traumatic scleral rupture. Traumatic scleral rupture, or globe rupture, occurs after blunt-force trauma. It usually occurs due to the compression force of the trauma. It therefore likely occurs at the insertion of rectus muscles, at the equator, or in an area parallel to the limbus opposite from the site of the impact. Rupture at the site of trauma, in this case lateral limbus, is rare. The major signs of scleral rupture are conjunctival edema and subconjunctival hemorrhage, hyphema, ocular hypotony, impairment or dislocation of the lens, vitreous hemorrhage, and retinal detachment.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the predominant type of collagen in the sclera?
explanation: Collagen type I is the predominant type of collagen found in the sclera. Collagen forms 50 to 75% of the dry weight of the sclera. Type II is absent in the sclera. It is found in the vitreous body of the eye.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient with glaucoma presents with a bulging cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: High intraocular pressure leads to the thinning of the outer tunics of the eyeball such as cornea and sclera, thereby resulting in their ectasia (bulging) which is known as staphyloma. Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma. Staphyloma is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera. Types of Staphyloma: Types Pathology Causes Anterior staphyloma Due to bulging of the pseudo cornea, internally lined by th e iris & externally by the newl y formed epithelium. Sloughing corneal ulcer Intercalary staphylom a Due to bulging of weakened l imbal tissue at the limbus, in ternally lined by the root of ir is & the anterior most part of the ciliary body Developmental glaucomaSec ondary angle closure glauco maHealing of perforating inj uryPeripheral corneal ulcer Ciliary staphyloma Due to bulging of the weaken ed sclera, internally lined by the ciliary body, can extend u p to 8mm behind the limbus ScleritisEnd stage glaucomaP erforating injuries Equatorial staphylom a Due to bulging of sclera with choroidal lining, seen around 14 mm behind the limbus, in the equatorial region ScleritisChronic uncontrolled glaucomaScleral degeneratio n in pathological myopia Posterior staphyloma Due to bulging of sclera lined by the choroid, seen behind the equator Posterior scleritisPathologica l myopiaPerforating injuries Keratoconus (Option A) is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissue. It usually starts at puberty and progresses slowly, not associated with risk factors like glaucoma. Therefore, we can rule out keratoconus in this patient.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Staphyloma involves .
explanation: Staphyloma (a bunch of grapes) is a clinical condition characterized by ectasia (dilation or bulging) of the outer coats (cornea or sclera or both) of the eye with the incarceration (trapping) of the uveal tissue. The image given below shows the anatomical types of staphyloma. The above image shows an anterior staphyloma.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The ciliary staphyloma is due to which of the following?
explanation: Ciliary staphyloma is due to scleritis. Ciliary staphyloma is the ectasia (bulging) of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone that includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus. It can be caused by scleritis, absolute glaucoma or trauma to the ciliary region of the eye. The image below shows ciliary staphyloma with scleritis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
explanation: I itation in the eye associated with areas of scleral thinning through which the uvea shines is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity of the sclera is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue. Other collagen disorders associated with it are as follows: Wegener’s granulomatosis (option B) Polyarteritis nodosa (option A) Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) Ankylosing spondylitis Relapsing polychondritis
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The most common type of scleritis is .
explanation: Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis is the most common type of scleritis. Scleritis can be classified into anterior and posterior scleritis. Anterior scleritis affects the sclera in front of the equator, while posterior scleritis affects the sclera behind the equator of the eye. Anterior scleritis is further classified into the following types: Non-necrotizing Diffuse: The most common variety Nodular: Scleral nodules are present. Annular scleritis is a variant in which the scleral nodules are arranged in a ring around the limbus. Necrotizing With inflammation Without inflammation: Also known as scleromalacia perforans. It is seen in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. The image below shows anterior nodular scleritis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: All the following statements are true for a 40-year-old diagnosed with scleritis except-
options: Scleromalacia perforans is associated with systemic disease.
Pain is not a prominent feature.
Retinal detachment is a known complication.
explanation: Pain is a prominent feature of scleritis. Scleritis is an inflammation of the sclera. Patients present with moderate to severe eye pain, redness, lacrimation and photophobia. Anterior scleritis affects the sclera in front of the equator and may lead to the following complications: Acute infiltrative stromal keratitis Sclerosing keratitis Peripheral ulcerative keratitis Uveitis Glaucoma Hypotony (rarely phthisis) Perforation of the sclera Posterior scleritis involves the sclera behind the equator and may lead to uveal effusion with choroidal detachment, disc edema, proptosis or exudative retinal detachment. Scleromalacia perforans is a type of anterior scleritis. It typically occurs in elderly women with rheumatoid arthritis (systemic disease). There is ischemia and necrosis of the sclera; however, there is no inflammation. Clinically, it is a painless condition with a white eye. Areas of thinned out sclera through which the uvea shines are seen in such patients.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 63-year-old woman presented with a two-week history of gradually worsening sharp and stabbing left eye pain with redness. The severe pain kept her awakened during the night. On investigation, B-scan ultrasound shows the 'T' sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon space. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of severe worsening eye pain with redness and a B-scan showing T sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon space is suggestive of posterior scleritis. Posterior scleritis is the inflammation involving the sclera behind the equator. Ultrasonography in posterior scleritis may show the following: Increased scleral thickness Scleral nodules Separation of tenon capsule from the sclera Disc oedema Choroidal folds Retinal detachment Fluid in the sub-tenon space may give a characteristic "T" sign. The stem of the "T" is formed by the optic nerve and the cross-bar by the fluid-containing gap. The image given below shows a B-scan ocular ultrasound of the eye.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient develops surgically induced necrotising scleritis following an ocular surgery. The patient most likely underwent any of the following surgeries except:
explanation: Surgically induced necrotizing scleritis (SINS) may occur following any ocular surgery involving the creation of a scleral wound. Tarso-frontalis sling surgery is a lid surgery and does not involve the sclera. SINS is a condition of scleral inflammation and necrosis that may occur as a complication of the following surgeries: Pterygium excision Cataract surgery (especially with sclero-corneal tunnel) Trabeculectomy Vitreo-retinal surgeries Squint surgery SINS is more likely to develop in those with rheumatoid arthritis, connective tissue disorders or following intra-operative use of mitomycin C. It is treated with NSAIDS and systemic steroids.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: As a first-year ophthalmology resident, you come across a child with the following presentation. Which of the following disorders is it associated with?
explanation: The child has blue sclera which is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta. Blue scleral discoloration is due to scleral thinning. The underlying uvea thus becomes prominent and visible. Osteogenesis imperfecta (types I and IIA) and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type VI) are the most commonly associated diseases. Both diseases are inherited disorders of collagen formation. Other options: Option A: Hemochromatosis occurs due to iron deposition in various tissues. Rusty-brown perilimbal conjunctiva and scleral discoloration are seen. Option C: Congenital ocular melanocytosis occurs due to an increase in the number, size and pigmentation of melanocytes. Sclera is multifocal slate-grey pigmented. Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis may present with extraarticular manifestations such as secondary Sjo■gren’s syndrome where keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be seen.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The sclera is thick in all the following conditions except-
explanation: The sclera is not thick in buphthalmos. The sclera is 1mm thick posteriorly, 0.66mm thick at the insertion of recti and 0.33mm thick beneath the recti. In buphthalmos, the sclera is stretched and thinned out, resulting in “blue sclera.” Buphthalmos refers to an enlarged eyeball due to congenital glaucoma.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
An intern comes across a 7-year-old girl with the following features. All the following are components of her condition except-

Disc coloboma
explanation: The given scenario of a young girl with facial asymmetry, deviation of angle of the mouth, flat nasal bridge, preauricular tags and limbal dermoid (lenticular yellow tumour at the limbus) of the eye is suggestive of Goldenhar syndrome. Lung hypoplasia is not a component of this syndrome. Goldenhar syndrome or oculoauriculovertebral spectrum is a congenital developmental anamoly affecting structures derived from the first branchial arch. It has the following features: Systemic: Hypoplasia of the malar, maxillary, and mandibular regions Macrostomia and microtia Preauricular and facial skin tags Hemivertebrae (usually cervical) Mental handicap Cardiac, renal, and central nervous system (CNS) anomalies. Ocular: Dermoid Upper lid notching or coloboma Microphthalmos Disc coloboma Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the corneal epithelium normally composed of?
explanation: The corneal epithelium is made up of stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium. Layers of the cornea: Epithelium (Stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium) Bowman’s membrane - Acellular; does not regenerate Stroma (Thickest layer) - The stroma can scar, but cannot regenerate Dua’s layer (Newly discovered, toughest layer) Descemet’s membrane- Ends peripherally as Schwalbe’s ring; has regenerative potential Endothelium (Most metabolically active layer)- does not regenerate Note: Limbal stem cells are located at the corneoscleral limbus, in the palisades of Vogt. Deficiency may result in chronic epithelial defects and "conjunctivalization" of the cornea
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the hydration and transparency of the cornea?
explanation: The hydration level and transparency of the cornea is maintained mainly by the endothelial cells of the cornea. The endothelium possesses Na+/K+ ATPase, which keeps the corneal stroma in a relatively dehydrated state. This helps maintain corneal transparency. Endothelial cells decrease in number with age. If the cornea becomes overhydrated, it begins to scatter light and gradually begins to lose its transparency Other factors contributing to the transparency of the cornea are as follows: Regular arrangement of corneal lamellae (Maurice theory) The peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory) Avascularity of the cornea A balance between the intraocular pressure (IOP) and swelling pressure The different layers of the cornea are as follows: Epithelium Bowman’s membrane Stroma (substantia propria) Dua’s layer (pre-Descemet’s layer) Descemet’s membrane Endothelium
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the average density of corneal endothelial cells?
explanation: The density of corneal endothelial cells in adults is about 2500–3000 cells/mm². Variation in corneal endothelial density with age: At birth- 3,500–4,000 cells/mm2 at birth Young adults- 2500–3000 cells/mm² Old age (about 80 years)- 2000 cells/mm² Corneas stored in eye banks are assessed for their quality and viability using a variety of parameters. Donor tissues are screened for stress lines, mechanical trauma, scarring, corneal edema, and infiltrates that could indicate poor tissue quality. They are further evaluated for thickness and endothelial cell density (a surrogate for endothelial function) which are important determinants of successful graft transplantation. Endothelial cell density (ECD) and morphology are assessed using a specular microscope or by a bright-field/phase-contrast light microscope. Note: The number of cells decreases at about 0.6% per year, and the neighboring cells enlarge to fill the space as the cells cannot regenerate. At a density of about 500 cells/mm2, corneal edema develops and transparency is impaired. This is known as critical endothelial density.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Below what horizontal diameter can a diagnosis of micro-cornea be made?
explanation: To make a diagnosis of microcornea, in this child, the diameter of the cornea should be less than 10 mm. Micro-cornea Horizontal corneal diameter is 10 mm or less (over 2 years of age) or less than 9 mm (in the newborn). There may be hypermetropia and a shallow anterior chamber but other dimensions are normal. Megalocornea Horizontal corneal diameter is 12 mm or more (up to 2 years of age) or 13 mm or more (if age >2 years) There is typically high myopia and astigmatism, but normal corrected visual acuity. Usually X-linked recessive; 90% of affected individuals are male. Cornea plana The cornea is flatter than normal, i.e., the radius of curvature is larger. There is a corresponding reduction in refractive power, resulting in high hypermetropia. Keratectasia It is characterized by a protuberance between the eyelids caused by a severely opacified, and sometimes vascularized, cornea. It is often associated with raised intraocular pressure as well as intrauterine keratitis. Usually unilateral Microphthalmos Microphthalmia is a condition in which the entire eye is small, with an axial length at least tw standard deviations below the mean for age. It may or may not be associated with ocular dysgenesis. Nanophthalmos In nanophthalmos (simple microphthalmos), the entire eye is small, but is structurally normal; It is usually associated with hypermetropia and strabismus Anophthalmos: Anophthalmos (anophthalmia) refers to the complete absence of any visible globe structure.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following organisms are capable of invading the intact cornea?
explanation: Gonococcus can invade an intact cornea. Organisms that can penetrate the intact epithelium of the cornea can be remembered with the mnemonic- CHaNNeLS Corynebacterium diphtheria Haemophilus influenza;Haemophilus aegypticus Neisseria gonorrhea; Neisseria meningitidis Listeria Shigella
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient with a history of uncomplicated cataract surgery 1 year back, presents with pain, redness, and purulent discharge from his right eye. A greyish-white serpiginous ulcer was noted over the lower third of the cornea. The anterior chamber showed a 4 mm hypopyon and a moderate flare reaction. A smear from the ulcerated area is likely to demonstrate which of the following organisms?
explanation: Hypopyon corneal ulcer with a characteristic serpiginous description (ulcus serpens) is typically caused by Pneumococcus. The bacterial hypopyon is sterile. Ulcus serpens is a greyish-white or yellowish disc-shaped ulcer occurring near the centre of the cornea. The ulcer has a tendency to creep over the cornea in a serpiginous fashion. Risk factors include both surgical and non-surgical ocular trauma, dry eye, chronic corneal disease, immune alterations and contact lenses. An examination may reveal the following signs: Swelling of lids and blepharospasm Conjunctival hyperemia Ciliary congestion, hypopyon and anterior chamber flare reaction Iridocyclitis Image given below shows ulcus serpens.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A young woman presents with sudden onset, rapidly progressing ocular pain, photophobia, and blurred vision in her right eye for 1 day. A deep, 4 mm diameter corneal ulcer, surrounded by stromal infiltrates was visualized. The anterior chamber has small amounts of mucopurulent discharge. She mentions using a cosmetic contact lens which she forgot to remove before sleeping 2 days ago. What is the most likely etiology?
explanation: The sudden onset and rapid progression of ocular symptoms and ulceration in this patient along with the history of improper contact lens usage are suggestive of a Pseudomonas infection. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common gram-negative organism isolated from corneal ulcers and is a frequent cause of contact lens–associated keratitis. Other risk factors include chlorinated swimming pools, hot tubs, ventilators, nebulizer, and vaporizer solutions, and ophthalmic solution bottles. Pseudomonas keratitis has a rapid and fulminant course if left untreated and are associated with a worse visual prognosis than that caused by most other common bacterial pathogens. Pseudomonas spp. can cause corneal perforation in just 48 hours. Treatment is mainly by topical NSAIDs and topical antipseudomonal antibiotic eye drops such as tobramycin 1.3% and fluoroquinolone eye drops.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A young woman comes with sudden onset ocular pain, tearing, and photophobia in the left eye. You suspect a bacterial corneal ulcer. What concentration of cephazolin drops would you prescribe for this patient?
explanation: The concentration of fortified cephazolin used to treat uncomplicated bacterial keratitis is 5% ( 50 mg/mL) Treatment of uncomplicated bacterial keratitis: Antibiotic eyedrops (broad-spectrum) If not responding, fortified antibiotic eye drops are used Fortified cephazolin (5%) Fortified tobramycin (1.3%) Fortified vancomycin (5%) Cycloplegic drugs- Preferably 1% atropine eye ointment or drops to prevent pain due to ciliary spasm. Also, it prevents the development of posterior synechiae. Oral vitamin A and vitamin C help in the healing of the epithelium Systemic analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs Management of non-healing ulcers: Debridement Chemical cauterization- 10–20% trichloroacetic acid, carbolic acid Conjunctival flapping Management of impending perforation: Decrease intraocular pressure (IOP) by antiglaucoma drugs Tissue adhesive glue such as cyanoacrylate Bandage contact lens No strain
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A non-sterile hypopyon is seen in .
explanation: Fungal keratitis can cause non-sterile hypopyon. Unlike bacterial ulcer, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungi can penetrate into the anterior chamber without perforation. Aspergillus spp. are the most common cause. Hypopyon in a fungal ulcer is fixed, non-sterile and contains fungal filaments.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. What would be the most likely pathology?
explanation: The given clinical vignette of the patient presenting with pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye following trauma by a vegetative matter is suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. Fungal corneal ulcer also known as mycotic keratitis is usually caused by trauma from vegetative matter such as branches of trees, leaves and animal tails. Injudicious use of topical steroids and antibiotics increases the predisposition to develop secondary fungal keratitis. Mycotic keratitis can be caused by Filamentous fungi such as Aspergillus and Fusarium Yeasts such as Candida and cryptococcus Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma and Blastomyces Typically in fungal corneal ulcers, the signs are more prominent than the symptoms. The symptoms of fungal keratitis are similar to that of bacterial ulcers which include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, blurred vision, and redness of the eyes. A typical fungal ulcer has the following signs: Greyish white looking dry corneal ulcer with rolled out margin. Feathery finger-like extensions into the corneal stroma under intact epithelium Wessley ring which is a sterile immune ring that occurs due to the deposition of immune complexes Multiple small satellite lesions around the ulcer Hypopyon: The hypopyon in fungal ulcer is immobile and unsterile unlike bacterial ulcer (sterile hypopyon) Perforation is rare Corneal vascularization is usually absent. A diagnosis of fungal ulcer is made by a typical history of trauma with vegetative matter followed by clinical examination and KOH mount or SDA agar cultures from corneal scrappings. The image below depicts a fungal corneal ulcer with the arrowhead indicating a satellite lesion. Other options: Option A: Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris up to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. Infectious uveitis can be caused by the exogenous entry of the organisms following penetrating injuries, perforation of corneal ulcer, and post-intaocular operations. Acute anterior uveitis presents with symptoms of pain, photophobia, lacrimation, blurring of vision and redness of the eye. Signs of anterior uveitis include: Aqueous flare - It is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis, it occurs following the leakage of protein particles into the aqueous humor. Keratic precipitates(KP) - These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. They are proteinaceous cellular deposits at the back of the cornea arranged in a triangular fashion. These include mutton fat KP's as seen in granulomatous uveitis and granular KP's of non granulomatous uveitis. Iris nodules: typically occur in granulomatous uveitis. Koppe's nodules are at the pupillary border and Busacca's nodules are situated near the collarette. Option C: Conjunctivitis is the inflammation of the conjunctiva of which the bacterial conjunctivitis is the most common. Acute bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by marked conjunctival hyperemia, swelling of the conjunctiva(chemosis), edematous eyelids, sticking together of lid margins and mucopurulent discharge from the eye. The image shows a patient with bacterial conjunctivitis. Option D: Corneal laceration: Partial corneal laceration or lamellar corneal laceration occurs from a blunt trauma and is treated by patching and antibiotics.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A farmer presents with blurring of vision in his left eye. He has a history of injury with a bush to the same eye while working. An ulcer is seen in his cornea with feathery margins. Slit-lamp examination shows infiltrates in the corneal stroma in a circular fashion. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction causes these infiltrates?
explanation: The given clinical situation points towards a fungal corneal ulcer and the infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion are suggestive of the immune ring of Wessely. This immune ring is due to type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex). The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as a result of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws the immune cells, inciting further inflammation. The given shows an ulcer in the cornea and the adjacent immune ring of Wessely.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal ulcer?
options: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescien dye
explanation: Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer. The signs of a fungal ulcer include: Irregular margins of the ulcer. Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer. An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immune complexes. Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation. Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Steroids are contraindicated in .
explanation: Steroids are contraindicated in fungal corneal ulcer Steroids make the fungi facultative pathogens when they are otherwise symbiotic saprophytes. Therefore, the use of these drugs predisposes the patients to fungal infections and perforation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 41-year-old female presented with a one-month history of photophobia and foreign body sensation in her right eye. A slit-lamp examination showed a corneal ulcer. The culture of the corneal scrapings grew a filamentous organism identified as a fusarium species. What would be the drug of choice in this case?
explanation: This patient with a one-month history of eye foreign body sensations and photophobia and slit lamp exam showing an ulcer that had fusarium growth most likely has a fungal corneal ulcer. Natamycin 5% suspension is the drug of choice for filamentous fungal keratitis caused by fusariam species. Surface debridement is also done as it helps to remove slough, reduce the load of infection and enhances drug penetration. Amphotericin B is particularly effective against yeasts but less effective against filamentous fungi. Also, its penetration through an intact epithelium is less than natamycin. Amphotericin B is the first agent of choice against yeasts. Amphotericin B (0.15%) drops can be considered alone or in combination with natamycin in refractory cases. Treatment of specific fungal corneal ulcers: Topical antifungal drops Aspergillus and Fusarium- Natamycin 5%, amphotericin B, fluconazole (0.2%) Candida- Amphotericin B (0.15%) or econazole (1%) Systemic antifungals such as itraconazole and voriconazole are used for severe non-responding cases or if the location of the ulcer is near the limbus or if there is a risk of perforation leading to endophthalmitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of the given condition?
explanation: The above image shows a dendritic ulcer caused by herpes simplex virus. Corneal guttata are not seen in HSV infection. They are droplet-like accumulations of non-banded collagen on the posterior surface of Descemet's membrane. It is a feature of corneal dystrophies.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about the given condition?
options: It is related to Hutchinson’s triad
There is usually a history of primary HSV infection as a child
High dose topical acyclovir is the treatment of choice
explanation: The image shows a unilateral painful, vesicular rash suggestive of herpes zoster ophthalmicus (HZO) caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) within the ophthalmic nerve. Neurotrophic keratitis is a complication of HZV infection. Keratitis occurs due to corneal nerve damage by the virus leading to decreased sensation, frequent infections, persistent epithelial defect, thinning and even perforation. Corneal lesions in HZO (zoster keratitis): Epithelium- superficial punctate keratitis and pseudo-dendritic ulcer Stroma- nummular keratitis and disciform keratitis Other ocular lesions in herpes zoster: Uveitis Episcleritis and scleritis Conjunctivitis Acute retinal necrosis Secondary glaucoma Anterior segment necrosis and pthisis bulbi Other options: Option A: Hutchinson’s rule is related to herpes zoster ophthalmicus. It states that if the tip of the nose is involved, there will be a significant risk of ocular involvement. This is due to the involvement of the nasociliary nerve. Hutchinson's triad is seen in congenital syphilis. Option B: There is primary HZV infection (chickenpox/varicella) not HSV infection. Option D: Systemic acyclovir is the treatment of choice; not topical antiviral drops. Oral acyclovir 800 mg five times a day for 7-10 days, ideally initiated within 72 h of the onset of symptoms is the usual regimen. The image shows Hutchinson's sign in a patient with herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 17-year-old boy presented with blurred vision, photophobia, and increasing pain in his right eye. He has been using contact lenses for the past 2 years. He mentions swimming with his cousins 2 weeks back in a local pond. A close-up image of the eye is given below. What is the most likely explanation?
explanation: The history of a patient with contact lens use with swimming in freshwater ponds with the image depicting a ring lesion (stromal infiltrate) makes acanthamoeba keratitis the likely diagnosis. Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare protozoal infection of the cornea. It is more common in soft contact lens users. The organism exists either as active, motile trophozoites or dormant, double-walled cysts. Suspicious sources of infection can be swimming or use of the hot tub while wearing contact lenses, homemade saline solution to wash contact lenses, exposure to standing groundwater etc. Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion. It presents as ring lesion (most common), pseudo-dendrites and as a reticular pattern. Diagnosis: Confocal microscopy - may reveal bright trophozoites with pseudopodia in the basal epithelium and double-walled cyst forms Histopathology - double-walled cysts are seen on H&E. Other stains for Acanthamoeba include calcofluor white, acridic orange, Giemsa-Wright, Wheatly trichrome or periodic acid-Schiff Culture - Acanthamoeba can be grown on a bed of E. coli plated on a non-nutrient agar
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 39-year-old contact lens user with a corneal ulcer, showing no improvement to tobramycin drops, was referred to a tertiary care centre. Corneal biopsy revealed double-walled cysts within the stroma. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
explanation: This patient with a corneal ulcer whose biopsy showed double walled cysts in the stroma most likely has acanthamoeba keratitis. Polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) is the treatment of choice for acanthamoeba keratitis. Combination therapy with chlorhexidine is most effective against trophozoites and cysts. This is recommended as the first line of therapy. Other topical anti-amoebic agents: Diamidines- Propamidine isethionate (0.1 %), Hexamidine Aminoglycosides- Neomycin, Paramomycin Imidazoles- Clotrimazole, Miconazole
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following does not cause interstitial keratitis?
explanation: Diphtheria is not a cause of interstitial keratitis. Interstitial keratitis is a non-ulcerating, inflammatory reaction of the corneal stroma that is characterized by non-suppurative infiltration and often stromal vascularization. The epithelium and endothelium are not affected. Scarring due to stromal inflammation and vascularization, in interstitial keratitis, can result in decreased vision. Interstitial keratitis (IK) is a common endpoint of any keratitis that predominantly involves the corneal stroma. So there is a wide range of potential etiologies. Treatment for IK typically involves the use of topical corticosteroids, as well as appropriate systemic medications for the associated systemic disease.
