subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following infections is classically associated with salmon patch appearance of the cornea?
explanation: Salmon patch appearance of the cornea is classically associated with syphilitic infection. This is because, syphilis causes deep vascularization of the cornea, leading to a radial bundle of brush-like vessels. Stages of interstitial keratitis in congenital syphilis: Progressive stage - ground-glass appearance Florid stage - salmon patch appearance Stage of regression - ghost vessels
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient with recurrent corneal epithelial erosions is diagnosed with limbal stem cell deficiency. She has been enrolled on a research trial for corneal epithelial stem cell transplant. All are markers that can be used to identify stem cells from an ex-vivo culture except?
explanation: Connexin 50 is not a limbal stem-cell marker. The major markers proposed for epithelial stem cells can be categorized into at least three groups: Nuclear proteins such as transcription factor p63 Cell membrane or transmembrane proteins Integrins (integrin ß1, 6, and 9), Receptors (epidermal growth factor [EGF] receptor and transferrin receptor CD71) Drug-resistance transporters (ABCG2—a universal stem cell marker) Cytoplasmic proteins such as Cytokeratins (cytokeratin 14 - exclusively at LSC) Alpha-enolase
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: For her final year thesis, an ophthalmology resident is studying endothelial cell loss due to phacoemulsification surgery. The image is taken during the pre-op evaluation of one of the cataract patients. What does this show?
explanation: The given image is a specular microscopy view of endothelial cells of different shapes (pleomorphism) and large surface area (polymegathism). These are indicators of endothelial dysfunction. A normal endothelium has a regular hexagonal shape. Because these cells are terminally differentiated cells, they do not divide, and when they die, the remaining cells have to stretch to cover more area, resulting in polymegathism and pleomorphism. Taking an endothelial cell count can be helpful before taking patients up for cataract or refractive surgery so that any potential endothelial dysfunction or thinning is recognized before they have the surgical intervention.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of herpetic keratitis?
explanation: Corneal guttata are seen in corneal dystrophy. Peripheral guttata are seen in old age—Hassall–Henle bodies. Central guttata, on the other hand, are found in Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A corneal foreign body was removed from a 53-year-old man. He was sent home with chloramphenicol and steroid eye drops. Two days later he came back with a corneal ulcer and a hypopyon. The ulcer scraping under microscopy revealed branched septate hyphae. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given history of trauma and worsening with antibiotic-steroid drops suggests a fungal corneal ulcer. Out of the given options, Aspergillus is the fungus with branched septate hyphae. Clinically, fungi are classified on a morphological basis into filamentous, yeast, and dimorphic forms: Filamentous organisms are multicellular with branched hyphae. It can be septate or aseptate. Septate filamentous organisms, such as Fusarium and Aspergillus, have hyphae that are divided by cell walls. Non-septate filamentous fungi, include Mucor and Rhizopus. Yeasts, such as Candida and Cryptococcus, are unicellular fungi that reproduce by budding, but in tissue, they might develop elongated buds (pseudohyphae). Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma, Coccidioides, and Blastomyces demonstrate both a yeast phase that occurs in tissues and a mycelial phase that appears on culture media and saprophytic surfaces. Image: Branched septate hyphae of Aspergillus spp.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
Corneal sensation is lost in .
Conjunctivitis
explanation: Corneal sensation is lost in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. The pathognomic feature of viral keratitis is decreased corneal sensation. Decreased corneal sensation is also seen in diabetes mellitus and leprosy. Non-infectious Disorders of Cornea
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Deposition of which of the following is responsible for band-shaped keratopathy?
explanation: Band-shaped keratopathy is caused by pathological calcium deposition on the cornea in the form of a band. On exam, there is a white band-like formation of calcium across the corneal surface with irregular borders and a peripheral clearing of cornea between the calcium deposits and the limbus. The calcium deposition is typically found beneath the epithelial layer within Bowman’s layer but may extend into the anterior stroma. Once the visual axis starts to get involved, there will be progressive loss of vision. Recurrence is common unless the predisposing cause is identified and treated. Local causes such as chronic ocular irritation or inflammatory conditions and systemic diseases that elevate serum calcium levels are the main causes for band-shaped keratopathy. It can rarely have hereditary causes as well. Image given below shows band-shaped keratopathy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient was with the given finding has been having painless and slowly progressive vision loss for the past 10 years. Which of the following diseases is not associated with the given condition?
explanation: Based on the given clinical scenario and ocular finding depicted here, it is suggestive of band-shaped keratopathy, and systemic lupus erythematosus is not associated with this condition. Band-shaped keratopathy (BSK) is due to calcium deposition, primarily in the form of hydroxyapatite, in the epithelial basement membrane, Bowman's layer, and the anterior stroma. Initially, these deposits are grey but may become chalky-white as the degeneration progresses. < typically presents as a band-shaped opacity in the interpalpebral zone with a clear interval between the ends of the band and the limbus. The condition begins at the periphery and gradually progresses towards the centre. The surface of this opaque band is stippled due to holes in the calcium plaques in the area of nerve canals of Bowman's membrane. Causes of band-shaped keratopathy include local causes such as chronic ocular irritation or inflammatory conditions and systemic diseases that elevate serum calcium levels: Treatment: Medical management- Chelation using topical ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) 1.5–3.0% Surgical management- Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) using excimer laser or manual superficial keratectomy Local causes Systemic diseases Chronic anterior uveitis (espe cially inJuvenile Idiopathic A rthritis)Interstitial keratitisS uperficial keratitisPhthisis bu lbiEnd-stage glaucomaSilicon e oil left in the aphakic eye HyperparathyroidismSarcoid osisMultiple myelomaHypop hosphatemiaPaget diseaseCh ronic renal failure
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 64-year-old woman was brought by her son, during a cataract outreach camp. She gives a history of trauma to her left eye, one year back and a complete loss of vision in that eye since then. Her image is given below. Which of the following statement is true about her condition?
options: Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in this lady.
The given lesion is an adherent leucoma.
It is due to scars involving Bowman's layer and superficial stroma.
Excimer laser phototherapeutic keratectomy is the current treatment of choice.
explanation: The above image shows a dense white opacity, which results from the scarring of more than half of the stroma, characteristic of leucoma. Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in patients with corneal opacities, who have lost their vision or who do not expect to recover it. It improves cosmetic appearance by altering the white colour of the opacity and blending it to normal eye colour. Depending on the density, corneal opacities are graded as nebula, macula and leucoma. Nebular corneal opacity (fog or mist): Hard-to-see corneal scar, due to superficial scars involving Bowman's layer and superficial stroma. Slit-lamp detection is required. A thin, diffuse nebula covering the pupillary area interferes more with vision than the localised leucoma away from the pupillary area. Nebula produces more discomfort due to blurred image (irregular astigmatism). Macular corneal opacity: Semi-dense opacity that can be seen with proper illumination. Due to scarring involving about half the corneal stroma. Leucomatous corneal opacity (leucoma simplex): White scar that is easily seen just by looking at the eye. Due to scarring of more than half of the stroma Adherent leucoma: It results when healing occurs after perforation of the cornea with incarceration of iris Secondary changes in corneal opacity which may be seen in long-standing cases include hyaline degeneration, calcareous degeneration, pigmentation and atheromatous ulceration. Treatment: Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice in leucomatous corneal opacities. Optical iridectomy may be performed in cases with central adherent leucomas Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) performed with excimer laser is useful only in superficial (nebular) corneal opacities.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with bilateral corneal opacities in a neonate?
explanation: Keratoglobus is least likely to be associated with bilateral corneal opacities in a neonate. Here, the cornea is clear. Keratoglobus is a rare noninflammatory, familial disorder marked by generalised thinning and globular protrusion of the cornea. It can be congenital or acquired. The thinning is usually greatest at corneal periphery or midperiphery. It can cause refractive errors, otherwise, cornea is clear, normal angle of anterior chamber, normal intraocular pressure with no optic disc cupping. Intrastromal ring segments and cross-linking can be used for management. Other options: Option B: Birth injuries resulting in Descemet's membrane tears can also cause corneal opacities. Option C: Peter's anomaly, also known as iridocorneal adhesions or keratolenticular adhesions, is a posterior corneal defect with an overlying stromal opacity. Option D: Sclerocornea is a congenital disorder in which the cornea is opaque and resembles the sclera, making the limbus indistinct. The central cornea is clearer than the periphery.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What causes neurotrophic keratopathy?
explanation: Neurotrophic keratopathy is caused by trigeminal nerve palsy. Lesions of the fifth cranial nerve from the trigeminal nucleus to the cornea may lead to abnormalities of the normal corneal sensation and trophic stimulation. Causes: Varicella-zoster (most common cause) Herpes simplex keratitis Trauma Irradiation to the eye Aneurysm/stroke Multiple sclerosis Mackie characterized three stages of neurotrophic keratitis. Stage I is characterized by an irregular corneal surface, which later develops into an easily recognized punctate keratitis. Stage II is characterized by a frank epithelial defect, which is typically associated with mild anterior stromal oedema and inflammation. Stage III involves stromal melting and occasionally perforation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Paralysis of which of the following nerves is responsible for exposure keratopathy?
explanation: Exposure keratopathy is caused by paralysis of the facial nerve. It is the result of incomplete lid closure (lagophthalmos) resulting in drying of the cornea (despite normal tear production). Causes: Neuroparalytic, e.g., facial nerve palsy Reduced muscle tone as in parkinsonism Mechanical such as lid scarring Proptosis Note: Neurotrophic keratopathy is due to loss of trigeminal nerve innervation resulting in partial or complete loss of sensation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause the given condition?
explanation: Erythromycin is least likely associated with cornea verticillata/vortex keratopathy, a whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium, as shown in the image above. Vortex keratopathy occurs due to corneal deposits in the basal epithelium. They are almost always bilateral and are readily recognisable by their distinct appearance as fine, golden-brown or grey opacities that branch out from a central whorl, usually across the inferior cornea. Opacity due to drugs is reversible upon stopping the drug. Causes: Amiodarone (most common) (Option A) Tamoxifen (Option C) Indomethacin Chloroquine (Option D) Chlorpromazine (rarely) Fabry’s disease
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 30-year-old albino woman presents with a characteristic finding as shown below. Which of the following statements are true regarding the suspected condition?
explanation: A 30-year-old individual with corneal changes, as shown above, known as gerontoxon or arcus lipoides, may require screening for underlying lipid disorder. Arcus senilis (AS), also known as gerontoxon, arcus lipoides or arcus cornealis, is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity, typically benign, occurring bilaterally and prevalent among the elderly. However, when observed in individuals under 50, termed arcus juvenilis, it may indicate underlying lipid disorder and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, warranting lipid profile screening. Unilateral cases of arcus senilis may indicate contralateral carotid artery stenosis due to decreased ophthalmic blood flow on the ipsilateral side, resulting in protection from forming arcus in the ipsilateral eye. The condition results from the leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma, initiating deposition at the superior and inferior cornea. Over time, the ring progresses circumferentially, sparing a clear corneal zone adjacent to the limbus called the interval of Vogt. The following opacities and rings can resemble arcus senilis: Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring: A dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper in Descemet's membrane, classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic, cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis. Limbus sign: Caused by dystrophic calcification, seen as a "milky precipitate" at the corneal limbus. It can sometimes be confused with AS in the elderly population. Pseudo-gerontoxon: A greyish peri-limbal band of superficial scarring adjacent to a previously inflamed segment of the limbus resembling AS, seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. The image below depicts the Kayser–Fleischer ring and anterior capsule of the crystalline lens (Sunflower cataract) seen in Wilson's disease.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A young male labourer presents to the casualty with severe bilateral eye pain that woke him from sleep. He reports welding the previous afternoon without a face shield and symptoms of photophobia, blurry vision, tearing, and worsening pain in bright light. Examination reveals mild conjunctival injection and diffuse punctate epithelial erosions on the cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The described corneal findings, with his classic history of welding less than 12 hours prior to presentation, are suggestive of photophthalmia. Photophthalmia is produced due to exposure to short-wavelength ultraviolet (UV-B) rays. The cornea absorbs the majority of UV light (especially 311 to 290 nm). It results in desquamation of the epithelium leading to multiple painful corneal erosions. Causes of of UV keratitis: The symptoms appear characteristically after a latent period of 4- 5 hours of exposure to ultraviolet light. There is intense burning pain, foreign body sensation, and watering of the eyes. There may be associated marked photophobia and blepharospasm. On slit-lamp examination, corneal epithelium shows a breach in continuity and takes up fluorescein stain. Management comprises cold compresses, lubricant eye drops and bandaging eyes for 24 hours with antibiotic eye ointment and cycloplegic. Avoid local surface topical anaesthesia. Crooke’s glass is a prophylactic aid consisting of a spectacle lens combined with metallic oxides to absorb ultraviolet or infrared rays and should be used by those who are prone to exposure. Note: Photoretinitis and macular burns are often a result of infrared radiation. Artificial causes Natural causes Arc weldingFlash from short- circuits,Damaged metal halid e lampsTanning bedsUV ger micidal lamps. Exposure to strong solar radi ation at high altitudes especi ally on snow-covered terrain (snow blindness)Prolonged vi ewing of a solar eclipse witho ut proper eye protection.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is a method for long-term preservation of cornea?
explanation: Cryopreservation is used for long-term preservation of cornea, up to 1 year.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection following corneal transplantation in India?
explanation: Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of infectious keratitis after corneal transplantation in developing countries. Pneumococcus spp. and Staphylococcus aureus have been found to be the most common causes of post-corneal transplant infections in developed countries.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following techniques is the gold standard for assessing corneal thickness?
explanation: The gold standard technique for assessing corneal thickness is ultrasound pachymetry, which uses a corneal pachymeter. Measurement of the corneal thickness (pachymetry) indirectly reflects endothelial function. The average central corneal thickness is around 0.5 mm, which gradually increases toward the periphery to around 0.7 mm. Normally, as a diurnal variation, corneas tend to be slightly thicker just after a person awakes in the morning. Other options: Option A: Confocal microscopy is an imaging technique that allows in vivo examination of corneal structures at high magnification and resolution. It is used to assess corneal nerve morphology and corneal endothelium. Option B: Keratometry measures the anterior corneal curvature and is traditionally performed with a manual keratometer, also known as an ophthalmometer. Option D: Corneal topography is used to assess the anterior corneal surface, its shape and thickness. The image below shows a corneal pachymeter.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Your aunt recently shared that it is becoming cumbersome for her to frequently change her glasses. You suggested a referral and the rapid change in power was diagnosed to be due to keratoconus. The following image shows the results of one of the investigations done on her. What is the name of the investigation?
explanation: The investigation shown in the image is corneal topography, and it is used for conditions like keratoconus, as seen in this clinical scenario. Corneal topography captures the shape of the cornea by projecting concentric rings of light onto its anterior surface, forming a Placido disc pattern. the reflected light is analyzed with specialised software to create a detailed map of the corneal curvature. Uses: Detection of corneal ectasia, mainly keratoconus To measure corneal thickness Prior to refractive surgery Sometimes prior to contact lens fitting The image shows a Placido or Keratoscopic disc which is used for corneal surface assessment.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 20-year-old girl with high myopia was referred by the optometrist for further evaluation. She has a history of recurrent allergic conjunctivitis and persistent eye rubbing. An image is given below. Which of the following statements are true about the given condition?
explanation: Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision. The pathogenesis is not fully known. Several associations have been identified, which include rigid contact lens wear, chronic eye rubbing, Down's syndrome, atopic disease, Leber's congenital amaurosis, and connective tissue disease. It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often causes significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool for KCN detection. Whereas keratoplasty, historically has been the mainstay of treatment for keratoconus, it is now generally reserved for eyes that are unable to achieve functional vision with other surgical or non-surgical modalities and is only considered only as a last resort, in very advanced disease. It is the definitive treatment for keratoconus, not the treatment of choice.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is not a treatment option in advanced keratoconus?
explanation: Vision correction with spectacles with spherical/toric soft contact lenses is suboptimal and only applicable to the early stages of keratoconus, not in the advanced stages. Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory, bilateral corneal ectasia characterized by cone-like steepening due to irregular stromal thinning. This leads to a conical corneal protrusion, significant vision loss, myopia and irregular astigmatism. The available options for the management of keratoconus are highly dependent on the stage of the disease and its progression. If the disease is stabilized (no progression), the emphasis is given to correcting the vision. If the disease is progressing, the emphasis is on slowing (arresting) the progression. Treatment options in moderate-to-advanced keratoconus: Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses and vaulting scleral lenses are the mainstays of vision treatment for moderate to advanced KCN. Their main advantage is the creation of a tear pool between the lens and the cornea, which naturally neutralizes the ocular aberrations associated with keratoconus. (Option B and C) Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that are implanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature to improve vision. Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetrating keratoplasty (PKP) Corneal collagen cross-linking with riboflavin (CXL or C3R) and ultraviolet-A rays arrest the progression of the disease. (Option D)
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 40-year old male with progressive loss of vision in his left eye was diagnosed with against-the-rule astigmatism. Examination revealed peripheral corneal thinning, but there was no inflammation. Which of the following is least likely to be the cause?
explanation: The examination in a 40-year-old male revealed peripheral corneal thinning with no inflammation, making peripheral ulcerative keratitis, an inflammatory condition, the least likely cause. Peripheral ulcerative keratitis is a destructive inflammatory disease involving the peripheral cornea. It is associated with signs and symptoms of inflammation. The other options are causes of peripheral thinning in a quiet eye. Other options: Options A and B: Terrien's and Pellucid marginal degeneration are noninflammatory corneal degenerations. Pellucid degeneration causes bilateral, inferior corneal thinning that leads to marked, irregular, against-the-rule astigmatism. Terrien's degeneration usually begins in the superior cornea. Option C: Dellen is a localized thinning of the peripheral cornea associated with the drying of a focal area. Usually associated with an adjacent elevated lesion (e.g., pinguecula or a large subconjunctival haemorrhage) that impairs physiological lubrication.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 47-year-old woman presented with tearing, irritation, and photophobia of the left eye. On examination, a paracentral, crescent-shaped corneal melt was noted. Peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK) was suspected. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis is commonly associated with peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK). It is also the most common cause. PUK is a group of destructive inflammatory diseases involving the peripheral cornea, characterized by the sloughing of corneal epithelium and keratolysis (corneal melting). It can lead to corneal perforation. The causes can be divided into: Infectious- bacterial, viral, protozoal, fungal. Non-infectious- rheumatoid arthritis, Wegener's granulomatosis, SLE, rosacea, psoriasis etc. Ophthalmologic manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis (due to type III and IV hypersensitivity reactions): dry eye scleritis stromal keratitis peripheral ulcerative keratitis paracentral keratolysis Treatment of PUK includes protection of the surface from drying and exposure; systemic corticosteroids and immunomodulatory; use of adjuncts such as amniotic membrane grafts to promote healing; and in some situations, tectonic keratoplasty.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 54-year-old school teacher presented with a chief complaint of pain in the eyes and intermittent blurry vision which was worse in the mornings. Generalized corneal haze was noted in both eyes but was more significant in the left. Examination findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with beaten metal appearance on slit lamp and reduced endothelial cell density with coalescing guttata on specular microscopy is suggestive of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy. Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral, slowly progressive, often asymmetric corneal disease. It is characterized by deterioration of endothelial cells and development of guttata, which are excrescences of Descemet’s membrane (seen on specular or confocal microscopy). Females are affected more than males. It is more common in the 4th decade or later. Endothelial layer dysfunction causes loss of corneal deturgescence, and bilateral oedema of the stroma, leading to ocular pain, glare, halos, and decreased visual acuity. Patients have a worse vision in the morning because of the eyes being closed during the night causing a buildup of corneal oedema. Stages of Fuch’s endothelial dystrophy: Stage 1: Central corneal guttata that spreads peripherally Stage 2: Corneal oedema - beaten metal-like appearance Stage 3: Bullous keratopathy Stage 4: Subepithelial scarring and superficial vascularization Treatment: Conservative option- topical hypertonic (saline sodium chloride 5% drops or 6% ointment) and bandage contact lenses. The definitive treatment is endothelial keratoplasty: Descemet’s stripping endothelial keratoplasty (DSEK/DSAEK) or Descemet membrane Endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is not true about macular corneal dystrophy?
explanation: Macular dystrophy does not spare the peripheral cornea. It is the least common corneal dystrophy. It has an autosomal recessive inheritance. Most other corneal dystrophies are autosomal dominant. It is associated with mucopolysaccharidoses and is characterized by the deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the stroma and staining by Alcian blue. It develops in childhood and is progressive, resulting in profound visual impairment in early adult life. Clinical examination reveals superficial whitish fleck-like opacities. These opacities extend peripherally to the limbus and the deep stroma down to Descemet’s membrane. The intervening corneal stroma develops a progressive and diffuse haze. Note: Most common dystrophy overall- Microcystic/fingerprint/map-dot dystrophy Most common stromal dystrophy- Lattice dystrophy Dystrophy with corectopia- Posterior polymorphous dystrophy Autosomal recessive dystrophy- Macular dystrophy
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following stains is used in identifying granular dystrophy of the cornea?
explanation: Masson trichrome stains stromal hyaline deposits in granular dystrophy of the cornea. Granular corneal dystrophy belongs to the stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene. Granular corneal dystrophy is characterized by milky, granular, hyaline deposits in the anterior stroma, which may coalesce into irregular shapes. The peripheral cornea and the area between the opacities/deposits remain clear. Early symptoms may involve light sensitivity, glare, ocular discomfort, pain, and watering. As opacification progresses with age, visual acuity decreases. The following image shows numerous irregularly shaped discrete crumb-like corneal opacities of Granular dystrophy, which stain bright red with Masson trichrome.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of oil-droplet keratopathy?
options: Deposition of lipid in the anterior stroma
explanation: Oil-droplet keratopathy occurs due to exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays. Climatic droplet keratopathy (CDK), alternatively known as oil droplet keratopathy/spheroidal degeneration/Labrador keratopathy, is an acquired corneal degenerative disorder. Clumps of variably sized golden-yellow globules accumulate in the superficial corneal stroma and are thought to be derived from photochemical degradation of plasma proteins, by UV radiation. The image shows Labrador keratopathy. Other options: Option A: Lipid keratopathy involves the accumulation of whitish or yellow fat deposits, mainly cholesterol and fatty acids, which begin intracellularly and later move extracellularly due to necrosis of corneal stromal cells. It can be primary (rare, in the cornea free of vascularization) or secondary (common, in the vascularized cornea). Option C: Exposure keratopathy results from lagophthalmos (incomplete eyelid closure), causing corneal dryness despite normal tear production. Causes include neuroparalytic conditions (like facial nerve palsy), reduced muscle tone in Parkinsonism, lid scarring, post-blepharoplasty and proptosis. Option D: Neurotrophic keratopathy results from loss of trigeminal nerve innervation to the cornea, affecting both sensation and healing. This disruption can cause corneal dryness, ulceration, exfoliation, and edema. It is commonly linked to conditions such as trigeminal ganglion surgical ablation for neuralgia, stroke, diabetes, herpes simplex and herpes zoster keratitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation is false?
options: It is used in the management of keratoconus.
Corneal perforation is a very common complication.
It is made of polymethyl methacrylate.
explanation: Corneal perforation may occur but is quite rare in intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation. Salient points on ICRS: These segments are made of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) and are implanted into the mid-peripheral corneal stroma. These are used in the management of keratoconus and low myopia. Improvement in visual acuity and refraction after ICRS implantation is accomplished by a shortening of collagen lamellae along the arc length of the ring. There is a redistribution o corneal stress due to a change in the curvature of the cornea after implantation of the ICRS. Decreased corneal sensation can be a postoperative complication. More than 90% of patients have <1 D change in refraction at 1-year postoperative follow-up. The image shows the intrastromal corneal ring segment.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 29-year-old woman with normal visual acuity undergoes a routine eye exam. Slit-lamp examination reveals numerous crumb-like centrally dense deposits in the anterior corneal stroma, bilaterally symmetrical, with clear intervening stroma. Which of the following statements is likely to be true?
options: Histopathology specimen will stain positive with alcian blue
Histopathologic review will reveal amyloid deposits on congo red staining
Histopathologic review will reveal hyaline deposits on the Masson trichrome stain
explanation: The given clinical scenario, with the given image showing multiple breadcrumb-like deposits, is suggestive of granular corneal dystrophy, where histopathology reveals hyaline deposits on the Masson trichrome stain. Granular corneal dystrophy belongs to the stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene. In granular corneal dystrophy, opacities form due to the abnormal accumulation of hyaline protein, assuming a discrete granular form and subsequently coalescing into various irregular shapes. The cornea between the opacities and the peripheral cornea remains clear. The condition is characterised by milky granular hyaline deposits in the anterior stroma. In many patients, no symptoms occur, whereas some patients develop recurrent erosions. In the fifth decade or later, some patients develop sufficient visual difficulties to require keratoplasty. Treatment is usually keratoplasty for severe visual handicaps. Note: The beaten metal appearance on the slit lamp and reduced endothelial cell density with coalescing guttata on specular microscopy is suggestive of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A 6-month-old infant is brought with a history of diffuse, ground glass-like corneal haze in both eyes. The corneas are thickened with normal diameters and associated nystagmus.
Which one of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
options: Intraocular pressure (IOP) is likely to be elevated.
The corneal stroma shows abnormal deposits that stain with amyloid.
It could be a bilateral choristoma.
Descemet’s membrane may be thickened due to an abnormal endothelium.
explanation: The given clinical scenario most likely suggest congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy (CHED), where Descemet’s membrane is abnormally thickened. CHED is a rare disorder characterized by focal or diffuse thickening of the Descemet membrane and endothelial degeneration. The key features of this condition include corneal thickness, which is two to three times the normal, normal intraocular pressure (IOP) and normal corneal diameter. Associated features are corneal pannus, nystagmus, and esotropia. Treatment usually involves corneal transplantation (lamellar or penetrating keratoplasty) for visual rehabilitation. Other options: Option A: As the corneal diameters are normal, and there are no typical symptoms, congenital glaucoma is ruled out. Option B: Amyloid deposits in the corneal stroma are seen in Lattice stromal dystrophy. Option C: Choristomas are congenital lesions representing normal tissue(s) in an abnormal location. They are the most common epibulbar and orbital tumors in children. It usually arises at the limbus of the eye and may include dermoid tissue, lipodermoid or other tissues. Note: The combination of congenital endothelial dystrophy and progressive neural deafness, is known as Harboyan syndrome. This disorder must be distinguished from another autosomal recessive disorder, congenital endothelial dystrophy, in which deafness does not occur.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about Mooren's ulcer?
options: Painless superficial ulcer that can perforate
Associated with autoimmune and rheumatological conditions
Characterized by a steep, overhanging edge
Ulcerative process begins centrally and then moves circumferentially
explanation: Moorens’s ulcer/ulcus roden is characterized by a steep, overhanging edge. It is described as a chronic serpiginous ulcer of the cornea. It is a subtype of peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK). It is defined as an idiopathic condition without associated systemic or rheumatological conditions and hence is a diagnosis of exclusion. The pathophysiology is thought to be due to autoimmune. Clinical features include redness, tearing, and photophobia, but pain is typically the outstanding feature. The pain often is incapacitating and may well be out of proportion to the inflammation. There may also be a complaint of decreased visual acuity, which may be secondary to associated iritis or central corneal involvement. Initially, the ulcerative process spreads circumferentially. Later, it moves centrally to involve the entire cornea. In contrast to other forms of PUK, the limbus is involved. The end-stage result is typically a scarred, vascularized cornea that may be thinned to less than half of its original thickness. Treatment involves corticosteroids and excision of a strip of adjacent conjunctiva, which eliminates the conjunctival sources of collagenase and proteoglycanase. The image shows a perforated Mooren's ulcer.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
Which layer of the cornea is affected in Reis–Buckler dystrophy?
Epithelium
explanation: The corneal layer involved in Reis–Buckler dystrophy is Bowman’s membrane. Corneal dystrophies are primarily a bilateral, inherited, non-inflammatory condition specific to the cornea. Reis–Buckler dystrophy, an autosomal dominant disorder, is an anterior variant of granular stromal dystrophy, characterised by the replacement of the Bowman layer with connective tissue bands, primarily affecting the Bowman layer and superficial stroma. Several recurrent corneal erosions may occur in childhood along with visual impairment. In this condition, there are grey-white, geographic subepithelial opacities (that are most dense centrally and increase over time, eventually forming a reticular pattern. Additionally, corneal sensation is reduced as the disease progresses. The image below shows Reis–buckler corneal dystrophy on slit-lamp examination: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Identify the marked layer of the retina.
explanation: The inner plexiform layer is the marked layer in the given histological image of retina, identified as the fourth layer from the uppermost (innermost) layer. The retina consists of 10 layers. The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is the outermost layer - below the Bruch's membrane of the choroid - and the internal limiting membrane is the innermost layer - separating the retina from the vitreous. The retinal pigment epithelium consists of a single layer of cells containing pigment. It is separated from the neurosensory retinal layers by the potential space between them which is known as interphotoreceptor matrix. The inner plexiform layer consists of synapsing nerve fibers. The axons of bipolar cells synapse with dendrites of ganglion cells; and both these processes synapse with processes of amacrine cells. It also contains some horizontally placed internal plexiform cells; and also a few ganglion cells.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Identify the structure marked with red arrow
explanation: The marked structure in the slide is the outer plexiform layer of the retina. The outer plexiform layer (outer synaptic layer) is present between the outer nuclear layer and the inner nuclear layer. This layer stains lightly. This layer consists of the axons of rods and cones which synapse with dendrites of bipolar neurons and horizontal cells.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The distance of the fovea from the temporal margin of the optic disc is .
explanation: The distance of the fovea from the temporal margin of the optic disc is 2 disc diameters. The fovea is an excavation in the retinal surface at the center of the macula, with a diameter of 1.5 mm, which is about the same as that of the optic disc. The foveola forms the bottom of the fovea and has a diameter of 0.35 mm. It is devoid of ganglion cells. The umbo is the central floor the foveola, which corresponds to the foveolar light reflex. The foveal avascular zone (FAZ) is a central area (including foveola and surrounding areas) which contains no blood vessels but is surrounded by a continuous network of capillaries. The macula is a round area at the posterior pole, lying inside the temporal vascular arcades. It measures 5.5 mm in diameter. The inner layers of the macula contain the yellow xanthophyll carotenoid pigments lutein and zeaxanthin in far higher concentrations than the peripheral retina (hence, the full name "macula lutea", which means yellow plaque).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Causes for expanding blind spot are all except
explanation: Optic disc hypoplasia does not cause enlargement of the blind spot. The physiological blind spot is an area of absolute scotoma in the visual field, seen in the region of optic disc. It is due to the absence of photoreceptors (rods and cones) in that region. Enlarged blind spot is seen in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) (Option A), papilledema (Option C), medullated nerve fibers (Option D), optic disc drusen, coloboma of optic disc and myopic disc with a crescent. Optic nerve hypoplasia is the most common congenital optic disc anomaly. There is underdevelopment of the optic disc in the disease and it typically presents with a small disc that is surrounded by a yellowish pigmented ring, called the 'double ring sign'. Option A: In primary open-angle glaucoma(POAG), the optic disc enlargement is seen secondary to increased intra-ocular pressure (IOP) in the eye. Option C: Papilledema is a passive disc swelling seen with raised intracranial pressure. The blind spot is enlarged due to the edema of the optic disc. Option D: Medullated or opaque nerve fibers are the abnormal myelination of nerve fibers of the retina. Normally, optic nerve myelination stops at the level of lamina cribrosa. If the myelination continues beyond the optic disc it leads to the expansion of the blind spot. On ophthalmoscopic examination, these are seen as a whitish patch with feathery margins.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which statement regarding Müller cells is false?
options: Their nuclei lie in the outer nuclear layer
Their foot processes form the inner & outer limiting membranes
They contribute to inner blood retinal barrier
explanation: The nuclei of Müller cells lie in the inner nuclear layer. Müller cells are a type of macroglial cells of the retina. The human retina contains 8–10 million Müller cells. Their nuclei lie in the inner nuclear layer and their processes extend across the retinal layers to form the inner and outer limiting membranes. Their functions include: Providing structural stability to the retina Interacting with other neurons and their functional and metabolic support Providing neurons with trophic substances and removing metabolic waste Playing a critical role in regulating the extracellular space volume as well as ion and water omeostasis and in maintaining the inner blood-retinal barrier Astrocytes are another type of macroglial cells of the retina. They play a crucial role in retinal vascularization. In the mature retina, they are restricted to the nerve fiber and ganglion cell layers.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the development of retinal vasculature?
options: Grow to temporal ora by 34 weeks of gestation
Grow to nasal ora by 36 weeks of gestation
Originate from mesenchymal tissue during week 16 of gestation
explanation: Retinal vessels reach temporal ora at approximately 40 weeks of gestation. Retinal vessels develop de novo from mesenchymal tissue, beginning during the 4th month of gestation. They radiate outward (centrifugally) from the optic nerve, reaching the nasal ora by 36 weeks.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A preterm baby treated for respiratory distress syndrome is found to have white pupillary reflex on opthalmologic examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: A preterm baby, treated for respiratory distress syndrome, with leucocoria (white pupillary reflex) most likely has retrolental fibroplasia. Retrolental fibroplasia, also known as retinopathy of prematurity, is a proliferative retinopathy. Risk factors include prematurity, very low birth weight and supplemental oxygen therapy (given for respiratory distress syndrome). ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may lead to blindness in serious cases.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is included under threshold disease when screening neonates for retinopathy of prematurity?
options: ROP stage 1 extending from 6'o clock to 11'0 clock in zone 1 with plus disease
ROP stage 3 extending from 2'o clock to 7'o clock in zone 2 with plus disease
ROP stage 3 extending from 1'o clock to 4'o clock in zone 1 without plus disease
ROP stage 2 extending from 3'o clock to 6'o clock in zone 2 with plus disease
explanation: ROP stage 3 extending from 2'0 clock to 7'o clock (6 clock hours) in zone 2 with plus disease fits into the definition of threshold disease. Threshold disease of retinopathy of prematurity is defined by the CRYO-ROP study as: Stage 3 disease: Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous Involvement of zones 1 or 2 Involvement of either at least 5 contiguous (continuous) clock hours or 8 non-contiguous clock ours Associated with "plus disease": Dilatation and tortuosity of posterior pole vessels in at least two quadrants at the posterior pole. Treatment of threshold disease is laser photocoagulation of the involved part within 72 hours of diagnosis. Treatment of the various stages of ROP includes: Pre-threshold type 1 disease - Treatment is now recommended within 48 hours and is done by laser photocoagulation of avascular retina. Pre-threshold type 2 disease (Any ROP not following under type 1)- Observation for progression Threshold disease - Laser photocoagulation of avascular retina Aggresive posterior-ROP- Intravitreal anti-VEGF agents, eg., bevacizumab Tractional retinal detachment (stage 4A) - Pars plana vitrectomy
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: All of the following are true statements regarding retinopathy of prematurity except:
options: First screening should be done 32 weeks PMA or 4 weeks PNA, whichever is later
For infants less than 28 week, screen at 3 week of postnatal age to detect APROP
Neonates are best examined at ophthalmology OPD and hence should be transported
Screening is done using indirect ophthalmoscopy by an expert ophthalmologist
explanation: Neonates are best examined in the neonatal unit itself under the supervision of the attending neonatologist. It is not recommended to transport infants to the ophthalmic outpatient department for examination. The first screening examination should be carried out by indirect ophthalmoscopy at 32 weeks PMA or 4 weeks PNA, whichever is later. For infants born at less than 28 weeks, screening is done at 3 weeks PNA to detect APROP. Aggressive posterior ROP ("rush" disease, AP-ROP), if untreated, usually progresses to total retinal detachment (stage 5) within a few days. It is characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease and ill-defined nature of the retinopathy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A preterm neonate admitted to NICU who received supplemental oxygen is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity. Fundus examination reveals a subtotal retinal detachment. How will you stage the disease?
explanation: Subtotal retinal detachment is considered to be stage 4 of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). The clinical staging of ROP is as follows: Stage 1 - Formation of a demarcation line at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina. Stage 2- Formation of an intraretinal ridge Stage 3- Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous Stage 4- Subtotal retinal detachment Stage 5- Total retinal detachment
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 14-day-old neonate born at 28 weeks of gestation had developed respiratory distress syndrome at birth. You want to screen for retinopathy of prematurity. How many weeks from now would you schedule the screening?
explanation: In the scenario above, the postnatal age of the premature infant is 2 weeks, and therefore, the infant must be screened in 2 weeks i.e., 4 weeks of postnatal age, as per the guidelines for the management of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). ROP guidelines state that the first examination should be performed between 4 and 6 weeks of postnatal age (after birth) or between 31–33 weeks of post-conceptional age (calculated as gestational age + postnatal age), whichever is later. Ideally, 2 examinations must be performed; however, 1 may suffice if it shows complete retinal vascularisation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is the most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy?
explanation: The most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy is the duration of diabetes. Diabetic retinopathy constitutes the retinal changes seen in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The most important factor for its development is duration of diabetes after the onset of puberty, followed by glycemic control. It is more common in type 1 diabetes mellitus. The presence of hypertension increases the risk of diabetic retinopathy. First fundus examination for type 1 diabetes is done after 5 years after diagnosis and for type 2 is done at the time of diagnosis. The frequency of follow-up for types 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus is every year. Diabetes in pregnancy is followed up every 3 months. The earliest feature of diabetic retinopathy is microaneurysms, which are present in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following findings on a fundus examination would suggest severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
options: Significant venous beading in any of the 4 quadrants
explanation: Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants is a feature of severe NPDR. Note: Macular star is a feature of malignant hypertensive retinopathy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him?
options: When he complains of decrease in vision
explanation: A 45 year old diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is likely to have type 2 diabetes and thus, he should undergo screening for diabetic retinopathy immediately. Duration of diabetes is the most important risk factor for developing diabetic retinopathy, especially proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The recommendations for first fundus examination in diabetic retinopathy is: Within 3-5 years of diagnosis in type 1 diabetes Immediately in type 2 diabetes. Later, the screening is continued once every year in both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes. In the event proliferative diabetic retinopathy develops, screening is done more frequently - once every 2 months.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: ETDRS study was related to?
explanation: Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a randomized clinical trial that studied the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema. The results of the study demonstrated the beneficial effects of focal photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema. The study resulted in the recommendation that all eyes with clinically significant diabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below, which is characteristic of:
explanation: The fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) image shows enlarged foveal avascular zone, seen as a hypofluorescent patch in the macula (white arrow), with surrounding capillary non perfused areas (blue arrow). Both of these are suggestive of macular ischemia. The above mentioned findings when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient points towards the diagnosis of diabetic macular ischemia. FFA images in a case of diabetic retinopathy are given below: Non proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) Punctate or pinpoint areas of hyperfluorescence - microaneurysms Abnormal branching of arteriovenous shunt - intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) Patchy filling defects of ischemia due to capillary atrophy or non perfusion Increase in the size of hypoperfusion in foveal avascular zone in macular ischemia 2. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy(PDR) Fluorescein leakage - in retinal neovascularization. Leakage in the disc region suggests neovascularization of the disc (NVD) and leakage in other regions suggests neovascularization elsewhere (NVE). The image below shows pinpoint areas of hyperfluorescence and areas of fluorescein leakage in the fundus. Option B: Macular edema also known as cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina following a break in the blood-retina barrier. On fundoscopy, a honeycomb appearance is seen, and on FFA, flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image shows the flower petal pattern on FFA as seen in CME. Option C: Submacular hemorrhage also known as subretinal hemorrhage will obscure the choroidal dye visualization and appaers as ill defined areas of hypoperfusion in the corresponding area. The retinal vessels overlying the area would, however will be visualized. There are no assosciated features of pinpoint hyperfluorescence and vascular leakage that are usually seen with diabetic macular ischemia. The below given images show fluorescein angiography which reveal blocked fluorescence in the maculae of both eyes due to subretinal hemorrhages. Option D: Premacular hemorrhage is a term used to define vitreous hemorrhage that occurs in the subhyaloid space. It is seen as a region of hypofluorescence with no overlying retinal vasculature visualization on FFA.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 69-year-old patient with hypertension has silver wiring, papilledema, and arteriovenous nipping visible on fundoscopy, but no other changes. How would you grade his disease?
explanation: A patient with hypertension having "silver wiring," papilledema, and arteriovenous nipping visible on fundoscopy has Grade IV retinopathy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 40-year-old male, newly diagnosed with systolic hypertension, presents with a three-week history of bilateral blurry vision. His visual acuity is 20/30 and 20/120 in the right and left eye, respectively. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen on his fundoscopy?
explanation: Systolic hypertension (systolic blood pressure over 200 mm Hg) with bilateral blurry vision and unremarkable examination findings point to a diagnosis of hypertensive retinopathy. Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) are not seen in hypertensive retinopathy. IRMA is a feature of diabetic retinopathy. Arteriolar narrowing occurs due to vasoconstriction and sclerosis of retinal vessels due to hypertension. Cotton wool spots are areas of nerve fibre layer infarcts. They occur due to capillary obliteration in hypertension.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The following image shows the picture of the fundus in a patient taken 48 hours after sustaining severe head trauma. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows multiple cotton wool spots around the disc. This is Purtschers' retinopathy, which is classically associated with severe head injury. It is also seen in pancreatitis and chest trauma due to fat/air embolism. Ophthalmoscopy reveals multiple, variably sized cotton-wool spots and intraretinal hemorrhages around the optic nerve. There is no effective treatment.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding sickle cell retinopathy?
options: Sea-fan appearance is seen in supero-temporal quadrant.
HbSS has more severe ocular manifestations than HbSC.
Central retinal vein occlusion may be seen.
explanation: Hemoglobin SC and S-Thal disease have the most severe ocular manifestations, although sickle SS disease has the most severe systemic manifestations. The incidence of proliferative retinopathy in SC disease (Hb SC) is 33%, sickle cell thalassemia (Hb S-Thal) is 14%, SS disease (Hb SS) is 3%. In sickle cell retinopathy, elevated blood viscosity may occlude venules and arterioles, as well as capillaries. The following fundus findings can be noted as a result: Retinal vascular peripheral non-perfusion Retinal hemorrhages: "salmon patches," "iridescent spots," and "black sunbursts" are hallmarks of nonproliferative sickle cell retinopathy. Peripheral retinal neovascularization in a "sea fan" configuration is the hallmark of proliferative sickle cell retinopathy. They are also described as "parachute" lesions. They are most commonly found in the supero-temporal vascular arcades. Angioid streaks (Rupture of Bruch’s membrane) Conjunctival "comma-shaped" capillaries and iris atrophy are other ocular findings seen. Complications of sickle cell retinopathy include central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) (occurs due to retinal hypoxia), vitreous hemorrhage and tractional retinal detachment. The image below shows 'sea fans' as seen on fluorescein angiography.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Roth spots are seen in .
explanation: Roth's spots are seen in acute leukemia. Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale center. The white centre due to coagulated fibrin-platelet plug is surrounded by red rim that is caused by hemorrhage. Roth's spots may be seen in: Subacute bacterial endocarditis Leukemia Diabetes Sickle cell retinopathy Hypertensive retinopathy HIV retinopathy Systemic lupus erythematosus The fundus image below shows Roth's spots. Option B: Uveal melanoma devolps due to malignant transformation of the normal melanocytes present in the uveal tissue. Primary posterior uveal melanoma (choroidal melanoma) which forms the majority of uveal melanoma manifests as: A solitary elevated subretinal grey-brown dome shaped mass "Collar stud" appearance on B-scan - when the tumor breaks through the Bruchs membrane and protrudes into subretinal space "Double circulation" sign Primary anterior uveal melanoma frequently involves the iris and presents as nodular melanocytic mass on the iris. The below given fundus image shows the "double circulation sign" of choroidal melanoma. Option C: Uveal lymphoma is characterized by localized or diffuse uveal infiltrates of malignant lymphoma cells. Fundus examination in these patients show diffuse creamy thickening of posterior uvea with nodular accentuation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 7-year-old boy presents with 6/6 vision in the right eye and vision for only hand movements in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. The left eye shows retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates, and telangiectatic vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: Unilateral decreased vision with retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates and telangiectatic vessels in a young boy points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease. Coats’ disease, described by Coats in 1908, affects boys three times more often than girls, has no reported racial or ethnic predilection, and is usually unilateral. The average age at diagnosis is 8–16 years. The clinical course is generally progressive. It is characterized by discrete zones of retinal vascular abnormalities like aneurysmal dilatation and leakage. It is associated with localized lipid deposition (hard exudates) and varying° of subretinal exudates. Vessels may appear telangiectatic, and they may have aneurysms that are grape-like, clustered, or light bulb-shaped. The image below depicts the typical vascular abnormalities with aneurysmal dilatation, telangiectasia, exudation, and severe lipid deposition in the macula which are seen in Coat's disease.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 64-year-old female presented with complaints of blurring of vision and pain in her left eye. She also gave a history of redness in her left eye about 3 months back, which she passed off as normal conjunctivitis. On tonometry, the IOP is 55 mm Hg. The slit-lamp revealed rubeosis iridis in all four quadrants. The fundus picture of the patient is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: Monocular blurring of vision and pain with "splashed sauce" appearance on fundoscopy points towards a diagnosis of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterised by sudden visual loss. There is splashed sauce appearance on fundoscopy due to retinal hemorrhages. Risk factors include high intraocular pressure (IOP), hypertension and blood viscosity syndromes. Its complications include neovascularisation of the iris (rubeosis iridis) and neovascular glaucoma (NVG). NVG typically occurs 3 months after the occlusive event. Up to 50% of eyes develop NVG following ischaemic CRVO. Pan-retinal photocoagulation is the treatment of choice. CRVO is classified into two types: Ischemic CRVO: Characterized by relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), markedly reduced visual acuity, and many cotton-wool spots Non-ischemic CRVO: Characterized by normal pupillary reaction, reduced visual acuity, and few cotton-wool spots Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A man with history of hypertension and loss of vision in the left eye has the following fundoscopy findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image above demonstrates characteristic flame-shaped hemorrhages, localized to the superotemporal sector of the retina. The image, along with loss of vision and history of hypertension, points to a diagnosis of branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO), specifically affecting the superotemporal branch of the retinal vein. Occlusion of a single branch of the retinal vein leads to branched retinal vein occlusion. This occlusion leads to impaired venous drainage, resulting in the accumulation of blood within the retina. The visual defect in BRVO tends to be partial. Note: The different types of retinal vascular obstructions are branched retinal vein obstruction (BRVO), central retinal vein obstruction (CRVO), branched retinal artery obstruction (BRAO) and central retinal artery obstruction (CRAO). Retinal vein occlusion (RVO) is the second most common retinal vascular disorder after diabetic retinopathy. In CRVO, tortuosity and engorgement of all branches of the central retinal vein are seen, affecting all quadrants of the retina.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss in his left eye. He has had a similar episode before but his vision was quickly restored. On physical exam, a carotid bruit is heard and a relative afferent pupillary defect is noted on ocular examination. His fundus appears as shown below. Which of the following is the best immediate step in the management of this condition?
explanation: Sudden painless unilateral vision loss with carotid bruit (carotid artery disease) and the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). The best immediate step in management is ocular massage among the given options. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level of lamina cribrosa. Risk factors include heart disease, carotid artery disease, mucormycosis, varicella infection, radiation exposure and trauma. It may be caused by the following: Emboli of carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli are cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis Retinal arteritis with obliteration Angiospasm Raised intraocular pressure Thrombophilic disorders Patients often present with sudden painless monocular loss of vision with history of a similar episode that resolved spontaneously (amaurosis fugax). On examination, direct pupillary reflex is absent and relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive. Fundus examination shows marked attenuation of arteries (thread like arteries), interrupted blood flow in vein (cattle track appearance), cherry red spot, severe edema and retinal pallor. A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because of the absence of ganglion cells at the foveola resulting in the transmission of the normal choroidal color. This in contrast to the surrounding area where intense retinal whitening blocks the transmission of the normal choroidal color. Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by IV acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 52-year-old woman presents with complaints of sudden painless loss of vision in the left eye since yesterday. She also gives a history of temporal headaches, myalgias, and pain in the jaw while chewing. Examination of the left eye reveals a visual acuity of HM+ and an RAPD. Fundus examination of the left eye shows cattle trucking of blood within the retinal veins on applying gentle pressure. Which of the following is the likely cause of fundal findings?
options: Non- ischemic central retinal venous occlusion
explanation: A 52-year-old woman temporal headaches, myalgias and pain in the jaw while chewing likely has giant cell arteritis (GCA). Given that she has sudden painless monocular loss of vision with RAPD and points to a diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). GCA is the most common primary vasculitis in adults. It is a risk factor for the development of CRAO. CRAO occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level of lamina cribrosa. When obstruction to the blood flow is not complete, the flow may be partially restored. Thus, gentle pressure upon the globe may break the column of venous blood into red beads separated by clear interspaces. This gives the characteristic 'cattle truck' appearance. Option A: Ischemic CRVO shows a characteristic "splashed tomato sauce" appearance on fundoscopy. Option C: Non-Ischemic CRVO does not present with such a severe loss of visual acuity. Option D: Branched retinal artery occlusion presents with hemifield visual defects.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden painless loss of vision. Fundoscopy findings are shown below. Which of the following findings do you expect in this patient?
explanation: Sudden painless monocular loss of vision with fundoscopy showing Hollehorst plaque is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen in these cases. Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that are seen in retinal arterioles. On fundus examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal vessels. Note: Although elevated intraocular pressure has been implicated as a cause of central retinal artery obstruction, it is unlikely that intraocular pressure can be raised high enough to block arterial inflow to the eye
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describes the sensation that a curtain was coming up over his affected eye. In addition, 7 days ago the patient noticed what he described as flashing lights and floaters. He gives a history of having cataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. A B-scan image of his left eye is shown below. Which of the following statements best describes the pathology?
options: Fibrovascular membranes in the vitreous causing traction
Fluid accumulation between NSR and RPE due to retinal tear
Fluid accumulation between NSR and RPE due to choroidal exudation
explanation: The prodromal symptoms of flashing lights, floaters followed by loss of monocular vision (curtain over the eye) and the B-scan suggest a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between NSR and RPE due to a retinal tear. Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the most common type of retinal detachment. It occurs due to fluid accumulation after a retinal break (tear). High myopia, trauma, pseudophakia, aphakia are predisposing factors. Patients present with photopsia (flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break), floaters and visual field defect (black curtain/veil in front of the eye). Signs include hypotony, as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE and Shafers sign or tobacco dusting (pigments in the anterior vitreous). The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations. The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear and the most dangerous location of retinal break is the supero-temporal retina. Treatment is by prophylactic laser barrage, scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy and pars plana vitrectomy. Other types of retinal detachment are tractional and exudative type: Tractional retinal detachment occurs when fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. It is seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy, central retinal venous occlusion, Eales disease and ROP. The detached retina is concave in configuration. No breaks are seen. Treatment is with pars plana vitrectomy with endo photocoagulation. Exudative retinal detachment is seen when exudative fluid from the choroid collects in the subretinal space. Patients present with visual field defects, floaters due to vitritis but no photopsia. The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break is seen. Shifting fluid is seen. The image below shows a fundus which reveals retinal detachment inferiorly from 3-9 o'clock with tear at 3:30.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Pneumatic retinopexy is an outpatient procedure where retinal detachment is sealed with air insufflation. Which of the following gases would you use while performing the said procedure?
explanation: Sulphur hexafluoride is the gas used in pneumatic retinopexy for the treatment of retinal detachments Pneumatic retinopexy is used for the treatment of fresh retinal detachments with a single retinal break in the superior two-thirds of the fundus. In this procedure, a bubble is injected intravitreally through the conjunctiva and postoperatively the patient is positioned so that the bubble tamponades the retinal break against the retinal pigment epithelium.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 24-year-old woman who is 8 months pregnant, myopic, and diabetic presents to you with sudden painless loss of vision in her right eye. She is a known case of Eales' disease. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. Which of her conditions is responsible for a fundus finding of retinal detachment with a positive shifting fluid sign?
explanation: Exudative retinal detachment is characterized by positive shifting fluid sign. Among her conditions, toxemia of pregnancy is one of the causes of exudative retinal detachment. Exudative retinal detachment occurs due to the presence of subretinal fluid in the absence of tear or traction. It is caused by: Malignant melanoma of the choroid Retinoblastoma Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada (VKH) syndrome Uveal effusion syndrome Posterior scleritis Coat’s disease Malignant hypertension Pregnancy-induced hypertensive retinopathy Sympathetic ophthalmitis Patients present with sudden and painless diminution of vision, visual field defects and grey reflex (detached retina looks grey). Indirect ophthalmoscopy is the investigation of choice. The image depicts retinal detachment showing a smooth, detached convex retina with subretinal fluid.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Shifting fluid sign is seen in?
explanation: The presence of shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment. In serous retinal detachment, there is a subretinal accumulation of the serous fluid mostly due to the breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier. When the position of the head is altered, the fluid shifts to the dependent portion. Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration. A retinal tear or preretinal traction is absent. Other options: Option B: Traction RD has a concave configuration and breaks are absent. Retinal mobility is severely reduced and shifting fluid is absent. Option C: Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous with substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells. Retinal breaks are also seen.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Hollenhorst plaques are seen in .
explanation: Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal arterial occlusion (CRAO). They are cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. They originate from atherosclerotis plaques in larger arteries. The image below shows Hollenhorst plaques (arrow).

question_text: Identify the condition.
explanation: The above image shows a loss of foveal reflex and central serous retinopathy, therefore showing focal foveal detachment. There is oedema at the fovea signifying foveal detachment from underlying retinal pigment epithelium. Macular oedema is also present (grey dull retina with a ring reflex around the site of oedema). Thus, the most appropriate choice would be foveal detachment. Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the macular region. It occurs due to increased permeability of choriocapillaris, leading to fluid accumulation in the subretinal space. Therefore, it is now known as central serous choriopathy (CSC). If there is serous retinal detachment at macula, there is sudden painless loss of vision. Patients also have relative positive scotoma, micropsia and metamorphopsia. On ophthalmoscopy, a circular ring reflex present. The foveal reflex is absent. On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), an enlarging ink-blot pattern or smoke-stack pattern is seen. Treatment is generally not required. It is usually self-limiting, but often recurrent. Steroids are contraindicated.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In which of the following conditions is the given sign seen?
explanation: The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Smokestack appearance is another pattern of fundus seen in CSR and is a characteristic sign of this condition. Amsler grid is used for: Assess macular function and detecting maculopathy. question_text:
The ETDRS chart is used for visual evaluation in diabetic patients. What does ETDRS stand for?
Extended treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
options: Early treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
Emergency treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
Emerging treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
explanation: ETDRS stands for Early Treatment for Diabetic Retinopathy Study. ETDRS was a clinical trial designed to evaluate if argon laser photocoagulation or aspirin treatment can reduce the risk of visual loss or slow the progression of diabetic retinopathy in patients with mild-to-severe nonproliferative or early proliferative diabetic retinopathy. During the study, three new visual acuity charts were created in place of Snellen's visual chart. Macular disorders, Retinal dystrophies, and Vitreal disorders
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A 25-year-old artist visits an art gallery. A painting of checkered squares appears distorted only to him, as shown below. He decides to go see an ophthalmologist who after initial evaluation, suggests an FFA. The FFA shows a characteristic smoke stack appearance.
Breakdown of which of the following barriers is responsible for his condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with a characteristic smoke stack pattern on FFA is suggestive of a diagnosis of central serous retinopathy. In CSR, the outer blood-retinal barrier is disrupted. CSR is the serous detachment of the neurosensory retina with focal and multifocal areas of leakage at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), mainly affecting the macular area. That is why the patient who is usually a young male presents with macular symptoms such as blurring of central vision, metamorphopsia. The blood-retina barrier (BRB) is composed of inner and outer barriers. The outer BRB refers to the barrier formed at the retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cell layer and regulates the movement of solutes and nutrients from the choroid to the sub-retinal space. By contrast, the inner BRB, similar to the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is located in the inner retinal microvasculature and comprises the microvascular endothelium, which lines these vessels. The image given below shows the smoke-stack pattern seen in CSR. Amsler grid is used in detecting maculopathy. Uses: Assess macular function Evaluate the visual field of 10° Good for follow-up in CSR The image below shows Amsler's grid.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Where does fluid accumulate in central serous retinopathy?
options: Between the Bruch membrane and retinal pigment epithelium
Between the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer
explanation: Fluid accumulation in central serous retinopathy (CSR) is in the subretinal space due to abnormal permeability of the choriocapillaris. The image depicts optical coherence tomography showing fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 60-year-old female presented with acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia. There is a history of the positive scotoma. Fundal changes are given below. What will be the fundus fluorescein angiography finding?
explanation: The above clinical scenario and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment are suggestive of central serous retinopathy. An enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern is seen in FFA. Central serous retinopathy refers to the spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region. Recent studies implicate an abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. Clinical features: Retinal detachment - Sudden painless loss of vision Relative positive scotoma Micropsia Metamorphopsia Investigations: Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases and hence observation is enough. Steroids are contraindicated. The disease is usually self-limiting but may recur. The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Other options: Option B- Petaloid appearance is seen in cystoid macular edema Option C- Stars in the sky appearance is suggestive of drusen Option D- Dual circulation is a pathognomonic feature of choroidal melanoma
