question_text: A 69-year-old man who is a chronic smoker, hypertensive, and has a BMI of 35 kg/m2 complains of diminished vision in the right eye. His visual acuity is 6/36 BE and the anterior segment appears normal. His fundus is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario along with the image which shows drusen (druplets) are a feature of dry or non-exudative age-related macular degeneration (ARMD). Drusen are the earliest visible clinical signs of ARMD. They are composed of lipid, amyloid, complement factors, and associated cellular components. There are two types of ARMD: Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) ARMD is the most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed cases. Initially characterized by macular Drusens, which later progress to geographical atrophy. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry ARMD. Antioxidants ike the AREDS2 supplements have proven effective. Wet (exudative, neovascular) ARMD is much less common than the dry type, but it is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss. question_text: Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) is primarily indicated in which of the following conditions?
explanation: Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) is primarily indicated in an occult choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM). ICGA is used to visualize the choroidal vasculature. Its main use is to differentiate between classic and occult CNVM when the clinical picture is not clear.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF is used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
explanation: Intravitreal injection of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is used as the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration (ARMD). Wet ARMD is characterized by retinal pigment epithelial detachment and choroidal/subretinal neovascularization. Treatment of ARMD depends on the location of the choroidal neovascularization membrane: For extrafoveal membrane - Laser photocoagulation For subfoveal and juxta foveal membranes, treatment options are as follows: Intravitreal injection of anti -VEGF agents Photodynamic therapy - the dye used is verteporfin followed by exposure to light from a diode Transpupillary thermotherapy
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An old cab driver whose livelihood depends on his driving is distressed. He complains that everything appears distorted and he perceives objects to smaller than their usual size. His anterior segment appears normal. Examination of the fundus reveals a honeycomb appearance of the macula. FFA is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image is that of fluorescein angiography showing the "flower petal pattern," which is seen in cystoid macular edema (CME). The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer at the macula The accumulation of fluid in the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer leads to retinal thickening at macula and loss of foveal depression, formation of cystic spaces (honey-comb macula). Risk factors include retinitis pigmentosa, uveitis, niacin, PGE2 analogues, epinephrine in aphakia, diabetic retinopathy, retinal venous occlusion and Irvin-Gass syndrome (CME post-cataract surgery). Symptoms may include blurring of vision, distortion, and micropsia. Therapeutic approaches for treating CME depend on the underlying etiology. This includes steroids, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, anti-VEGF agents, PPV for associated vitreomacular traction.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient presents to the emergency department and is found to have a corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation, and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
explanation: Suprachoroidal hemorrhage will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient. Maculopathy is common in eyes developing hypotony, which is defined as IOP <6 mmHg. The most common cause is excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery (Option D). Other causes include trauma such as cyclodialysis of the uvea (Option B), penetrating injury (Option C), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment, and other systemic causes such as dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes, uremia, and treatment with hyperosmotic agents. They usually cause bilateral hypotonic maculopathy. Suprachoroidal hemorrhage is a bleed into the suprachoroidal space that results from the rupture of the posterior ciliary artery. When the bleed is severe it causes extrusion of intraocular contents that is termed as expulsive hemorrhage. It is a rare but dreaded complication of the phacoemulsification procedure. Signs seen in suprachoroidal hemorrhage are: Progressive increase in intraocular pressure Prolapse of iris Loss or partial obscuration of the red reflex In severe cases there can be extrusion of the posterior segment contents into the anterior chamber and through the incision such as vitreous extrusion Immediate treatment involves rapid closure of the incision followed by administration of IOP-lowering medications such as oral acetazolamide and topical or systemic steroids to reduce inflammation. Standard post-operative antibiotics can be added in these patients.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 45-year old patient on systemic treatment for rheumatoid arthritis develops bilateral painless decrease in vision. What does the image show?
options: Fluorescein angiography showing bull’s eye maculopathy
Autofluorescence showing changes of bull’s eye maculopathy
explanation: The investigation shown in the image is an autofluorescence showing bull’s eye maculopathy. Hydroxychloroquine, which is generally used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, toxicity causes bull’s eye maculopathy. Chloroquine binds to melanin in the retinal pigment epithelium, causing cytotoxic effects. RPE atrophy occurs in the macula, resulting in dark areas on the autofluorescence image. Other causes of Bull’s eye maculopathy include chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine, congenital cone dystrophy, juvenile X-linked retinoschisis, and juvenile Batten's disease. Fundus autofluorescence is a non-invasive imaging modality. It reflects the morphological changes associated with the metabolism of lipofuscin and does not require the injection of any fluorescent dye. A fundus image of bull’s eye maculopathy is shown below: The following image shows the difference between fundus autofluorescence and fluorescence angiography Other ocular effects of chloroquine include: Chloroquine keratopathy—vortex keratopathy Ocular palsy, ptosis Electroretinographic depression Optic neuritis Posterior subcapsular cataract
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A study used electroretinography(ERG) in military conscripts whose visual abnormalities could not be explained by the findings of ophthalmologic, neurological, and psychiatric examinations. The ERG of pure malingerers was found to be, as shown below. The activity of which cells of the retina is depicted by the a-wave?
explanation: "a" wave in an electroretinogram (ERG) represents rods and cones. Electroretinography is used to evaluate retinal functions by examining the electrical response to a light stimulus. Electroretinograms (ERGs) show the amplitudes of currents that flow within the eye following exposure to a point of light. The amplitudes are analyzed into waves, which are composed of the responses of neuronal, glial, and retinal pigment epithelial cells. ERG: The a-wave originates from photoreceptors (rods and cones) The b-wave originates from Muller and bipolar cells, but is directly dependant on photoreceptors The c-wave originates from retinal pigment epithelial cells and retinal glial cells Oscillatory potentials (OPs) originate in the inner retina Scotopic ERGs are used to evaluate responses starting from rod photoreceptors exposed to flash-light in darkness, and photopic ERGs are used to evaluate responses starting from cone photoreceptors exposed to flash-light under constant light exposure.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which area of the retina has the highest concentration of rods?
explanation: Mid-periphery of the retina has the highest concentration of rods. The following table lists the differences between rods and cones Property Rods Cones Number Most numerous (120 million) Far fewer in number (6 milli on) Location Mid-peripheral retina Fovea Function Night visionMotion sensePeri pheral vision Day visionColour visionCentr al and fine vision Dysfunction sympt oms NyctalopiaPeripheral field los s Poor central visionDyschrom atopsiaHemeralopia

question_text: A researcher is studying mutations in the rhodopsin gene which are responsible for some forms of autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa. On which chromosome is this gene located?
explanation: The gene for rhodopsin is located at 3q22.1 Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary types, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis. The presenting feature is night blindness. Investigations: Perimetry - the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision. Electroretinography - reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves. Retinitis pigmentosa is a condition with no cure. There are drugs used to slow down the progression such as acetazolamide for concomitant cystoid macular edema. Recently, vitamin A has been recommended, although the efficacy has not been established.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)?
options: RPE forms the inner blood retinal barrier
Electroculogram is an assessment of RPE health
Bruch’s membrane is the basement membrane of RPE
explanation: Tight junctions between retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) form the outer blood-retinal barrier. The inner blood-retinal barrier is formed by the tight junctions between the endothelial cells of retinal capillaries. RPE serves many functions, like Development of photoreceptors during embryogenesis Tight junctions between RPE form the outer blood-retinal barrier Absorption of fluid from the subretinal space and adhesion of the underlying neurosensory retina Selective transport of metabolites to and from the retina Uptake, transport, storage, metabolism, and isomerization of vitamin A Regeneration of the visual pigment rhodopsin Phagocytosis of photoreceptor outer segment tips Absorption of stray light by melanin If the RPE is damaged, this is seen as a loss of autofluorescence (RPE-deficient areas appear darker on autofluorescence images). Bruch's membrane is the basement membrane of RPE.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following disorders is not associated with retinitis pigmentosa?
explanation: Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is associated with abetalipoprotenemia (Bassen–•ornzweig syndrome) and not with abetaglobulinemia. Syndromes associated with R P (Atypical RP) Usher syndrome Sensory neuraldeafness+ RP Bardet–Biedl syndrome(Previ ously called Lawrence–Moon –Biedl–Bartum Syndrome) Polydactyly, obesity, mental handicap, and kidney disease + RP •earn–Sayre syndrome Ocular myopathy and heart d isease + RP Refsum Syndrome Varied skin as well as neurol ogical and visceral features + RP Bassen–•ornzweig syndrome Abetalipoprotenemia and aca nthocytosis + RP Neuropathy, ataxia, and retin itis pigmentosa (NARP) Neuropathy and Ataxia + RP
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa?
explanation: Electroretinogram (ERG) is abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa (RP). ERG is a sensitive diagnostic test in retinitis pigmentosa that shows reduced scotopic, subnormal responses in early disease and becomes completely extinguished in advanced disease. Electroocoulogram (EOG) is also abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa. Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is an inherited or acquired pigmentatory retinal dystrophy affecting the rods more than the cones. The earliest manifestation is worsening of night blindness and delayed adaptation which gradually progresses to tunnel vision and ultimately loss of central vision. The classic triad of findings in RP comprises: Bone-spicule retinal pigmentation Arteriolar attenuation ‘Waxy’ disc pallor The image below shows the classical triad findings of retinitis pigmentosa.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
explanation: The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP). Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis. The presenting feature is night blindness. Investigations: Perimetry - the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision. Electroretinography - reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves. Atypical types of RP are as follows: Sectoral RP Pericentric/Inverse RP RP sine pigmento RP punctata albescens There is no effective treatment for RP.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In which of the following conditions is the Mizuo phenomenon seen?
explanation: Mizuo phenomenon is seen in Oguchi's disease. Oguchi's disease is a type of congenital stationary night blindness with abnormal fundus. Congenital stationary night blindness refers to a group of disorders characterized by infantile-onset nyctalopia but non-progressive retinal dysfunction. The fundus has an unusual golden yellow color in the light-adapted state, which becomes normal after prolonged dark adaptation (Mizuo or Mizuo–Nakamura phenomenon). The following image shows a comparison in the fundus appearances ("A" shows the golden yellow color of the fundus in a light-adapted state; "B" shows normal-appearing funds after prolonged dark adaptation of 3 to 4 hours) Rod function is absent even after 30 minutes of dark adaptation (normal dark adaptation time is 20–30 mins) but recovers to a near-normal level after a long period of dark adaptation (4 hours).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Flat electrooculogram (EOG) is an Arden ratio of .
explanation: A flat electrooculogram (EOG) is an Arden ratio of less than 1.25. An EOG measures the standing potential of the eye. It reflects the activity of the RPE and the photoreceptors. This means that an eye blinded by disease proximal to the photoreceptors will have a normal EOG. Arden ratio is the ratio between the light peak and the dark trough in an EOG. The normal Arden ratio is 1.85 and above. A flat EOG occurs when the Arden ratio is less than 1.25. Best disease is an autosomal-dominant childhood disease characterized by the dystrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. In Best disease, the Arden ratio is less than 1.50.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A young patient presents with loss of central vision. ERG is normal, but EOG is abnormal. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The diagnosis based on the above scenario is Best's disease. Best's disease/Vitelliform macular dystrophy is an inherited macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula causing progressive central vision loss. It is autosomal-dominant and linked to the mutation in the bestrophin (VMD2) gene. It is characterized by bilateral yellow, yolk-like (vitelliform) macular lesions. The stages of evolution of the macular lesions are described as progressing from: Pre-vitelliform stage Vitelliform stage - scrambled egg stage with or without hypopyon Vitelliruptive - the lesion breaks and visual acuity drops The atrophic stage Patients with Best’s disease usually have good visual acuity when the "yolk" remains intact. Diagnosis: This is the only disease with relatively normal ERG results associated with an abnormal EOG. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) reveals that the vitelliform material appears as a dome-shaped, hyperreflective, and homogenous lesion, located below the hyperreflective photoreceptor layer. The image below shows Best’s disease - the typical vitelliform lesion in an 11-year-old girl. 248
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A young patient presents with loss of central vision. There is a family history of a similar condition. Both EOG and ERG are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis based on the given scenario is Stargardt's disease. Stargardt's disease also known as Stargardt macular dystrophy or fundus flavimaculatus is the most common macular dystrophy. It most commonly is inherited in an autosomal-recessive manner caused by a mutation on an adenosine triphosphate-binding cassette (ABCA4) gene. Characterized by macular "pisciform" flecks that accumulate at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), sometimes resulting in central macular atrophy early in life. Patients develop a macula with a “beaten bronze” appearance caused by atrophic changes in the RPE. In addition, a "dark" or "silent" choroid is seen on the fluorescein angiography that appears as a prominent retinal circulation against hypofluorescent choroid. The electroretinogram (ERG) and electro-oculography (EOG) are normal early in the disease but may be reduced in more advanced cases. Of note, the ERG findings do not directly correlate with clinical findings. There is no known proven treatment for this disease. Because ABCA4 plays a role in vitamin A processing in the visual cycle, additional vitamin A is suspected to make the disease worse. The image below shows macular pisciform flecks. Other options: Option A: Retinitis pigmentosa: abnormal electroretinogram (ERG). Option B: Rod–cone dystrophy: abnormal ERG. Option D: Best's disease: Normal ERG with abnormal electrooculogram (EOG).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Silent choroid on FFA is a feature of which of the following disorders?
explanation: Silent/Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of Stargardt's disease. The classic feature of 'silent choroid' is due to the masking of background choroidal fluorescence by lipofuscin deposits in the subretinal space. Stargardt disease constitutes the most common type of macular dystrophy. It has mutations in a photoreceptor cell-specific ATP-binding cassette gene (ABC4) that is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The disease usually starts in the juvenile group with progressive central vision loss and color vision loss that occurs due to the atrophy of the macular retinal pigment epithelium with an accumulation of discrete pisciform flecks of lipofuscin. Signs of Stargardt’s disease: Beaten bronze appearance of the macula that is caused by the atrophic changes in the RPE. Silent/Dark choroid on FFA. Visual field testing shows central vision loss. The electroretinogram (ERG) is normal early in the disease but may be reduced in more advanced cases. Fundus flavimaculatus is genetically considered to be a part of the same spectrum as Stargardt's disease with late onset i.e. usually after 40 years of age. Other options: Option B: Best's disease also known as vitelliform macular dystrophy is an autosomal dominant macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula, causing progressive central vision loss. This disease is linked to mutations in the bestrophin (VMD2) gene and they do not exhibit silent choroid on FFA. Findings seen in Best’s disease are: Vitelliform(yolk like) appearance of the fundus Relatively normal ERG results associated with abnormal EOG The given below is the fundus picture of Best's disease showing an egg yolk lesion in the macula. Option C: Age related Macular degeneration(ARMD) also known as senile macular degeneration is a chronic and progressive bilateral degenerative disorder of the macula that affects older individuals >50 yrs. ARMD is classified as dry and wet ARMD where the hallmarks are the presence of drusen and choroidal neovascularization respectively. Drusen are extracellular eosinophilic deposits between RPE and Bruch’s membrane. Clinical features include loss of central vision, distorted vision (lines seen as wavy), and sudden painless loss of vision as seen in wet ARMD. The image below shows Drusens in the macular area in dry macular degeneration. Option D: Cystoid Macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina following a break in the blood-retinal barrier. In CME on fundoscopy, a honeycomb appearance and on FFA flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image shows the flower petal pattern on FFA as seen in CME.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A neonate with leukocoria and strabismus is diagnosed to have persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV). Which of the following congenital disorders is it associated with?
explanation: Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is associated with Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13). PHPV is a developmental disorder of the vitreous humor. In this condition, there is persistence of the embryonic hyaloid vessel. Anterior PHPV - Here, the remnant vessel is attached to the back of the lens but does not reach the optic nerve. Posterior PHPV- In this form of the disease, the vessel arises from the optic nerve. Clinically, PHPV presents with leucocoria and microphthalmia, and there can be complications such as tractional retinal detachments. This condition has a poor prognosis regardless of the time of intervention.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: When compared to blood, vitreous humor has a high concentration of which of the following?
explanation: When compared to blood, vitreous humor has a high concentration of ascorbate. The vitreous: plasma ratio of ascorbic acid concentration is 9:1. This high concentration of ascorbic acid is maintained by the active transport by the ciliary body epithelium, and it is attributed to the ability of the ascorbate to absorb ultraviolet rays and act as a free radical scavenger.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 40-year-old woman complains of discomfort in her left eye. There is a past history of blunt trauma in her childhood which made her left eye blind. Slit-lamp examination of her left eye is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: These are synchysis scintillans, which are floaters composed of cholesterol bodies, found in the vitreous (extending into the anterior chamber in this picture). Synchysis scintillans are vitreous opacities that occur as a consequence of chronic vitreous haemorrhage, often in a blind eye. This condition is usually discovered, when frank haemorrhage is no longer present. They are composed of cholesterol derived from plasma cells or degraded products of erythrocytes. Vitreous opacities can be caused by a variety of pathological processes and the following are few examples of vitreous opacities: Vitreous haemorrhage Asteroid hyalosis Synchysis scintillans Amyloidosis Vitreous cyst Persistent fetal vasculature.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding. It is also noted that these yellow-white vitreous opacities do not settle down when the eye is immobile. All of the following statements about this condition are true except:
explanation: The examination findings are suggestive of asteroid bodies/hyalosis. It is not common in myopes. Asteroid hyalosis is a common degenerative process in which calcium pyrophosphate particles collect within the vitreous gel. It is seen clinically as numerous tiny round yellow-white opacities of varying size and density. These move with the vitreous during eye movements but do not sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile. Only one eye is affected in 75% of patients; it rarely causes visual problems and the majority of patients are asymptomatic. The cause of asteroid hyalosis is unknown, but it has been associated with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The prevalence of asteroid hyalosis increases with age and affects 3% of those aged 75–86 years. It is more common in men than in women. While treatment of asteroid hyalosis is usually unnecessary, vitrectomy may occasionally be indicated.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A young male presents with recurrent vitreous hemorrhage. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: For a young male presenting with recurrent vitreous hemorrhage, the diagnosis is Eale's disease. Eales disease is an idiopathic occlusive peripheral periphlebitis. It is characterized by three overlapping stages: inflammatory, occlusive, and retinal neovascular. Visual prognosis is good in the majority of cases. It is an important cause of visual morbidity in young males from the Indian subcontinent. Diagnosis: Symptoms - Floaters or sudden visual reduction due to vitreous hemorrhage. There can be neurological deficits as well. Mild anterior uveitis Fundus - The condition is typically bilateral, although often asymmetrical. Peripheral periphlebitis Branch retinal vein occlusion Peripheral capillary non-perfusion; microaneurysms, tortuosity, vascular shunts, and neovascularization with recurrent vitreous hemorrhage Treatment: Steroids: Periocular, systemic, topical, and intravitreal steroids seem to be helpful in the inflammatory stage. Antitubercular treatment
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is characteristic of Eale’s disease?
explanation: Eale’s disease is an idiopathic inflammatory venous occlusion (phlebitis) that primarily affects the peripheral retina that is periphlebitis and is characterized by recurrent bilateral vitreous hemorrhage. Superficial retinal hemorrhages and cotton-wool spots can be sometimes seen, but they are not characteristic of Eales disease.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of a vitreous hemorrhage?
explanation: The investigation of choice for vitreous hemorrhage is ultrasonography (USG) B-scan. Mild hemorrhage causes sudden onset floaters and diffuse blurring of vision, but may not affect visual acuity, whilst a dense bleed may result in sudden painless loss of vision. B-mode ultrasonography(B-scan) in unclotted vitreous hemorrhage generally shows a uniform appearance, and once cellular aggregates develop, small particulate echoes become visible. Causes of vitreous hemorrhage: Acute posterior vitreous detachment associated either with a retinal tear or avulsion of a peripheral vesse Proliferative retinopathy Diabetic Retinal vein occlusion Sickle cell disease Eales disease Vasculitis Miscellaneous retinal disorders Macroaneurysm Telangiectasia Capillary hemangioma Trauma Systemic Bleeding disorders Terson syndrome- refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery. Treatment is dictated by severity and cause, but an increasingly low threshold is being adopted for early vitrectomy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Sub-hyaloid hemorrhage is .
explanation: Sub-hyaloid hemorrhage is dome-shaped or boat-shaped. Subhyaloid hemorrhage is the collection of blood in the potential space between the posterior vitreous and internal limiting membrane of the retina. The image depicts a sub-hyaloid hemorrhage which is boat-shaped.

question_text: What is a reverse hypopyon?
options: Collection of pus in the vitreous
Collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber
explanation: Reverse hypopyon is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber. Silicone oil is the vitreous substitute that is injected into the vitreous cavity after vitrectomy. When it gets emulsified, it enters the anterior chamber and collects in the upper part. Complications of silicone oil in the anterior chamber: Glaucoma Band-shaped keratopathy The image below shows reverse hypopyon.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
Which anti-fungal can be administered intravitreally?
Fluconazole
explanation: Voriconazole and amphotericin-B can be given intravitreally. Vancomycin and ceftazidime is the preferred combination for endophthalmitis (intravitreous). Amikacin (0.4 mg in 0.1 ml) or gentamicin (0.4 mg in 0.1 ml) are used less frequently in endophthalmitis owing to the risk of macular infarction. question_text: What is the embryonic origin of the lens?
explanation: The lens of the eye originates embryonically from the surface ectoderm. Surface ectoderm gives rise to lens, conjunctival and corneal epithelium and epithelial lining of lacrimal glands and tarsal glands.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Where are the youngest fibers of the lens present?
explanation: The youngest fibers of the lens are the peripheral part, the cortex. The nucleus of the lens is the central part containing the oldest fibers. The lens fibers are produced by mitosis of the epithelial cells in the pre-equatorial zone. As the lens fibers elongate and the new ones are formed, the older ones are pushed towards the depth of the lens so that the youngest fibers are the most superficially located.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: At a routine ophthalmological check-up, a patient was found to have bilateral, Y-shaped lens opacities as shown below. He was diagnosed with suture cataracts. Which zone of the lens nucleus is not involved here?
explanation: The primary fibers in the embryonic nucleus of the lens do not form Y-shaped sutures. The image shows bilateral cataracts in the Y-shaped sutures of the lens. These are very slowly progressive congenital cataracts and do not require any surgical intervention. Types of lens nucleus and their age of development: Embryonic nucleus: Innermost nucleus formed at around 1–3 months of gestation Fetal nucleus: From 3 months of gestation till birth Infantile nucleus: From birth to puberty Adult nucleus As lens fibers grow anteriorly and posteriorly, a pattern emerges where the ends of the fibers meet. These patterns of cell association are known as sutures. Y-shaped sutures are recognizable at about 8 weeks of gestation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the ligament of Weigert?
options: Attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens
Attachment of the lens to the ciliary muscles
explanation: The hyaloideo-capsular ligament of Weigert is the attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens. It is the annular region (1–2 mm in width and 8–9 mm in diameter) where the vitreous is attached to the posterior aspect of the lens. Erggelet’s or Berger’s space is at the centre of the hyaloideo-capsular ligament, a potential space between the vitreous and the lens. The canal of Cloquet arises from this space and courses posteriorly through the central vitreous, which is the former site of the hyaloid artery in the embryonic vitreous. Posteriorly, Cloquet’s canal opens into a funnel-shaped region anterior to the optic disc, whch is known as the area of Martegiani.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Where does the crystalline lens derive its nutrition from?
explanation: The crystalline lens derives its nutrition from the aqueous humor. The lens is an avascular structure. It receives nutrition mostly from the aqueous humor and, to some extent, from the vitreous humor as well. Glucose is the main energy source. Major intrinsic protein 26 (MIP 26)/Aquaporin 0 in the lens is responsible for maintaining transparency by transporting water and glycerol across the lens. Anti-oxidant mechanisms in the lens: Reduced glutathione (most important) Glutathione peroxidase Superoxide dismutase Catalase Vitamin C, Vitamin E, carotenoids.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: While studying the histological anatomy of the lens, you are measuring the thickness of the lens capsule in various areas. At which of the following zones would you get the lowest measurement?
explanation: The lens capsule is the thinnest at the posterior pole, measuring 4 µm. Other options: Option A: At the anterior pole, the thickness of lens capsule is 14 µm. Option C: In the pre-equator region, lens capsule is the thickest, measuring 23 µm. Option D: At the equator, as shown in the illustration below, the thickness is 17 µm.

question_text: You are observing the given slide in a histology examination. Where is the marked structure absent?
explanation: The slide shows the histology of the lens and the structure marked in the subcapsular epithelium. The epithelium of the lens is absent on its posterior surface. The lens epithelium is a single layer of cells on the anterior surface of the lens. There is no epithelium on the posterior surface, as these cells are used up in filling the central cavity of the lens vesicle during the development of the lens. The anterior epithelial lining creates new lens fibers throughout a person's life.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced state by .
explanation: Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced, functional state by glutathione. Glutathione is present in high concentrations in the lens, particularly in the epithelial layer. One of its key functions is to maintain protein thiols in their reduced state, which preserves the lens transparency by preventing the formation of high molecular weight crystalline aggregates and protects the lens from oxidative stress. The lens is highly prone to photochemical reactions from continuous exposure to ultraviolet rays (295–400 nm), leading to reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation. Its defence relies heavily on superoxide dismutase, ascorbate, catalase and glutathione peroxidase. With ageing or cataracts, levels of glutathione and ascorbic acid (in reduced form) significantly decrease.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: As part of a public health initiative, screening for cataract is being carried out. What is the most common cause of this healthcare issue in the population?
explanation: The most common cause of cataracts is ageing, specifically senile (age-related) cataract. Important causes of cataract: Aging (Most common) Congenital cataract (crystallin gene - CRYAA, CRYAB, CRYGC, CRYGS) (Option A) Diabetes mellitus (Option B) Syndermatotic- atopic dermatitis is the most common skin condition associated with cataract Galactosemia- reversible cataract Radiation- UV rays, X-rays, gamma rays, infrared Toxic agents- Corticosteroids, miotics (long-acting anticholinesterases, e.g., echothiophate) (Option C) Obesity Senile cataract is the most common type of acquired cataract and is also known as age-related cataract. The two types of senile cataracts are cortical (soft cataract)-75% and nuclear (hard cataract)-25%. In cortical cataract, the cuneiform type (70%) is the most common, and the cupuliform type is the most visually handicapping.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: You are compiling a literature review on congenital cataracts diagnosed in the last few years. Which of the following is the most common type?
explanation: The most common type of congenital cataract is the blue-dot cataract. Cataracta-punctata-caerulea, commonly known as blue dot cataract, is a prevalent type of congenital cataract. It typically develops during the first two decades of life. This condition is characterized by distinctive rounded bluish opacities located in the peripheral region of the adolescent nucleus and the deeper cortical layers of the lens. While these opacities are generally stationary and do not impair vision, larger ones may cause slight visual disturbance.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The parents of a child have been informed at a PTA meeting that he has a lot of incomplete classwork. On being questioned, the child complains that he is unable to see things clearly and is having difficulty in reading and writing. On ophthalmic examination, he is found to have a cataract. Which type of congenital cataract most commonly presents with these findings?
explanation: Lamellar or zonular cataract is the most common type of congenital cataract presenting with visual impairment. The etiology may be either genetic or environmental in origin. Genetic- familial autosomal-dominant Environmental form is associated with: Vitamin D deficiency Hypocalcemia Sometimes, maternal rubella infection contracted between the 7th and 8th week of gestation may also cause lamellar cataract. The main mass of the lens internal and external to the zone of cataract is clear. Small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel (riders) may be seen towards the equator.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 33-year-old woman delivers a baby girl with a congenital rash, as shown below, and patent ductus arteriosus. What type of cataract is commonly associated with this condition?
explanation: The clinical scenario showing blueberry muffin rash, combined with patent ductus arteriosus in a baby girl, suggests a diagnosis of congenital rubella syndrome, which is typically associated with a progressive, pearly white nuclear cataract. Ocular effects of rubella: Microphthalmia Rubella keratitis Angle-closure glaucoma Nuclear pearly cataract Salt and pepper fundus (a most common ocular feature of rubella) due to diffuse chorioretinitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
The following finding is found on the ophthalmologic examination of an 18-year-old girl. What is the most likely diagnosis?
262
explanation: The image above characteristically depicts a Christmas tree cataract, featuring multiple refractile colors commonly observed in myotonic dystrophy. Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by difficulty relaxing skeletal muscles after contraction. The initial symptoms typically manifest during adolescence or early adulthood. Cataracts are an early and prominent feature in 90% of patients with myotonic dystrophy. They typically present as fine, dust-like opacities interspersed with iridescent, polychromatic spots in the cortical layer beneath the anterior and posterior lens capsule, resembling a Christmas tree. These cataracts may remain stable or progress. Surgical outcomes are generally favourable.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology OPD with the findings shown below. She has been diagnosed with a right-sided senile cataract. Identify the stage of the cataract.
explanation: The above image represents an advanced stage of cataract progression characteristic of a Morgagnian hyper-mature cataract. Morgagnian hyper-mature cataracts are characterized by liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head. Senile cataract is the most common type of acquired cataract and is also known as age-related cataract. The two types of senile cataracts are cortical (soft cataract)-75% and nuclear (hard cataract)-25%. Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types. Nuclear cataracts: These may be pigmented due to the deposition of urochrome pigments. These are cataracta brunescens (brown), cataracta nigra (black), cataracta rubra (red). question_text: Where is polychromatic luster noted?
explanation: Polychromatic luster is seen in complicated cataracts. Due to disturbances in nutrition of the lens due to inflammatory/degenerative disease of other parts of the eye like iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors. In inflammations/degenerations affecting the posterior segment, a characteristic opacification is seen in the posterior part of the cortex in the axial region (posterior subcapsular cataract). These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster. Even in the early stages, vision is impaired.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Who among the following patients can potentially develop drug-induced cataracts?
explanation: Patients taking dexamethasone (corticosteroid) are prone to drug-induced cataracts, predominantly presenting as discoid posterior subcapsular cataracts. Drugs causing cataracts: Other options: Option A: Zoledronate, a bisphosphonate drug can cause orbital inflammation, uveitis, and scleritis. Option B: Hydroxychloroquine, a drug used in malaria and rheumatoid arthritis, does not cause cataracts, chloroquine does. It can rarely cause retinal toxicity. Option D: Ethambutol is used in anti-tubercular therapy and its use has been shown to cause optic neuritis. question_text: The ophthalmologic examination on a 23-year-old college student revealed the following image. What disease is commonly associated with this ocular finding?
explanation: The given picture of a slit-lamp biomicroscope examination depicts the anterior lenticonus, which is associated with Alport syndrome. In Alport’s syndrome, both anterior and posterior lenticonus are seen, but anterior lenticonus is more common. The diagnosis of lenticonus is typically confirmed through slit-lamp examination. Note: Lowe’s syndrome is an oculo-cerebro-renal syndrome characterized by congenital cataract, glaucoma, and posterior lenticonus
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 60-year-old man, diagnosed with bilateral cataracts two months ago, reports being able to read better without prescription glasses. However, he complains that his distant vision has become blurrier. Which type of cataract typically causes this phenomenon?
explanation: The phenomenon described is the second sight of old age, seen in nuclear cataracts. Due to nuclear sclerosis, there is an increase in the refractive index, causing progressive myopia. A patient with presbyopia may be able to read again, without the aid of spectacles. This improvement in vision is termed second sight.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 38-year-old lady is a known case of diabetes and is on insulin for the last 8 years. Her sugars are poorly controlled and now she complains of hazy vision. What type of cataract will be characteristically noted in her eyes?
explanation: The typical appearance of a diabetic cataract is a snowflake cataract. Hyperglycemia is reflected in a high level of glucose in the aqueous humor, which diffuses into the lens. Here, glucose is metabolized into sorbitol, which accumulates within the lens, resulting in secondary osmotic overhydration.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 55-year-old woman presents with an inability to see objects in bright light. On examination, she is diagnosed with a cataract. In which of the following cataract is this characteristic finding not seen?
explanation: The inability to see objects in bright light is not a feature of cuneiform cataract, as the lens opacity is peripheral, allowing visibility in bright light during miosis. The loss of the ability to see objects in bright light is a feature of posterior subcapsular cataract (visually handicapping), cupuliform cataract and nuclear cataract as these present with central opacities. When a person is exposed to bright light, the pupil undergoes miosis (constriction). These central opacities come to lie directly in the path of axial rays, allowing no transmission of rays. Therefore, there is an inability to see objects in bright light. However, in dim light, when there is mydriasis (dilatation of the pupil), some rays may pass around the opacity, leading to an improvement in dim-light vision. Furthermore, the complicated cataract, steroid-induced cataract, radiation-induced mainly present with a posterior subcapsular cataract and therefore have a similar clinical picture.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: You are counseling the parents of Nisha, a 1-month-old child diagnosed with a congenital lamellar cataract in both eyes. What is the course of treatment you would advise?
options: Cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implant
Pars plana lensectomy with no IOL implant
explanation: Cataract surgery with an intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the treatment of choice in congenital cataracts. It involves an extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with primary posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy. After removal of the cataractous lens, a posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) is implanted. The critical period for the development of the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorders is 2–4 months of age. Thus, any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age, and the earliest possible time is preferred. Bilateral dense cataract- early surgery by 4-6 weeks of age Unilateral dense cataract or involving visual axis- urgent surgery within days Intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is contraindicated in children.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 28-year-old girl is being evaluated for an aortic root aneurysm. She says her mother died of an aortic dissection at the age of 43. She is tall and slim. A musculoskeletal system finding is shown below. What is the most common lens subluxation noted in the genetic disease she is suffering from?
explanation: The clinical vignette of a girl with tall, slim stature, an aortic arch aneurysm, Steinberg sign (positive thumb sign), and similar family history suggest a diagnosis of Marfan’s syndrome. It is most commonly associated with a superotemporal subluxation of the lens. The image below shows a subluxated lens in a patient with Marfan's syndrome. Congenital subluxation of the lens is called ectopia lentis. Types of ectopia lentis are as follows: Simple type Ectopia lentis et pupillae (pupil also displaced in opposite direction) Ectopia lentis associated with syndromes Marfan’s syndrome- superotemporal subluxation of lens Homocystinuria- inferonasal subluxation of the lens Weill–Marchesani- downward, forward subluxation of the lens. Ehler–Danlos syndrome

Which of the following diseases does not show a specific pattern of cataract?
Juvenile diabetes
explanation: A specific pattern of cataract is not seen in leprosy. A specific pattern of cararact is seen in the following: Juvenile diabetes: Snowflake cataract Myotonic dystrophy: Christmas tree cataract Wilson's disease: Sunflower cataract Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

question_text: A child has congenital cataract involving the visual axis, which was detected at birth. When should the child be operated up on?
options: At 1 year of age, when the globe attains normal size
At 4 years, when ocular and orbital growth is complete
explanation: The child should be operated at 4-6 weeks of age. When a child has unilateral or bilateral cataract impairing vision (involving the visual axis), the cataract surgery must be performed before 2-4 months of age. This is because 2-4 months is the critical period for visual maturation and development of the fixation reflex in children. A unilateral cataract is more dangerous than a bilateral cataract because the risk of amblyopia is greater. Under-correction of intraocular lens (IOL) power is needed in children. In children < 2 years of age: In unilateral cases, primary implantation is indicated as soon as the patient is fit for anesthesia, ideally between 2 and 3 months of age. The power is undercorrected by 20%. The earlier the surgery is done, the better the chance that deep amblyopia can be overcome. After the cataract has been aspirated, an elective posterior capsulectomy–anterior vitrectomy is performed. The posterior chamber IOL is inserted through a scleral tunnel, which is prepared in advance. Sulcus implantation is indicated in neonates and infants less than 1 year of age. In children between 2 and 8 years of age: An IOL is implanted but power is undercorrected by 10%. An in-the-bag IOL is chosen for children above 1 year of age because they are less likely to need an IOL exchange. Beyond 8 years, IOL power is the same as the calculated value.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In which of the following cataract surgeries is a self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision used?
explanation: The self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made in small-incision cataract surgery (SICS). SICS is a type of extracapsular cataract extraction techniques (ECCE). In these techniques, the major portion of the anterior capsule with the epithelium, nucleus, and cortex are removed, leaving behind the intact posterior capsule. Note: Newer cataract surgeries include femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS), micro-incision cataract surgery (MICS) and Phaconit. FLACS is a microincision cataract surgery or a micro-phacoemulsification where a femtosecond laser is used to make the corneal incisions, perform capsulorhexis and fragment the lens. MICS refers to the phacoemulsification techniques that can be performed through a microincision (<2 mm). Phaconit is the term for the bimanual micro-phacoemulsification done with the needle incision technique through an incision of <1mm.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In which of the following patients is an intracapsular cataract extraction indicated?
explanation: At present, the only indication of intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is markedly subluxated and dislocated lens. In ICCE, the entire cataractous lens along with the intact capsule is removed by rupturing the zonules. Therefore, weak and degenerated zonules are a prerequisite for this method. Methods of lens delivery include cryoextraction (best method), forceps extraction (Arruga forceps), wire vectis method and Indian Smith method. ICCE is no longer used for cataract treatment due to the large incision required, inability to implant an IOL and a high rate of complications like vitreous loss, retinal detachment and cystoid macular edema.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the length of the incision used in phacoemulsification?
explanation: The length of the incision in phacoemulsification varies from 1.5 to 2.4 mm. The option closest to this answer is B, i.e., 2 to 2.5 mm. In phacoemulsification, the nucleus of the lens is emulsified and aspired. This is done by the phacoemulsifier. It acts through a hollow 1-mm titanium needle, which vibrates by at an ultrasonic speed of 40000 times a second. The steps of phacoemulsification are given below: Step 1 - Small clear corneal incision Step 2 - Continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis Step 3 - Hydro dissection Step 4 - Hydro delineation is done in some cases. Steps 5 and 6 - Emulsification and aspiration of the nucleus Step 7 - Removal of the cortical lens matter using an irrigation-aspiration technique Step 8 - Implantation of a foldable lens Length of the incision in various cataract surgeries: Phacoemulsification- 1.5–2.4 mm. Micro-phacoemulsification- 1–1.5 mm. Intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE)- 12–14 mm. Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE)- 8–12 mm.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the most common late complication following cataract surgery?
explanation: The most common late complication following cataract surgery is posterior capsule opacification. Posterior capsule opacification, known as after or secondary cataract, is the most common late postoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation of left out anterior epithelial cells.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In a patient undergoing cataract surgery, which of the following is the most important strategy in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis?
options: One week antibiotic therapy prior to surgery
explanation: The most important factor in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis is preoperative preparation with povidone-iodine. Postoperative endophthalmitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis. Flora of the eyelids and conjunctiva are the most frequent source. Other potential sources include contaminated solutions and instruments, environmental air, and the surgeon and other operating room personnel. Prophylaxis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes: Instillation of 5% povidone-iodine into the conjunctival fornices and leaving this undisturbed for at least 3 minutes prior to surgery. This is the most important factor. Scrupulous preparation of the surgical site Treatment of pre-existing infections such as blepharitis Antibiotic prophylaxis Intracameral cefuroxime (1 mg in 0.1 mL) injected into the anterior chamber (AC) at the end of surgery. Post-operative subconjunctival injection can achieve bactericidal levels in the AC for at least 1–2 hours. Preoperative topical fluoroquinolone antibiotics are frequently given in regimens from 1 hour t 3 days before surgery Patients present with ocular pain, diminished vision, circumciliary congestion and hypopyon. The differential diagnosis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes retained lens material in the AC, vitreous hemorrhage, postoperative uveitis and toxic reaction to the use of inappropriate or contaminated irrigating fluid or viscoelastic.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?
options: Bandage and padding of the eye
explanation: A post cataract surgery patient presenting within 36 hours of surgery with inflammation, congestion and hypopyon as seen in the image, is suggestive of acute bacterial endophthalmitis. The treatment of acute bacterial endophthalmitis is intravitreal antibiotics. Endophthalmitis is an intraocular inflammation affecting the inner structures of the eyeball. Acute postoperative bacterial endophthalmitis occurs within 1-7 days after cataract surgery and the most important factor to prevent it is preoperative administration of 5% povidone iodine. The cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid, and a decrease in vision. The patient classically shows inflammation of the eye, corneal edema and a hypopyon due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber. Once the endophthalmitis sets in it is important to treat all the cases empirically with a combination of antibiotics and steroids from the beginning. The various drugs, routes and surgical management used to treat endophthalmitis are as follows: The mainstay of treatment is intravitreal injections of antibiotics. First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus ceftazidime 2.25mg in 0.1ml. Second choice:Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus amikacin 0.4mg in 0.1ml. If there is no improvement, a repeat intravitreal injection should be given after 48 hours Topical antibiotics are started immediately and used frequently. Vancomycin (50mg/ml) or cefazolin (50mg/ml) Amikacin (20mg/ml) or tobramycin Systemic antibiotics have a limited role in the treatment but are commonly used in practice. Steroid therapy includes: Intravitreal injection of dexamethasone (0.4mg in 0.1ml) which is started along with antibiotics. Topical dexamethasone (0.1%) Oral steroids such as prednisolone are started after 24 hours of intensive antibiotic therapy. Supportive therapy includes: Cycloplegics such as atropine 1% Anti-glaucoma drugs such as oral acetazolamide or timolol in patients with raised intraocular pressure Pars plana vitrectomy is done if the patient does not improve with the above therapy in 48-72 hours or when the visual acuity is reduced to hand movements near the eye Other options: Option A: Steroids are given in endophthalmitis to reduce the inflammation of the tissues. The preferred route of administration is either by intravitreal injections, topical concentrations or oral route. Intravenous route (option A) of administration of steroids is not used in endophthalmitis. Option B: Systemic administration (intravenous) of antibiotics have a limited role in the treatment but are commonly used in practice as an add on.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery, supported with the image of vacoulated clusters seen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig’s pearls. It is a type of after cataract. After cataract, or secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification, is a late postoperative complication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. It is the most common late postoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation of left out anterior epithelial cells. Different types of after cataract include: Elschnig’s pearls: The subcapsular epithelial cells proliferate and develop into vacuolated soap bubble like clusters along the posterior capsule. Soemmering’s ring: A peripheral dense ring is formed behind the iris and is enclosed between layers of the capsule. Dense membranous after-cataract: It is formed in the pupillary area impairing the vision. Thin membranous after-cataract: It is thickened posterior capsule. Treatment of after cataract is by Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy of the posterior capsule, which works on the principle of photodisruption, or surgical posterior capsulotomy. Option B: Irvine–Gass syndrome is cystoid macular edema (CME) that develops in post-cataract surgery patients. Though it is mostly clinically insignificant, some cases can present with blurring of vision, one to three months after surgery. In CME, on fundoscopy a honeycomb appearance and on fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image depicts the flower petal pattern seen on FFA. Option C: Post operative endophthalmitis presents as ocular pain, diminished vision and hypopyon within months to years after the surgery. Fungal endophthalmitis can rarely occur with puff ball exudates in the vitreous cavity. Option D: UGH syndrome is where uveitis, glaucoma and hyphema occurs simultaneously. It is seen commonly with rigid anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the treatment of choice for after cataract?
explanation: Nd:YAG laser is the treatment of choice for after cataract. Thin membranous after-cataract, thickened posterior capsule and Elschnig's pearls are treated with Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy. Dense membranous after-cataract requires capsulotomy using a vitreous cutter. Sommering's ring, if the central posterior capsule is clear, requires no treatment. Other options: Option A: Intra-capsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is currently used for the treatment of markedly subluxated and dislocated lens. Option B: Intravitreal steroids may be used for the treatment of acute endophthalmitis, an early postoperative complication of cataract surgery. Option C: Anterior vitrectomy is performed for the treatment of cystoid macular edema with vitreous incarceration. This is a late post-cataract surgery complication.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the cause of late-onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery?
explanation: Late-onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery is caused by Propionibacterium acnes. Late or delayed-onset endophthalmitis following cataract surgery develops when an organism of low virulence such as P. acnes, becomes trapped within the capsular bag (saccular endophthalmitis). Organisms can become sequestered within macrophages, protected from eradication but with continued expression of bacterial antigens. Patients present with symptoms between 4 weeks to years (mean 9 months) postoperatively following an uneventful cataract surgery.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An elderly male residing in an old-age home is brought to the hospital with senile cataracts in both eyes. He says he had difficulty in seeing objects for a few years, but never went to the clinic. He is posted for surgery in 3 weeks. Which of the following is a complication is he unlikely to develop in the 3 weeks until his surgery?
explanation: Hypopyon is not a complication of senile cataracts. Hypermature, or senile cataracts, can lead to the following complications. Phacoanaphylactic uveitis: The lens proteins may leak into the anterior chamber. They may act as an antigen and induce antigen–antibody reaction, leading to phacoanaphylactic uveitis. Lens-induced glaucoma: Phacomorphic glaucoma: Most common, seen in intumescent cataract. The lens swells and causes secondary angle closure glaucoma. Phacolytic glaucoma: Seen in hypermature cataract. The leaked lens proteins are engulfed by macrophages, which clog the trabecular meshwork and cause secondary open-angle glaucoma. Phacotopic glaucoma: Seen in hypermature cataract. The lens may subluxate or dislocate and block the angle of the anterior chamber. Subluxation or dislocation of the lens: It may occur due to degeneration of zonules in the hypermature stage.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the best irrigating fluid for cataract surgery?
explanation: The best irrigating fluid for cataract surgery is balanced salt solution plus glutathione (BSS plus). In the early days of phacoemulsification, the only irrigating solutions available were normal saline, plasmalyte, and lactated Ringer’s solution. Their main adverse effects were endothelial cell toxicity. The buffer in BSS Plus is bicarbonate, which is an improvement over the sodium acetate and citrate buffers in BSS.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: How many weeks following surgery are spectacles prescribed?
explanation: Spectacles are prescribed 6 weeks after cataract surgery after the course of steroids is over. It is the time required for the incison to heal. Then visual acuity is checked and glasses are prescribed.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 72-year-old diabetic who underwent uncomplicated cataract extraction with PCIOL implant 15 days back presents with painless, decreased vision in the operated eye. His visual acuity is 6/12 and does not improve with a pinhole. On examination, the anterior chamber is deep, and PCIOL is well-centered in the capsular bag. Dilated fundus exam reveals clear media, and optic nerve with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.4, a few peripheral microaneurysms, and a dull foveal reflex. The rest of the fundus exam is unremarkable. Which test would be of least benefit?
explanation: In the above case scenario, gonioscopy would be the least helpful. A painless decrease in vision after cataract surgery could be due to: Posterior capsular opacification (most commonly, after 1-3 months) Cystoid macular edema (early) Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (delayed) In the given question, the media is clear (rules out posterior capsular opacification). Also, there are no symptoms nor signs of retinal detachment (RD), hence it is ruled out. Decreased vision not improving with a pinhole in the presence of clear media is attributable to macular pathology. Also, there is a dull foveal reflex. The diagnosis in this patient is cystoid macular edema (CME). The incidence of clinical CME is about 1% to 2% following uncomplicated cataract surgeries. The incidence of angiographic evidence of CME is 10 times greater at around 10% to 20%. Optical coherence tomography (option A) is useful in identifying cystoid macular edema and evaluating the vitreomacular interface. It is also useful in the measurement of retinal thickening, thus allowing the assessment of the therapeutic response. On fluorescein angiography (option B), the classic petaloid leakage in the fovea is seen in the case of CME. Amsler’s grid (option D) is a macular function test. Hence, the least useful in this scenario is gonioscopy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Two months after undergoing cataract surgery, a 45-year-old man is found to have after cataract. He is planned for an Nd:YAG laser posterior capsulotomy. What is the principle behind the use of this laser?
explanation: The principle of the Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm) is photodisruption. Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy is used for treatment of thin membranous after-cataract, posterior capsular opacification and Elschnig's pearls. The plasma produced at the laser target expands and disrupts the tissues, creating an opening. Double frequency Nd:YAG laser is used in posterior segment photocoagulation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following complaints in a patient presenting to your OPD would prompt you to perform a Fincham's test?
explanation: Fincham's test is used to distinguish whether the colored halos are due to cataract or glaucoma. Colored halos are rainbow-colored rings seen around lights at nighttime. It may be caused by cataracts, acute congestive glaucoma and mucopurulent conjunctivitis. These conditions lead to prismatic disruption of light.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: As part of the pre-operative evaluation of a patient posted for cataract surgery, you are asked to calculate the power of the IOL to be implanted. What investigation do you perform?
explanation: The power of the intraocular lens (IOL) to be implanted after cataract surgery is calculated by a biometer and the procedure is termed as biometry. Biometry consists of keratometry and axial length measurement. The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called modified Sanders–Retzlaff– Kraff (SRK) formula, which is given below: E = A - 2.5L - 0.9K Where, E is the emmetropic power designated for the eye A is a predetermined constant, which is specific for each intraocular lens type L is the axial length of the eyeball in millimeter, determined by using the "A" scan ultrasonography K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry. The image given below shows a biometer.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In the SRK formula for intraocular lens power calculation 'E=A-2.5L-0.9K', the value of L is estimated using
explanation: In the SRK formula, the value of L is calculated using the A-scan ultrasonographic biometry. The most widely used formula for intraocular lens power calculation is the modified Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff (SRK) formula, given by: E = A - 2.5L - 0.9K Where, E: Emmetropic power designated for the eye A: Predetermine constant which is specific for each intraocular lens type. L: Axial length of eyeball in millimeters, determined using the A scan ultrasonography. K: Average corneal curvature determined by keratometry. Given below is an image of A scan ultrasonography.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is a rigid intraocular lens made of?
explanation: Rigid IOLs are made of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA). Depending on the type of material of manufacturing, 3 types of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOLs) are available: Rigid IOLs are made entirely from polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA). Foldable IOLs are made of silicone, hydrogel, acrylic, and Collamer. These are implanted through a small incision. Rollable IOLs are ultra-thin IOLs made of acyrlic or hydrogel. These are implanted through a 1-mm incision after micro-incision cataract surgery technique.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient, on follow-up after cataract surgery, has the lens shown below. What is the type of lens implanted in the patient?
options: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL
explanation: The image depicts Singh and Worst’s iris claw lens. This lens is an iris-supported lens, which is fixed with the help of sutures, loops or claws. They are associated with a high incidence of postoperative complications and are thus only used if posterior chamber IOLs cannot be implanted. Note: Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL) is the most commonly used ACIOL. Anterior chamber IOLs lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported in the angle of the anterior chamber. These are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy. Thus, they are currently used only for correction of aphakia in cases where posterior chamber IOLs cannot be used (eg: rupture of posterior capsule).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An 80-year-old man is posted for cataract surgery. The given lens is chosen to be used for implantation. Identify the lens.
options: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL
Singh and Worst's iris claw lens
explanation: The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL). A PCIOL rests entirely behind the iris. They may be supported and fixed by capsular bag fixation of PCIOL (most ideal method), ciliary sulcus fixation or scleral fixation. The PCIOL consists of a central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic and the peripheral arms used for placement and stabilization called the haptics.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
Identify the intraocular lens shown below.

Kelman’s AC-IOL
explanation: The given image is of a toric IOL used to correct pre-existing astigmatism. The dotted markings on the optic of the IOL indicate the axis of IOL, and it is aligned to coincide with the steep axis of the patient’s eye. F r every, one degree of misalignment, about 3 percent of the lens cylinder power is lost. Glaucoma

question_text: What is the normal aqueous production rate?
explanation: The rate of formation of aqueous humor is 2-3 L/min. F rmation of aqueous humor involves the following: Ultrafiltration Secretion- Na/K ATPase of non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary process Diffusion
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the critical angle of the air-cornea interface?
explanation: The critical angle of the air–cornea interface is 46°. Gonioscopy is a method of evaluating the anterior chamber (AC) angle. Direct goniolenses include the Koeppe, Medical Workshop, Barkan, and Swan–Jacob. Indirect goniolenses include Goldmann, Zeiss, and Posner. Structures seen on gonioscopy from anterior to posterior are: Schwalbe line: represents the posterior limit of Descemet's membrane Trabecular meshwork Scleral spur Ciliary body and root of the iris Shaffers grading of angle width: Grade 4 (35–45°) is the widest angle, characteristic of myopia and pseudophakia; the ciliary body can be visualized without tilting the lens. Grade 3 (25–35°) is an open-angle in which the scleral spur is visible. Grade 2 (20°) is an angle in which the trabeculum but not the scleral spur can be seen. Grade 1 (10°) is a very narrow-angle in which only the Schwalbe line, and perhaps the top of the trabeculum, can be identified. A slit angle is one in which there is no obvious iridocorneal contact but no angle structures can be identified. Grade 0 (0°) is closed due to iridocorneal contact.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which statement regarding the depth of the anterior chamber is false?
options: Depth is less in women than men
explanation: The depth of the anterior chamber decreases with age. Anterior chamber depth The anterior chamber is shallow in very young and in old age. At other periods of life, it is normally about 2.5 mm deep. Depth is less in women than in men. Depth is more in myopes. Depth is less in hypermetropia and in angle-closure glaucoma
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of an infant with large corneas, lacrimation and photophobia supported with the image is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) also known as developmental glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure(IOP) which results from the developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. It can be classified as: True congenital or newborn glaucoma in which IOP is elevated during intrauterine life and the baby is born with ocular enlargement. Infantile glaucoma: which manifests prior to age 3 years. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age. Clinical findings include: Blepharospasm Buphthalmos: Large eyeball due to stretching of the globe from elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years. Corneal enlargement: Corneal haze is due to corneal edema. Blue sclera - due to the shining of the underlying uveal tissue through the thinned-out sclera Haab striae are healed breaks in Descemet's membrane Treatment: Goniotomy - when the angle of the anterior chamber is visible through the clear cornea. Trabeculectomy when the corneal clouding prevents visualization of the angle. Filtration procedures such as Trabeculectomy or combined trabeculectomy with trabeculectomy if the above procedures fail. Glaucoma drainage devices in unresponsive cases. Other options: Option A: Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood that is seen between 1-2 years. Findings of Retinoblastoma include: Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex)- the most common manifestation Strabismus Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma An endophytic tumor grows into the vitreous as a white mass that may ‘seed’ into the gel. If calcification is present it gives a "cottage cheese appearance". An exophytic tumor grows outwards and causes overlying exudative retinal detachment. The image below shows the leucocoria of the left eye. Option C: Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy (CHED) is an inherited corneal dystrophy that manifests since birth with endothelial degeneration. It appears as diffuse bilateral corneal edema in the absence of elevated IOP. The clinical features of the disease include corneal clouding, visual impairment, and nystagmus. Option D: Megalocornea is a bilateral non-progressive X-linked condition that most commonly affects males. In this condition, the horizontal corneal diameter is 12mm(<2 years) and is 13 mm(>2 years). It is characterized by a clear cornea, normal corneal thickness, and no breaks in the descemet's membrane. Systemic associations of Megalocornea include Marfan's syndrome, Apert syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos, and Down syndrome.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A neonate is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and clear but large cornea. Investigation reveals Haab’s striae seen in the eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This neonate with complaints of photophobia and watering with large cornea and Haab's striae is suggestive of buphthalmos. Haab’s striae are horizontal/circumferential breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in buphthalmos. Buphthalmos (Bull-like eyes) is an enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years. The image given below shows Haab's striae and a child having buphthalmos in congenital glaucoma. Note: Vogt's striae are vertical, fine, whitish lines (folds/tears) in Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus. The image given below shows Vogt's striae.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient presents to the clinic for a change of her presbyopic glasses. This is the third time that she is coming in 2 months. What is the likely underlying diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: Frequent changes in presbyopic glasses in this patient is a symptom of open-angle glaucoma (OAG). This is due to increasing accommodative failure as a result of constant pressure on the ciliary muscle and nerve supply. In intumescent cataracts, patients report difficulty with distance vision and frequent change of spectacle prescription. However, it is not associated with frequent changes of presbyopic glasses.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Normal cup-to-disc ratio is up to .
explanation: Normal cup-to-disc ratio is up to 0.6. Although the average cup-to-disc ratio is around 0.3 to 0.4, a ratio of up to 0.6 may be found in healthy individuals. This larger ratio is frequently seen in cases of large discs, myopic discs or physiological cupping. A cup-to-disc ratio of > 0.6 is suggestive of glaucoma.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 61-year-old man, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus, presents with headache and eye pain. He also reports difficulty with driving at night. Examination showed a laminar dot sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient with headache and eye pain along with the finding of a laminar dot sign is suggestive of glaucoma. The laminar dot sign is an advanced glaucomatous change in the optic disc. This occurs because the pores in the lamina cribrosa are slit-shaped and are visible up to the margin of the disc. Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc Early glaucomatous changes: Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin Large cup - 0.7 or more Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant Vertically oval cup Advanced glaucomatous changes: Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping) Thinning of neuroretinal rim Bayonetting sign - Sharp angulation of vessel at the margin of the excavated cup Laminar dot sign
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the last visual field to be affected in glaucoma?
explanation: The temporal visual field is the last field to be affected in glaucoma. The pattern of visual field progression in glaucoma from early to severe is predictable in light of the pattern of thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer, which usually begins with the superior and inferior arcuate fibers, then the papillomacular bundle and finally, the nasal fibers. Since the nasal fibers are the last to be involved, the temporal field is the last to be affected in glaucoma.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is a late visual field defect in open-angle glaucoma?
explanation: Bjerrum scotoma (arcuate) is a late and clinically significant visual field defect. Progression of visual field changes seen in glaucoma: Early non-specific changes Isopter contractionBaringof a blind spot:Exclusion of blind spot from the central field Early significant changes Peripheral nasal step(may be early or late)Paracentral scot omain Bjerrum's area.Siedel’ s scotoma:Paracentral scoto ma joins the blind spot Late significant changes ArcuateorBjerrum scotomaRi ngorDoublearcuate scotoma: When 2 arcuate scotomas joi n togetherRoenne’s central n asal step Early non-specific changes Isopter contractionBaringof a blind spot:Exclusion of blind spot from the central field Early non-specific changes Isopter contractionBaringof a blind spot:Exclusion of blind spot from the central field Advanced glaucomatous field defects Tubular visionNo light perce ption: Complete visual field d efect.
