question_text: A 70-year-old patient presents with progressive deterioration of vision. The pupillary reaction is sluggish and the IOP is elevated. Fundoscopy shows a large and deep cup and the visual field reveals paracentral scotoma. What is the first line of treatment for this diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of deterioration of vision, sluggish pupils, elevated IOP and paracentral scotoma is suggestive of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). Timolol is one of the first-line agents used in the treatment of primary open-angle glaucoma. First-line agents for the treatment of glaucoma are: Prostaglandin analogs such as latanoprost and bimatoprost Topical beta-blockers such as timolol, betaxolol, and levobunolol Selective alpha 2 adrenergic agonist brimonidine Adjunctive therapy: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors Laser trabeculoplasty: In cases where intraocular pressure (IOP) is uncontrolled despite maximal tolerated medical therapy. Note: Since prostaglandin (PG) analogs are not included in the options, the next best option to choose is timolol. Historically, beta-blockers were the most common first-line agents used in the medical treatment of POAG. However, with an increase in our experience with newer agents, specifically the prostaglandin analogues that facilitate outflow, they were recognized as being more efficacious in lowering IOP and systemically safer than beta-blockers. As a result, now they are the first-line agents in glaucoma treatment.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient with a known case of MI on aspirin comes with shortness of breath. She has an active history of asthma and uses inhalational bronchodilators, her last attack was 7 months ago. She was recently prescribed medications for increased intraocular pressure. What is the likely cause of her current symptoms?
explanation: This patient with a history of asthma now presenting with shortness of breath after starting medications for increased intraocular pressure was most likely diagnosed with glaucoma. The drug she was likely prescribed was timolol, a non-selective beta blocker. Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used in glaucoma. Non-selective beta-blockers can cause precipitation of bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals (beta-2 block on bronchi). They cause bronchospasms and are therefore contraindicated in patients with asthma (e.g. timolol, levobunolol). Ocular beta-blockers reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation by blockade of 2 receptors. Timolol is specifically associated with allergic blepharoconjunctivitis and punctal stenosis Side effects: Systemic: Bronchospasm, bradycardia, decreased cardiac output, hypotension, depression, impotence, and altered lipid profile. Contraindications: Asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, congestive heart failure, sinus bradycardia, and atrioventricular blocks Other options: Option A: The patient has been stable on aspirin for the past three years which is unlikely to be the cause of her current symptoms. Option B: Betaxolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma. Option C: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF2 alpha) analog and does not precipitate bronchial asthma.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: As a first-year ophthalmology resident, you have been referred a case of glaucoma. He complaints that his current medication is causing excessive drowsiness and is interfering with his work. Which of the following anti-glaucoma medications can cause drowsiness?
explanation: Brimonidine is an anti-glaucoma medication that can cause drowsiness. It is a selective alpha-2 agonist. It can cross the blood-brain barrier and, hence, causes drowsiness and CNS depression; it is contraindicated in infants and children. A new class of glaucoma drugs, Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors, promises to act specifically on the trabecular meshwork, a main outflow and blockage site in glaucoma. ROCK inhibitors are not yet approved and available for glaucoma patients. Two US companies, Aerie and Altheos, are currently in early clinical research development with topical ROCK inhibitors to lower IOP.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 55-year-old female, who is a known case of sickle cell anemia, comes to the casualty with a history of severe eye pain, redness, and diminution of vision. On examination, the visual acuity is 6/60, and there is circumcorneal congestion, corneal edema, and a shallow anterior chamber. What is the drug of choice from the given options?
explanation: This patient with complaints of severe headache, corneal congestion, and edema with a shallow anterior chamber most likely has acute angle closure glaucoma. Since this patient has a past history of sickle cell disease, intravenous mannitol is the drug of choice for this patient Acetazolamide is contraindicated in cases of sickle-cell anemia since these drugs tend to increase sickling of erythrocytes.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 50-year-old female presents with an acute painful red-eye. An image of her eye is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario, supported with the image of the mid-dilated and vertically oval pupil is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. The pupil is non-reactive to both light and accommodation. Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma refers to the occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris (iridotrabecular contact [ITC]), obstructing aqueous outflow. Angle closure can be primary, when it occurs in an anatomically predisposed eye or secondary to another ocular or systemic factor. Classification: Symptoms: Pain, redness, photophobia, impaired vision, watering Signs: Corneal edema- colored halos Conjunctiva- congestion, chemosis IOP- elevated 40–70 mm Hg AC very shallow Pupil- vertically oval, mid-dilated Angle- completely closed, Grade 0 Treatment: Immediate- Intravenous mannitol, intravenous acetazolamide followed by oral dose, topical beta-blockers, brimonidine, latanoprost Definitive- Laser peripheral iridotomy, filtration surgery Primary angle-closure suspec t (PACS) Gonioscopy shows posterior meshwork ITC in three or mo re quadrants but no peripher al anterior synechiae (PAS).I ntraocular pressure (IOP), op tic disc, and visual field are n ormal.No PAS are seenThe ri sk of PACG at 5 years may be around 30%. Primary angle closure (PAC) Gonioscopy shows three or m ore quadrants of ITC with rai sed IOP and/or PAS or excess ive pigment smudging on the TM.Normal optic disc and fi eld. Primary angle-closure glauco ma (PACG) ITC in three or more quadra nts, with glaucomatous optic neuropathy.Optic nerve dam age from an episode of severe IOP elevation, such as acute angle closure, may not appea r as typical glaucomatous cup ping.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman develops pain in the eye after dark-room/prone-provocative test. Which of the following drugs should be avoided?
explanation: Pain after dark-room prone-provocative test indicates occludable angles. Hence, atropine is contraindicated as it is a long-acting mydriatic and can precipitate angle closure. Dark-room/prone-provocative test (DRPPT)- The patient sits in a dark room, face down for one hour without sleeping (sleep induces miosis). The intraocular pressure (IOP) is checked (immediately after the test, as IOP can normalize very rapidly), and an IOP rise of 8 mmHg or more is frequently considered significant.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A young female presents with sudden onset severe pain in the left eye after watching a movie. She rushes to the hospital as there is a progressive loss of vision. She has ciliary injection and a shallow anterior chamber. The pupil is semi dilated and the cornea appears oedematous.
What is the procedure of choice for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of sudden onset severe pain in the eye, progressive loss of vision, shallow anterior chamber, semi-dilated pupil, and edematous cornea is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Laser iridotomy is the procedure of choice especially in emergency situations. The attack may have been precipitated by pupillary dilation, which may result from activities such as going to a movie theater. Laser iridotomy re-establishes the communication between the posterior and anterior chamber, bypassing the pupillary block; hence, it immediately relieves crowding of the angle. Various surgical and laser modalities used in glaucoma: Angle-closure glaucoma: Laser iridotomy by Nd:Yag along with prophylactic iridotomy of the other eye  Treatment of choice. Trabeculectomy  Filtration surgery Congenital glaucoma: Goniotomy Trabeculotomy Primary open-angle glaucoma: Laser trabeculoplasty: Argon or diode (if not controlled medications) Trabeculectomy: Filtration surgery (if not controlled medications) Absolute glaucoma: Cyclocryotherapy Nd:Yag lasercyclo destruction
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. Identify the device.
explanation: The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is an ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt). It is a form of minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage. Ex-PRESS glaucoma implant is a small stainless steel device. It is inserted under a scleral flap during a modified trabeculectomy. Complications such as hypotony are lower than with standard trabeculectomy. Glaucoma drainage devices are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. While these devices were traditionally reserved for high-risk patients, or after trabeculectomy had failed, they are becoming increasingly popular. The commonly used devices are as follows: Shunts using episcleral explants Ahmed glaucoma valve: Silicone Molteno implant - Polypropylene plate and silicone plate Baerveldt implant - Silicone Mini-shunts Ex-Press™ Mini-Shunt: Stainless steel iStent® - Titanium
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is Glaukomflecken?
explanation: Glaukomflecken is anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity and a component of Vogt's triad seen in patients after an acute angle closure glaucoma attack. The Vogt's triad comprises of: Glaukomflecken Patches of iris atrophy Slightly dilated nonreactive pupil
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 25-year-old patient presents with painless white eye with an intraocular pressure of 60 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario fits the description of glaucomatocyclitic crisis. Glaucomatocyclitic crisis/Posner–Schlossman Syndrome [PSS]) describes recurrent attacks of unilateral acute raised intraocular pressure (IOP) associated with mild anterior uveitis. The mechanism is thought to be acute trabeculitis, and there is evidence that infection, possibly cytomegalovirus (CMV) or Helicobacter pylori, may play a role. PSS typically affects young to middle-aged adults. Males are affected more frequently than females. Signs: Slit-lamp biomicroscopy typically shows a few anterior chamber cells and one to several fine white central keratic precipitates. Mydriasis is common; posterior synechiae are not a feature. IOP is typically raised to over 40 mmHg, out of proportion to iritis severity. Gonioscopy shows an open-angle. Treatment: Topical steroids are used to control inflammation, with aqueous suppressants to lower the IOP. Topical or oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents may also be beneficial. Note: In PSS, the rise in IOP is out of proportion to the pain felt. There is often a mild discomfort and pain may even be absent.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An ophthalmologist evaluating a patient with glaucoma identifies the following finding on slit-lamp examination. What is the finding?
explanation: The given image shows a pattern of the deposition of pigments on the back of the cornea in pigmentary glaucoma. They are called Krukenberg spindles. Pigmentary glaucoma is an open-angle glaucoma having the following features: Krukenberg spindles Gonioscopy shows pigment accumulation along the Schwalbe line inferiorly, and this accumulation is called the Sampaolesi line. Radial transillumination defect in the iris is a pathognomonic feature. Pigment granules may be deposited on the anterior surface. There may be a Scheie line or Zentmayer ring of pigment on the peripheral/equatorial surface around the zonular insertions. Other options: Option A: Ferry line: Corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of filtering blebs of glaucoma surgery Option B: Fleischer line/ring: Epithelial iron deposits at the base of the cone in keratoconus Option C: Hudson–Stahli line: Iron deposition line in the corneal epithelium, which is commonly seen in the junction between middle and lower third cornea. This finding is mainly age-related.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Malignant glaucoma is seen in .
explanation: Malignant glaucoma is seen after intra-ocular surgery (usually after trabeculectomy). Ciliary block glaucoma is also called malignant glaucoma/inverse glaucoma. It can be seen after any intraocular surgery. Forward flow of the aqueous is blocked as tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against the lens/intraocular lens (IOL)/anterior hyaloid of the vitreous. Hence, aqueous humor starts collecting in the vitreous cavity. Signs: High intraocular pressure (IOP) and absent bleb. Negative Seidel test. Shallow anterior chamber (AC) Treatment: Initial treatment is with cycloplegics (atropine 1%) to dilate the ciliary ring and push the vitreous-lens-iris posteriorly. Subsequent treatment if medical therapy fails is with Nd:YAG laser hyaloidotomy. Pars plana vitrectomy can be considered in conditions that don't respond to the above treatment modalities.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is iridocorneal endothelial syndrome associated with?
options: Progressive atrophy of the iris stroma
Bilateral stromal edema of the iris
Deposition of glycosaminoglycans in Descemet's membrane
explanation: Progressive atrophy of iris stroma is a clinical entity of iridocorneal endothelial syndrome (ICE). ICE syndrome is a proliferative endotheliopathy, which leads to secondary angle-closure glaucoma. It includes three clinical entities: Progressive iris atrophy Chandler’s syndrome - corneal edema Cogan–Reese syndrome - nodules and nevus on the iris; hence, it is known as iris nevus syndrome.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is seen in hypersecretory glaucoma?
explanation: Hypersecretory glaucoma is associated with epidemic dropsy. Epidemic dropsy occurs due to Argemone mexicana poisoning. Here, glaucoma is due to excessive production of aqueous humor.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following conditions?
explanation: 100-day glaucoma is a neovascular glaucoma that occurs in ischemic type of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). It is known as 100-day glaucoma because it occurs 3 months after the episode of CRVO. Although neovascular glaucoma occurs as a complication in Eale's disease (Option B) and central retinal artery occlusion (Option C) and long-term use of topical steroid therapy causes steroid-induced glaucoma (Option D) none of them are termed as 100-day glaucoma. CRVO is further classified into two types: Non-ischemic CRVO: occurs secondary to venous stasis.It is the most common type of CRVO of the two. Ischemic CRVO: occurs due to acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It is also termed as hemorrhagic retinopathy. Ischemic CRVO presents with sudden loss of vision and Relative afferent pupil defect(RAPD). Fundus examination shows massive enlargement of retinal veins and massive retinal hemorrhages giving a "splashed tomato appearance". Other findings include cotton wool spots, optic disc edema and neovascularization at the disc and in the periphery. Pathagnomic features of ischemic CRVO that differentiates it from non-ischemic CRVO are: RAPD Reduced amplitude of B-wave on electroretinogram Visual field defects Complications of the disease: Neovascular Glaucoma known as 100 day glaucoma Neovascularisation of iris known as Rubeosis iridis Vitreous hemorrhage Proliferative retinopathy The below-given fundus image is of the "splashed tomato" appearance of CRVO. Option B: Eales disease is an idiopathic inflammatory disease of the peripheral retinal veins.It is considered to be a hypersensitivity reaction to the tubercular proteins and it is commonly seen in young males. It is characterized by recurrent vitreous hemorrhage. Complications include: Neovascular glaucoma Proliferative vitreoretinopathy Tractional retinal detachment, Rubeosis iridis Option C: Central retinal artery occlusion(CRAO) is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. It presents as sudden painless loss of vision and amaurosis fugax (transient monocular blindness that is due to ischemia). Fundus examination shows an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot. Neovascular glaucoma may occur as a delayed complication of CRAO but it is not termed as 100 day glaucoma. The below image depicts the fundus image seen in CRAO with the cherry red spot. Option D:Steroid induced glaucoma is a type of secondary open angle glaucoma that usually follows weeks-months of topical steroid therapy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the progression of ocular hypertension to primary open-angle glaucoma?
options: Reducing IOP is effective in delaying the onset of POAG
Thin cornea is a risk factor for POAG development
Family history is not a risk factor for POAG development
Increased cup disc ratio is a risk factor for POAG development
explanation: Family history is a risk factor for the development of primary open-angle glaucoma. Ocular hypertension (OHT) is characterized by only raised intraocular pressure (IOP). Optic disc and normal visual field are normal, with no evidence of angle closure. Risk factors for the progression of ocular hypertension to primary open-angle glaucoma include the following: African American race Thin cornea Increasing age Increased cup-disc rati Increased IOP Family history of POAG
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Identify the instrument given in the image below.
explanation: The given image shows Baerveldt implant which is a glaucoma drainage device (GDD)/seton/aqueous shunt. It consists of a scleral plate that is sutured to the sclera and a tube connecting it into the anterior chamber. It is valveless, and hence, it carries the risk of postoperative hypotony due to excessive aqueous drainage. Glaucoma drainage devices are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing a communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. The glaucoma valve implant is also known as a seton. The commonly used devices are as follows: Shunts using episcleral explants Ahmed glaucoma valve: Silicone Molteno implant- Polypropelene plate and silicone plate Baerveldt implant- Silicone Mini-shunts Ex-Press™ Mini-Shunt: Stainless steel iStent®- Titanium
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the drug of choice for inverse glaucoma?
explanation: The drug of choice for inverse glaucoma is atropine. Inverse glaucoma is a type of secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by the flow of aqueous humour posteriorly to the posterior segment instead of the posterior chamber. The increased pressure in the posterior segment pushes the lens forward leading to the shallowing of the anterior chamber. Miotics are contraindicated as they can cause the ciliary zonules to slack, the lens to move forward and further shallowing of the anterior chamber. So mydriatic and cycloplegic agents such as atropine are administered. Inverse glaucoma is also called: Malignant glaucoma Ciliary block glaucoma Aqueous misdirection. Note: Pilocarpine is the drug of choice in angle-closure glaucoma but is contraindicated in inverse glaucoma. Whereas, atropine is the drug of choice in inverse glaucoma but is contraindicated in angle-closure glaucoma.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An elderly male who is a known case of diabetes presents with blurry vision near the center of his field of vision. He also informs that colours appear washed out or faded. His IOP was found to be elevated. Which of the following drugs should not be used to control IOP in this diabetic patient?
explanation: This diabetic patient with new onset central loss of vision and reports of colors appearing faded or washed out most likely has macular edema. Prostaglandin analogs have a high propensity to cause and further exacerbate cystoid macular edema and hence are not preferred in this patient. Drugs associated with cystoid macular edema (CME): Prostaglandin analogues Epinephrine Dipivefrine (only the non-selective alpha agonists, in aphakic eyes) Tamoxifen Timolol Docetaxel Interferons Fingolimod Thiazolinediones Niacin (pseudo-CME)
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In a 55-year-old patient presenting with secondary open-angle glaucoma, what is the most likely etiology?
explanation: Pseudoexfoliation (PEX) syndrome is the most likely cause of secondary open-angle glaucoma. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an ocular manifestation of an age-related systemic disorder of the extracellular matrix, characterized by the production and progressive accumulation of fibrillar extracellular material in many ocular and systemic tissues. The clinical hallmark of PEX syndrome is the deposition of whitish abnormal pseudoexfoliative debris on the anterior lens capsule. A deposition is also noted on: Zonules (causing zonulolysis and phacodonesis, lens subluxation) Pupillary margin Trabecular meshwork (causing the secondary open-angle glaucoma)
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following drugs increases the uveoscleral outflow?
explanation: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug, which acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow and thereby lowers the intraocular pressure. Mechanism of action: Latanoprost is a prodrug and gets activated during its passage through the cornea. It acts by stimulating the prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles. This leads to the release of matrix metalloproteinases, which increases the uveoscleral outflow.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: True regarding POAG:
explanation: In primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), family members are likely to develop steroid responsiveness (statement B) and visual field defect can exist with a normal C:D ratio (statement E). Statement A: Gonioscopy cannot visualize the specific abnormalities that occur in the trabecular meshwork in POAG. Gonioscopy diagnoses POAG because of the visibility of all the structures of the angle of the anterior chamber in contrast to the non-visibility of different structures in angle closure glaucoma. Statement C: Primary angle-closure glaucoma is associated with exacerbation of IOP with pupillary dilatation and not POAG. Statement D: There is a 10% increased risk of POAG in siblings and a 4% increased risk in children of patients with POAG. POAG also known as chronic simple glaucoma of adult-onset is characterized by the presence of any 2 of the following 3 categories of changes: Increased intraocular pressure: IOP >21mmHg on more than one occasion, and/or Circadian variation in IOP of >8 mmHg, or Asymmetry in IOP > 5 mmHg between both eyes Optic nerve head changes suggestive of glaucomatous damage. These may include one or more f the following changes: Vertically oval cup Cup-disc (C:D) ratio > 0.6 (average cup: disc ratio 0.3-0.4) Asymmetry in C:D ratio > 0.2 between both eyes. Narrowing, notching, or pallor of the neuroretinal rim. Disc haemorrhages Nasal shifting of retinal vessels-Bayonetting sign Lamellar dot sign Visual field changes - isopter contraction, barring of blind spot, paracentral scotoma, Seidel's scotoma, Bjerrum's scotoma, double arcuate scotoma, and Roenne's central nasal step. A patient presenting with just raised IOP and visual field defects with normal optic nerve head findings such as a normal C:D ratio can still be diagnosed as POAG (statement E).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 48-year-old lady was started on an ocular medication that she was instructed to take daily. She develops redness of the eye. Examination reveals a colour change of the iris and orbital fat atrophy. Which of the following medications was she likely prescribed?
explanation: The given clinical history of a patient that has iris pigmentation and redness of the eye, was most likely started on latanoprost. Drug Side Effects Latanopr ost Allergic conjunctival hypere mia, permanent increase in ir is pigmentation, orbital fat at rophy. Timolol Exacerbation of asthma and c hronic obstructive pulmonar y disease, bradycardia, depre ssion, impotence Scopola mine Photosensitivity, blurred visi on Pilocarpi ne Corneal edema, miosis, induc ed myopia, decreased vision, brow ache, retinal detachmen t
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: First drug to be given in acute angle-closure glaucoma is .
explanation: The first drug to be given in acute angle-closure glaucoma is oral acetazolamide or intravenous mannitol. Acetazolamide reduces IOP by decreasing the production of aqueous. The definitive drug is pilocarpine as it constricts the pupil and breaks the attack. Finally, when the corneal edema resolves, the patient has to undergo laser iridotomy to prevent such attacks in the future. So, laser iridotomy is the definitive management for acute angle-closure glaucoma.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
The normal extent of the visual field superiorly is .
60°
explanation: The extent of visual field superiorly is 50° Normal extent of the visual field: Temporal: 90°/100° Inferiorly: 70° Nasal: 60° Superiorly: 50° Note: According to Parson's 22nd Ed., Page no. 101, the visual field extends 60o superiorly. However, most journals and other standard textbooks consider the answer to be 50o. Hence, we choose 50o as the most appropriate answer. Uveitis - Anterior and Intermediate
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements are false about the ciliary body?
options: It consists of the pars plana and pars plicata.
Contraction of the ciliary body helps in accommodation.
It derives its blood supply from short posterior ciliary arteries.
explanation: The ciliary body derives its blood supply from the long posterior ciliary artery and anterior ciliary arteries, which form the major arterial circle at the root of the iris. The ciliary body is a triangular structure that begins at the base of the iris and becomes continuous with the choroid at the ora serrata. It is approximately 6–6.5 mm in an anteroposterior dimension. It consists of an anterior portion called the pars plicata and a posterior portion called the pars plana (option A). The pars plicata contains approximately 70 finger-like projections called ciliary processes, which are covered by the ciliary body epithelium. These processes secrete aqueous humor (option C). The pars plana is the flat part of the ciliary body and ends at the ora serrata. The smooth muscle of the ciliary body is divided into three groups of fibers: Outer longitudinal portion that attaches anteriorly to the scleral spur and trabecular meshwork fibers Middle oblique portion Inner circular portion (responsible for accommodation) (option B)
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 3-year-old child with the following finding has high myopia. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows corectopia, an abnormal eccentrically placed pupil. It can be a congenital anomaly or an acquired defect with essential iris atrophy. It may be associated with high myopia or ectopia lentis, among other conditions.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient presents to the casualty after ocular trauma with a D-shaped pupil. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: A D-shaped pupil is seen in iridodialysis. Iridodialysis is the dis-insertion of the iris root from the ciliary body attachment. It may occur following ocular trauma. A red reflex can be obtained from the peripheral gap in the iris. The given image depicts iridodialysis and a D-shaped pupil.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is the pathognomonic sign of acute anterior uveitis?
explanation: The pathognomonic sign of acute anterior uveitis is keratic precipitates (KP). Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular deposits at the back of cornea. The composition of KPs varies with the type of uveitis. Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis: Corneal signs Corneal edema Keratic precipitates (Pathognomonic) Posterior corneal opacity Anterior chamber signs Aqueous cells Aqueous flare (earliest sign) Hypopyon Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae Iris signs Loss of normal pattern Change in color Iris nodules (Koeppe, Busacca) Posterior synechiae Neovascularization Pupillary signs Constricted pupi Irregular pupil shape Ectropion of pupillary margin Occlusion pupillae
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the first sign a patient with anterior uveitis may show?
explanation: Aqueous flare is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis. Aqueous flare is due to the leakage of protein particles into the aqueous humor from damaged blood vessels. It is demonstrated on the slit-lamp examination. It is based on the principle of Brownian movement or Tyndall phenomenon. Aqueous flare is usually marked in non-granulomatous uveitis and minimal in granulomatous uveitis. The presence of cells in the anterior chamber denotes an active inflammatory process. The image below is a high magnification slit-beam photograph 3×1 mm in size in a darkroom showing the presence of cells and flare.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 34-year-old lady presents with eye pain, photophobia, and red-eye. The slit-lamp examination finding is shown below. On which layer of the cornea are these present?
explanation: Eye pain, photophobia and red-eye along with the slit lamp finding of keratic precipitates suggests a diagnosis of acute anterior uveitis. Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular deposits occurring at the back of the corneal endothelium. Keratuc precipitates are arranged in a triangular fashion, occupying the center and inferior parts of the cornea (Arlt's triangle).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: You are evaluating a 45-year-old man admitted for acute anterior uveitis. What is the pupillary shape you expect to find in his eyes?
explanation: The pupil in acute anterior uveitis is constricted (pupillary sphincter spasm), irregular and sluggishly reactive to light In an acute attack of uveitis, the pupil is irregular and narrow due to irritation of sphinchter pupillae. Pupillary signs in chronic anterior uveitis is as follows: Festooned pupil results from the application of mydriatics in segmental posterior synechiae. Occlusio pupillae results when the pupil is completely occluded due to the organization of the exudates across the pupillary area. Seclusio pupillae due to ring synechiae, that prevent the circulation of aqueous humor from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber. The image below shows a festooned pupil.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient with sarcoidosis shows Koeppe's nodules on ophthalmologic examination. Where are these seen?
explanation: Koeppe's nodules and Bussaca's nodules develop on the iris in granulomatous uveitis. Granulomatous uveitis is a chronic proliferative inflammation seen in reponse to tuberculosis, leprosy, syphilis and sarcoidosis. Infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, with proliferation of mononuclear cells leads to the formation of iris nodule. Koeppe's nodules are seen at the pupillary margin. Bussaca's nodules are seen on the peripheral part of the anterior surface of iris.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the type of synechiae formed in iris bombe?
explanation: Iris bombe formation is due to the development of annular or ring synechiae. Annular posterior/ring synechiae are 360° adhesions of the pupillary margin to the anterior capsule of the lens. They prevent the circulation of aqueous humor from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber (seclusio pupillae). Thus, the aqueous collects behind the iris and pushes it anteriorly leading to iris bombe. This is usually followed by a rise in intraocular pressure. The anterior chamber is funnel-shaped when ring synechiae are present. The image below shows iris bombe on slit lamp examination.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 38-year-old woman has been having repeated episodes of red-eye, eye pain, and blurred vision. She is diagnosed with chronic granulomatous uveitis. Which of the following is not a cause?
explanation: Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a type of non-granulomatous uveitis. Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is an insidious progressive anterior uveitis. It is mostly unilateral and associated with early cataract formation. Stellate keratic precipitates are seen and there is a notable absence of posterior synechiae. Causes for chronic granulomatous uveitis include sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, herpes simplex, herpes zoster, syphilis, leprosy, brucellosis and phacoanaphylactic.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Intermediate uveitis is also called as .
explanation: Intermediate uveitis refers to pars planitis. It involves inflammation of the pars plana. The uvea consists of the iris, ciliary body and choroid. Inflammation of uveal tissue is called uveitis. It can be classified anatomically as follows: Anterior uveitis: Inflammation of iris and pars plicata, consisting of iritis, iridocyclitis and anterior cyclitis Intermediate uveitis: Inflammation of pars plana (pars planitis) Posterior uveitis: Inflammation of the retina with or without involvement of the retina. It includes choroiditis, chorioretinitis, retinochoroiditis and neuroretinitis. Panuveitis Pathological classification divides uveitis into suppurative and nonsuppurative uveitis. Nonsuppurative uveitis is further classified into nongranulomatous and granulomatous uveitis. The image is a schematic representation of the anatomical classification of uveitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In a patient with intermediate uveitis, which of the following is a pathognomonic examination finding?
explanation: Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. Snow banking refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or without peripheral retinal periphlebitis. Intermediate uveitis is the inflammation of the pars plana and presents with retrolental flare, few keratic precipitates, vitreous cells and snow-ball opacities (Ant’s egg opacities). These are typical exudates present near the ora serrata in the inferior quadrant. Treatment of intermediate uveitis is by the Kaplan 4-step protocol: Periocular steroid: Sub tenon injection of triamcinolone acetate Systemic steroid Cryotherapy over snow banking Pars plana vitrectomy
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: While studying a cohort of patients with juvenile idiopathic arthritis, you are evaluating the risk of iridocyclitis among the different subtypes of JIA. Which subtype has the highest risk of iridocyclitis associated?
explanation: ANA-positive oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is associated with the highest risk for iridocyclitis (uveitis). A positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test result confers increased risk for uveitis in children with JIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination. Uveitis in JIA is characteristically chronic, non-granulomatous, and bilateral. It presents as a white eye without congestion- white uveitis. Complications include complicated cataracts, secondary glaucoma, and band-shaped keratopathy. Note: Intraocular lens (IOL) implantation can be considered in most pediatric patients with well-controlled uveitis, but JIA-associated uveitis should be considered as a relative contraindication.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Where is Amsler's sign seen?
explanation: Amsler sign is seen in Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI). Amsler sign is the hemorrhage caused by cataract surgery in FHI. During cataract surgery, fine filiform hemorrhages from the opposite angle are seen to occur as soon as the anterior chamber is opened. This is due to neovascularization. Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is an insidiously progressive, non- granulomatous anterior uveitis, that is usually unilateral. Stellate KPs are seen and tiny crystals (Russell bodies) may be present on the iris surface. There are no posterior synechiae. Rubeosis iridis may be present. The 1st image shows Fuchs heterochromic uveitis. The right eye is normal. The left hypochromic eye is affected. The 2nd image shows stellate keratic precipiates.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is Posner-Schlossman syndrome?
options: Ipsilateral optic atrophy with contralateral papilloedemac
Unilateral glaucomatous changes with mild anterior uveitis
explanation: Posner–Schlossman syndrome is characterized by unilateral glaucomatous changes with mild anterior uveitis. This syndrome, also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis or hypertensive uveitis, presents with recurrent unilateral attachs of acute raised intraocular pressure (IOP) (>40 mmHg) changes, fine white central keratic precipitates (KPs) and mydriasis. Treatment includes topical corticosteroids, cycloplegics, and aqueous suppressants.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 44-year-old patient with AIDS and opportunistic infections was started on treatment. He develops a sterile hypopyon anterior uveitis that is suspected to be drug-induced. Which of the following drugs may be implicated here?
explanation: Rifabutin causes uveitis in AIDS patients. Causes of drug-induced uveitis include: Cidofovir Rifabutin Bisphosphonates Oral moxifloxacin
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which among the following is associated with transient hypopyon syndrome?
explanation: Behcet's disease presents with recurrent iridocyclitis associated with transient hypopyon. Behcet's disease is a systemic vascular disease. It is associated with HLA B5 >> B51. Patients have obliterative vasculitis due to circulating immune complexes, leading to a recurrent, bilateral non-granulomatous uveitis. There is acute recurrent iridocyclitis, transient hypopyon, periphlebitis, retinitis, vitritis and cystoid macular edema (CME).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A patient presents with photophobia and blurring of vision. On examination, the eye appears as shown below. What is the mainstay of treatment?

Antibiotics and cycloplegics
explanation: The clinical scenario of photophobia and blurring of vision along with red-eye and irregularly shaped pupil suggests a diagnosis of anterior uveitis. Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of the treatment of uveitis. Steroids are the drug of choice in anterior uveitis. They reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect. Cycloplegics like 1% atropine relieve spasm of the iris sphincter and ciliary muscles. They prevent the formation of synechiae and reduce exudation. Systemic therapy includes steroids, NSAIDs, and immunosuppressants. Immunosuppressants like voclosporin (calcineurin inhibitor) are used in severe cases. They are being studied under a program called LUMINATE. Uveitis - Posterior and Panuveitis
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient describes the image below on the Amsler grid test. In which of the given conditions is this phenomenon noted?
explanation: The image shows metamorphopsia seen in posterior uveitis. Metamorphopsia is a condition in which patients perceive distorted images of the object. It is measured using the Amsler grid, which tests the central 10° of vision. In posterior uveitis, metamorphopsia occurs due to macular edema. Posterior uveitis is a painless inflammation of the choroid. Patients present with various visual symptoms like defective vision, black spots floating in front of the eye, micropsia/macropsia and positive scotomas.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following features is unlikely to be noted in a patient with Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome?
explanation: Iris heterochromia is not a feature of Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome. Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome is an idiopathic, multi-system disorder characterised by autoimmunity against melanocytes. It is associated with HLA-DR1 and HLA-DR4 across different racial groups. Patients may present with cutaneous, neurological and ocular features. Cutaneous features include alopecia, poliosis and vitiligo (option A). Neurological features include meningism, encephalopathy, tinnitus, deafness and vertigo (option B). Ocular features include bilateral chronic granulomatous panuveitis (option C), posterior uveitis, exudative retinal detachment, perilimbal vitiligo (Suguiura's sign) and sunset glow appearance of the fundus. The modified diagnostic criteria for Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome are as follows: Absence of a history of penetrating ocular trauma Absence of other ocular disease entitie Bilateral uveiti Neurological and auditory manifestation Integumentary findings, not preceding the onset of the central nervous system or ocular diseases, such as alopecia, poliosis, and vitiligo. The treatment is high-dose (1–2 mg/kg/day) oral prednisolone, tapered over 3–6 months. This may be preceded by intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy (500–1000 mg/day).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A middle aged male presents with recurrent oral ulcers and ulcers over his scrotum. He also has pain and redness of both his eyes. A positive pathergy test is noted. What is the HLA association of the disease this patient is most likely to be suffering from?
explanation: Recurrent oral ulcers, ulcers over his scrotum with binocular pain and redness and a positive pathergy test point to a diagnosis of Behcet's disease. HLA B5 (HLA B51) is associated with Behcet's disease. Behcet's disease is a systemic vasculitis that can cause recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, skin lesions and ocular inflammation. Pathergy test is usually positive. Ocular inflammation occurs in about 70% of patients and tends to be more severe in men. A classical presentation is relapsing/remitting acute onset panuveitis with retinal vasculitis which resolves spontaneously even without treatment. It is usually bilateral and non-granulomatous. Patients present with a transient mobile hypopyon in a relatively white eye. They may develop visual impairment if retinal vascular disease (vasculitis and occlusion) occurs. Other options: Option A: HLA-B27 is associated with Reiter's syndrome. Option B: HLA DR1 and HLA-DR4 are associated with Vogt–Koyanagi–Haradas disease. Option D: HLA Bw54 is associated with Possner–Scholssman syndrome. Note: The association between HLA-A29 and birdshot retinochoroidopathy is the most consistent of any medical disorder. Approximately 95% of patients with birdshot retinochoroidopathy are HLA-A29–positive.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 28 year old man presents to the medicine OPD with cough with hemoptysis of 1 month duration. A sputum culture done is shown below. What is the most common ocular manifestation associated with this infection?
explanation: The image shows the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) colonies on the Lowenstein-Jensen medium. In tuberculosis (TB), granulomatous panuveitis is the most common ocular feature. Ocular TB commonly occurs due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB. It can have multiple presentations like lupus vulgaris of eyelid, tubercular conjunctivitis, interstitial keratitis, granulomatous uveitis and endophthalmitis. Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the MTB antigen. Treatment of granulomatous panuveitis is anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) plus steroids.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In a patient showing salt and pepper appearance of the fundus, which of the following is not a differential diagnosis?
explanation: Salt and pepper fundus is not seen in tuberculosis. Salt and pepper fundus is seen when there are multiple small black and white spots present on the retina. It is also known as pseudo-retinitis pigmentosa. Its causes include congenital syphilis, rubella, Refsum’s disease, carriers of albinism, Leber’s congenital amaurosis and retinitis pigmentosa sine pigmentosa.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 32-year-old lady presented with dry, itchy eyes, blurred vision, and sensitivity to light. She says there are black dots floating around in her visual field. She denies wearing any spectacles or contact lenses. On fundoscopy, the following image is obtained. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: Dry, itchy eyes, blurred vision, sensitivity to light with candle wax dripping on fundus examination points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a chronic granulomatous multi-system disease. Ocular inflammation occurs in 25–70% of sarcoid patients, which includes uveitis, conjuctival and lacrimal gland involvement. Chronic granulomatous panuveitis may be seen. Anterior uveitis is the most common manifestation. In anterior uveitis due to sarcoidosis, "mutton fat" keratic precipitates (KPs) and/or small granulomatous KPs with iris nodules (Koeppe and/or Busacca) are seen. Trabecular meshwork (TM) nodules and/or tent-shaped peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) is also seen. In intermediate uveitis, vitreous cells with snowbanking and snowball opacities/string of pearl appearance are seen. Posterior uveitis presents with candle-wax dripping (thick venous sheathing and periphlebitis), pre-retinal nodules (Lander’s sign), choroidal granulomata and sarcoid infiltration. Other ocular features seen are interstitial keratitis and band-shaped keratopathy. Steroids are the mainstay of treatment in sarcoidosis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the most common ocular manifestation in patients infected by the human immunodeficiency virus?
explanation: Microangiopathy is the most common ocular feature of HIV infection. Microangiopathy of the retina in HIV consists of the hemorrhages, micro-aneurysms and cotton-wool spots or soft exudates (axonal debris). Cotton wool spots are the most common finding of HIV retinopathy. HIV leads to multiple opportunistic infections of the eye like cytomegalovirus (CMV) - most common cause of posterior uveitis in HIV - toxoplasmosis, Pneumocystis carinii and herpes zoster. These infections present as keratitis, choroiditis, retinitis and endophthalmitis. The most common ocular adverse effect in patients receiving highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is immune recovery uveitis (IRU). It is a non-granulomatous uveitis (usually anterior uveitis and vitritis) associated with a paradoxical or exaggerated reactivation of the immune system and an increase in intraocular inflammation. It occurs after receiving HAART for CMV chorioretinitis. Visual complications of IRU include cataract, cystoid macular edema (CME), glaucoma, and epiretinal membrane formation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An HIV positive patient presented to OPD with painless blurring of vision. On fundus examination, the following findings were seen. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: Painless blurring of vision in an HIV positive patient with "sauce and cheese" or "pizza pie" retinopathy (shown in the image) is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. CMV retinitis is the most common ocular opportunistic infection in patients with HIV. It is often asymptomatic and can be classified as central or peripheral CMV retinitis. Central CMV retinitis is characterised by dense, white areas of retinal necrosis and retinal hemorrhage in the areas of necrosis - pizza pie or sauce and cheese appearance. Peripheral CMV retinitis is less demarcated. The infection spreads along the vascular arcades in a brush fire-like fashion.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A newly diagnosed HIV-positive lady with CD4+ count of 35/L presented with decreased visual acuity and floaters. On fundus examination, there were dense, white areas of retinal necrosis with interspersed areas of retinal hemorrhage. What is the most rapid and accurate method to confirm the diagnosis?
options: Viral nucleic acid detection in intraocular fluid
Viral antibody detection in blood by ELISA
explanation: An HIV-positive patient with CD4+ count of 35/L presenting with decreased visual acuity, floaters and pizza pie retinitis (dense, white areas of retinal necrosis with interspersed areas of retinal hemorrhage) likely has CMV retinitis. The most rapid and accurate method to diagnose cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is viral nucleic acid detection in the intraocular fluid. CMV retinitis is an opportunistic infection seen in HIV patients with a CD4+ count less than 50/L. Patients present with reduced vision due to macular involvement and floaters due to vitritis. One eye is usually affected initially. Retinitis is seen. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA), which is marked vascular sheathing that occurs in about 6% patients, may be seen. Cataract is common late-stage manifestation of CMV retinitis. Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management, restoring the patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is a prodrug of ganciclovir that is taken orally. Ganciclovir slow-release intravitreal implant can also be used. Screening of patients with low CD4+ counts: 3-monthly, if <50/l 6-monthly, if 50–100/l Yearly, if >100/l
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 32-year-old man presented with blurring of vision in the right eye. Examination reveals mild iritis, severe vitritis, and a focal necrotic lesion on the macula. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Monocular iritis, severe vitritis with a focal necrotic lesion on the macula is a classical description of ocular toxoplasmosis. Ocular toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan. It causes severe recurrent attacks of posterior uveitis in adults, due to reactivation at previously inactive cyst-containing scars. A single inflammatory focus of fluffy white retinitis or retinochoroiditis associated with a pigmented scar ("satellite lesion") is typical. "Headlight in the fog" is the classic description of a white retinal inflammatory nidus viewed through vitritis. "Spill-over" anterior uveitis is common. Treatment: Prednisolone (1 mg/kg) is given initially and tapered according to clinical response. Pyrimethamine is administered as a loading dose of 75–100 mg for 1–2 days followed by 25–50 mg daily for 4 weeks in combination with oral folinic (not folic) acid 5 mg three times a week to retard thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and folate deficiency. Sulfadiazine 1 g four times daily for 3–4 weeks is usually given in combination with pyrimethamine. Intravitreal therapy with clindamycin (1 mg) and dexamethasone (400 g) may be as effective a triple therapy in reactivated infection. The image shows the characteristic "headlight in the fog" appearance:
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In which disease is the "headlight in fog" appearance seen?
explanation: The "headlight in fog" appearance is seen in toxoplasmosis. Ocular toxoplasmosis presents with iridocyclitis, which can be granulomatous or non-granulomatous. There is focal superficial necrotizing retinochoroiditis along with vitritis, which gives the "headlight in fog" appearance (image). Fundoscopy shows deep retinitis and papillitis with granulomas. Old choroid lesions of toxoplasmosis are punched-out lesions with pigmented borders. The treatment of choice for ocular toxoplasmosis is triple therapy with systemic steroids, pyrimethamine, and sulfadiazine. Clindamycin is also used.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 45-year-old man presented with red-eye, ocular pain, and acute loss of vision to the casualty. On fundoscopy, areas of retinal ischemia and necrosis were seen, leading to a diagnosis of acute retinal necrosis. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
options: It is seen in immunocompetent individuals.
Posterior pole is involved initially with centrifugal spread.
It may lead to retinal detachment.
explanation: In acute retinal necrosis, the posterior pole is typically spared until late. Acute retinal necrosis (ARN) occurs in immunocompetent individuals. It is a severe posterior uveitis causing retinal necrosis. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is the most common cause of acute retinal necrosis in adults. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) are the commonest causes of acute retinal necrosis in children. Patients present with confluent peripheral necrotizing retinitis, retinal arteritis with vaso-occlusion, and vitritis. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachments are common due to retinal thinning from large areas of necrosis. The posterior pole is involved only in the later stages. Aciclovir is administered intravenously (10 mg/kg, every 8 hours) for 10–14 days, and then orally (800 mg, five times daily) for 6–12 weeks. Oral valaciclovir or famciclovir may be substituted for oral aciclovir, with similar outcomes but better tolerability. Intravitreal ganciclovir or foscarnet may enhance the prognosis. Systemic steroids may be started 24 hours after the initiation of antiviral therapy, especially in severe cases. Laser retinopexy is performed around necrotic areas. Progressive outer retinal necrosis is a manifestation of HSV or varicella zoster virus (VZV) that occurs in immunocompromised individuals. It may begin at the posterior pole or the periphery. It has a rapid course and is not generally associated with vasculitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A 65-year-old male presents with a painful decrease in vision of his right eye for the past 3 days. He underwent right phacoemulsification with PC-IOL insertion 6 months ago.
Examination revealed a mild granulomatous anterior uveitis with minimal hypopyon and mild vitritis. There is a white plaque seen on the posterior lens capsule. Which one of the
following is the most appropriate therapy for this condition?
options: Vitrectomy and intravitreal injection of amphotericin B
Vitrectomy, removal of the IOL, and intravitreal injection of gentamicin
Vitrectomy, posterior capsulotomy, and intravitreal injection of vancomycin
explanation: Painful decrease in vision following cataract surgery 6 months ago with granulomatous anterior uveitis, hypopyon, vitritis and a white plaque on the posterior lens capsule suggests a diagnosis of delayed-onset postoperative endophthalmitis caused by Propionibacterium acnes. The best management for the above clinical scenario would be vitrectomy and posterior capsulotomy, followed by intravitreal injection of vancomycin. Delayed-onset endophthalmitis, a complication of cataract surgery, has a slow course and panuveitis like picture. There is low grade anterior chamber inflammation and vitritis. When caused by P. acnes, it typically presents from 3 months to 2 years after surgery with a characteristic white retro-lenticular plaque on the posterior capsule of lens. Endophthalmitis caused by Candida occurs within 3 months of surgery. Management includes anterior vitrectomy, IOL explantation, posterior capsulectomy, intravitreal vancomycin, and a scleral-fixated intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is seen after .
explanation: Sympathetic ophthalmia is seen after a penetrating trauma. Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating trauma or less frequently, following intraocular surgery, usually multiple vitreoretinal procedures. Patients present between 2 weeks and 3 months after initial injury. The earliest symptom is blurred near vision in the sympathizing (uninjured) eye. The earliest sign is a retrolental flare in the sympathizing eye. Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes. The fundus shows multifocal choroidal infiltrates in the mid-periphery. Sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen–Fuchs nodules (image)(a granuloma situated between Bruch membrane and the RPE) are also present. Steroids are the basis of treatment. High-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months. Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate can be used in resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents. Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury prevents the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the most common cause of endophthalmitis in a patient following eye trauma?
explanation: Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of post-traumatic endophthalmitis, followed by Bacillus cereus. However, if the trauma involves soil contamination, Bacillus cereus is the most common cause of post-traumatic endophthalmitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
Which of the following drugs should not be used in a patient with uveitis and raised IOP?
Atropine
explanation: Pilocarpine should not be used in cases of uveitis with raised intraocular pressure. Hypertensive uveitis or inflammatory glaucoma occurs when uveitis is associated with raised IOP. It is treated with topical cycloplegics (atropine), topical steroids and IOP-lowering drugs like topical timolol or systemic acetazolamide. Pilocarpine is contraindicated since it causes miosis and ciliary spasm. It also increases intraocular inflammation. Disorders of the Eyelid
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is defined as loss of eyelashes?
explanation: Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows. Loss of eyebrows is seen in leprosy and myxedema. Loss of eyelashes is seen in chronic blepharitis. Other options: Option A: Tylosis is a thickening of the tarsal border of the eyelid. Option C: Trichiasis is an inward misdirection of cilia, with the normal position of the lid margin. Option D: Distichiasis is the presence of a double row of eyelashes.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the term used to describe an extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line?
explanation: The extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called distichiasis. Distichiasis can occur due to congenital or acquired causes. These lashes may irritate the cornea. Management is by lid splitting with cryotherapy to the base of the hair follicles. Other options: Option A: Trichiasis is inward misdirection of cilia, with the normal position of the lid margin. Option C: Tylosis is the thickening of the tarsal plate. Option D: Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A term neonate is referred to the district hospital for an ophthalmic exam. Partial fusion of her right upper and lower eyelids by a central narrow band of tissue is noted as shown below. The left eye examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows an adhesion between the margins of the upper and lower eyelids, which suggests ankyloblepharon. It may occur as a congenital anomaly or as acquired adhesions after healing of chemical burns, ulcers, or traumatic wounds of the lid margins. Treatment is the excision of the adhesions between lid margins. In severe cases where the adhesions involve the angle of the eyes, epithelial grafts can be used. Other options: Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva, whereby the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball. Option C: Blepharophimosis is a congenital anomaly in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It appears contracted at the outer canthus. Option D: Lagophthalmos is characterized by the inability to close the eyelids voluntarily. It may be due to a malfunction of the facial nerve. The image below shows nocturnal lagophthalmos (inability to close eyelids during sleep).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A male patient complains of a foreign body sensation, irritation, and lacrimation in the right eye. During the evaluation, you notice the following findings with normal lid margins. What is this condition known as?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the above image is suggestive of trichiasis. Trichiasis refers to the inward misdirection of cilia, which usually rub against the eyeball with the normal position of the lid margin. These patients present with foreign body sensations and photophobia. They experience troublesome irritation, pain, and lacrimation. On examination, one or more misdirected cilia touching the cornea are seen. The conjunctiva may be congested. Treatment includes: Epilation: Mechanical removal with forceps Electrolysis: Method of destroying the lash follicle by electric current. Cryoepilation Surgical correction.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What defines telecanthus?
options: Widened root of the nose with normal inter-pupillary distance
explanation: Telecanthus means an increased distance between medial canthi (widened root of the nose) with normal inter-pupillary distance. In hypertelorism, there is a wide bony separation of the orbits. In epicanthus, there are bilateral vertical folds of skin that extend from the upper or lower lids towards the medial canthi. They may give rise to pseudoesotropia.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Weiss operation is done in which of the following condition?
explanation: Weiss operation is done in senile entropion. In this operation, the transverse lid split, and everything sutures are placed. Entropion refers to the inward rolling and rotation of the lid margin towards the globe. It is more common in the lower lid. Causes include: Horizontal lid laxity Vertical lid instability Over-riding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis during lid closure Orbital septum laxity
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: For which of the following is medial conjunctivoplasty the surgical modality of treatment?
explanation: Medial conjunctivoplasty is done in involutional ectropion. Ectropion is the eversion of the lid margin and eyelashes away from the globe. Types: Involutional/senile - affects the lower lid of elderly patients. Cicatricial - caused by the scarring or contracture of the skin and underlying tissues Paralytic - caused by ipsilateral facial nerve palsy Mechanical - caused by tumors on or near the lid margin that mechanically evert the lid Congenita
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which among the following is not a feature of blepharophimosis syndrome?
explanation: Entropion is not a feature of blepharophimosis syndrome. Blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) consists of the following: Narrow palpebral fissure Ptosis Congenital ectropion of the lower lid Telecanthus Epicanthus inversus: an extra fold of skin arising from the lower lid The image below shows blepharophimosis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye exam. Which of the following pair of muscles are likely to be affected in this patient?
options: Levator palpebrae superioris and superior oblique
Levator palpebrae superioris and Muller's muscle
explanation: The patient has mild right eye ptosis. Injury or weakness of levator palpebrae superioris and Muller's muscle leads to ptosis. Levator palpebrae superioris is the important upper eyelid retractor. Frontalis and Muller’s muscle assist in the elevation of the upper eyelid.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following conditions is a cause of pseudoptosis?
explanation: Brow ptosis is a type of pseudoptosis, not ptosis. Ptosis is abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid to a level that covers more than 2mm of the superior cornea. Types of ptosis: Mechanical ptosis - Can be due to lid tumors, multiple/big chalazions, and conjunctival scarring Aponeurotic ptosis - Due to dehiscence of the aponeurosis and in postoperative patients Involutional ptosis seen in old age Neurogenic ptosis due to a 3rd nerve palsy, Horner syndrome and synkinetic ptosis/Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking ptosis Myogenic ptosis Congenital: most common myogenic ptosis Simple Blepharophimosis syndrome Congenital synkinetic ptosis Acquired Myasthenia gravis Lambert–Eaton syndrome Ocular myopathy Causes of pseudoptosis (apparent ptosis): Lack of support of the lids by the globe e.g. artificial eye, microphthalmos, phthisis bulbi, or enophthalmos. Contralateral lid retraction Ipsilateral hypotropia Brow ptosis occurs due to excessive skin on the brow, or seventh nerve palsy, which is diagnosed by manually elevating the eyebrow Dermatochalasis
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis and ptosis is the most common ocular feature of the disease. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction most commonly caused by anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. The disorder is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles where the weakness increases during repeated use and may improve following rest. Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints due to early involvement of the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs). Of them, Ptosis is a more common manifestation than diplopia. Ptosis in myasthenia gravis is insidious, bilateral, and frequently asymmetrical. Investigations of myasthenia gravis include: Ice pack test -This tests for a transient improvement of the ptotic eyelid on placing an ice pack for 2 minutes, as the cold inhibits the breakdown of acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase. Tensilon (Edrophonium) test - This tests for a transient improvement in the weakness on administration of a short-acting anticholinesterase such as edrophonium. Antibody testing - for Acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies, MuSK protein antibodies helps support a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following conditions will not have a finding of bilateral ptosis?
explanation: Bilateral ptosis is not seen in Marfan's syndrome. Causes of unilateral ptosis: Horner's syndrome Oculomotor nerve palsy Causes of bilateral ptosis: Congenita Senile/involutional/aponeurotic Blepharophimosis syndrome Myasthenia gravis Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO) - seen in Kearns-Sayre syndrome Myotonic dystrophy Ocular myopathies The image below shows a case of botulinum toxicity with bilateral ptosis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: During OPD hours, a patient came with the finding shown below. On examination, the upper 4 mm of the cornea is covered by the upper eyelid. What is the grade of ptosis in this patient?
explanation: In this question, 4 mm of the cornea is covered by the upper eyelid. Subtracting 2 mm from this implies that there is 2 mm of ptosis, which is classified as mild grade. In bilateral cases, the grade of ptosis can be determined by measuring the amount of cornea covered by the upper lid and then subtracting 2 mm. Depending upon this value, the ptosis is graded as follows: Mild: 2 mm Moderate: 3 mm Severe: 4 mm
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A child with a high risk of amblyopia is planned for surgical correction of unilateral simple congenital ptosis. He has poor levator function. What is the treatment of choice in this case?
explanation: Frontalis sling procedure is the treatment of choice for congenital ptosis with poor levator function.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient presents to you with anhidrosis and enophthalmos. Examination reveals miosis along with mild ptosis. You decide to correct the ptosis by performing a Fasanella-Servat operation, by resecting which of the following muscles?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's syndrome and the associated mild ptosis in this condition can be corrected by resecting Muller's muscle. Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to the paralysis of Muller's muscle. Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated in cases having mild ptosis(< 2 mm) and good levator function. In this surgery, the upper tarsal border along with its attached Muller’s muscle and conjunctiva are resected.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A couple brought their 11-month-old child for an eye exam when they noticed that his left upper eyelid was in a lower position than his right one. The mother also noticed that his left upper eyelid goes "up and down” when she breastfeeds him. His delivery was unremarkable. When the baby opens his mouth or sucks his thumb, the left eyelid ptosis disappears. What is the pathology behind this condition?
options: Superior division of the third cranial nerve is misdirected
Sympathetic nerves to Muller's muscles are misdirected
Ophthalmic division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected
Mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. In this condition, the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle. Some cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. The vast majority are unilateral. Signs include retraction of the ptotic lid in conjunction with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement. Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth. Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it. The following image shows a woman with Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. See how her right eyelid ptosis retracts with the opening of the mouth.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is the causative agent for blepharitis acarica?
explanation: Blepharitis acarica is caused by Demodex folliculorum. Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the margins of the lids. The two types are Anterior Seborrheic and ulcerative types Caused by staphylococci, mainly Posterior – Mebomianitis Occasionally caused by Demodex folliculorum – Blepharitis acarica Crab louse – Phthiriasis palpebrarum The following image shows swollen and inflamed eyelid suggestive of blepharitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the most common malignant tumor of the eyelid?
explanation: Basal cell carcinoma constitutes 85–90% of all malignant epithelial eyelid tumors. It is locally malignant and most commonly involves the lower lid, followed by the medial canthus, upper lid, and outer canthus.
