question_text: Which of the following systemic drugs is used specifically in the management of periocular basal cell carcinoma?
explanation: Vismodegib is the systemic drug used for the management of periocular basal cell carcinoma (BCC). Vismodegib is an eye-sparing adjuvant therapy of periocular and orbital BCC for patients: Who cannot tolerate surgery or radiotherapy, or With relapsed locally advanced disease after surgery or With metastatic disease. Vismodegib is a Hedgehog pathway inhibitor, given 150 mg orally twice a day. Treatment options for BCC consist of surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. Surgical excision using Mohs micrographic surgery or wide surgical excision with frozen section margin control is the first-line treatment of periocular BCC. Other options: Option A: Imiquimod 5% topical cream can also be used in patients with BCC. But, it is not a systemic drug. Option C: Siponimod is the drug approved for secondary progressive multiple sclerosis. Option D: Interferons are generally not used in periocular BCC.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 6-month-old girl was brought by her worried parents due to a swelling on the eyelid as shown below. They were told by a local village doctor that the swelling will disappear on its own but recently it has been increasing rapidly. What would be the most likely management of this baby's condition?
options: Treatment with intralesional steroids at 2 years of age
explanation: The history and image are suggestive of capillary hemangioma involving the left upper lid and periocular region causing severe mechanical ptosis. Immediate management with oral propranolol is the treatment of choice in this case. The ptosis is so severe that it obstructs the pupillary area (visual axis) with the risk of sensory deprivation amblyopia. This warrants immediate treatment to reduce the bulk of the tumor. Capillary hemangioma regresses spontaneously very often. It may be managed by oral propranolol, oral prednisolone, or intralesional steroid. Indications for treatment of patients with capillary hemangioma with pharmacologic therapy are: Visual symptoms (amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion, strabismus) Cosmesis Optic nerve compression Exposure keratopathy
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Identify the clinical condition.
explanation: The image shows plexiform neurofibroma of the upper lid causing an S-shaped deformity of the upper lid and mechanical ptosis. This is seen particularly in neurofibromatosis type 1. NF1 is caused by the autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17. It is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes neurofibromin, a negative RAS regulator. The disease is clinically diagnosed when any two of the following seven features are present: Six or more café-au-lait macules (CALMs) - They are the hallmark of neurofibromatosis and are present in almost 100% of patients. They are present at birth but increase in size, number, and pigmentation, especially during the first few years of life, and are scattered over the entire body. Axillary or inguinal freckling Two or more iris Lisch nodules - They are iris hamartomas that are best identified by a slit-lamp examination. They are present in the majority of patients with NF1. Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones such as the tibia Optic gliomas (most frequently observed CNS tumor in NF1) A first-degree relative with NF-1
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
Which of the following sign is used to describe the fullness of eyelids seen in Grave's ophthalmopathy?
Mobius’ sign
explanation: The fullness of the eyelids is described as the Enroth's sign in Graves ophthalmopathy. Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of the Eye
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Moll glands are examples of
explanation: Moll glands are examples of apocrine sweat gland. Moll glands are present in the eyelid. They are a type of modified apocrine sweat glands opening either into a lash follicle or directly onto the anterior lid margin between the lashes. Zeis glands are a type of modified sebaceous glands associated with lash follicles. Meibomian glands are modified sebaceous glands found in the tarsal plates.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient presented with a painless swelling and watering in his left eye. Examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following statements is false regarding his diagnosis?
options: It needs to be surgically treated.
It does not have malignant potential.
It is a chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation.
explanation: A painless swelling on the lower lid is suggestive of a chalazion (tarsal cyst/meibomian cyst). It has the malignant potential to become an adenocarcinoma of the meibomian gland. Chalazion is the chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation (option D) of the meibomian gland (option B). It presents as painless swelling of the eyelid. It is more common in adults than children. Treatment includes incision and curettage (option B) and intralesional injection of triamcinolone acetate.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the possibility of .
explanation: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the possibility of sebaceous gland carcinoma. Note: A chalazion can undergo malignant change into sebaceous gland carcinoma (adenocarcinoma of meibomian gland). Recurrences of chalazia are not uncommon. However, the physician should entertain the possibility of malignancy in such cases and should biopsy a lesion that recurs or appears atypical. The pathologist should be alerted to the suspicion of sebaceous gland carcinoma and frozen sections and lipid stains should be requested.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient presented to the clinic with severe left eye pain, watering, and swelling of the lid for 2 days. He says it's difficult to see the laptop screen while working and he is unable to complete his daily targets. On examination, tender swelling is noted as shown below. What is the cause of this finding?
explanation: The patient has acute presentation and painful swelling in the palpebral conjunctiva as shown in the image, suggestive of internal hordeolum. It is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland associated with blockage of the duct. Other options: Options A and B: Hordeolum externum or stye is the acute staphylococcal infection of the hair follicle/Zeis gland/Moll gland. Option D: Chalazion is a chronic non-suppurative lipogranulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the length of the nasolacrimal duct?
explanation: The nasolacrimal duct is 12–18 mm long. The lacrimal drainage system consists of the lacrimal sac, which is 10–12 mm long. It lies in the lacrimal fossa, between the anterior and posterior lacrimal crests. The lacrimal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla separate the lacrimal sac from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. The nasolacrimal duct is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac. It is 12–18 mm long and is directed downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus is partially covered by a mucosal fold (valve of Hasner). The puncta are openings on the lid margin. There are two canaliculi from the puncta. Each canaliculus (superior and inferior) has two parts: Vertical (2 mm) and horizontal (8 mm). The superior and inferior canaliculi usually unite to form the common canaliculus, which opens into the lateral wall of the lacrimal sac. A small flap of mucosa (Rosenmüller valve) overhangs the junction of the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac and prevents the reflux of tears into the canaliculi. The image below shows structures of the lacrimal apparatus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Where does the nasolacrimal duct open?
explanation: The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus. The nasolacrimal duct is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac. It is 12–18 mm long and is directed downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus is partially covered by a mucosal fold, called the valve of Hasner. The valve of Hasner prevents reflux from the nose.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 60-year-old woman came for an eye exam due to a gritty sensation that has been causing her a lot of discomfort. On examination, Rose Bengal staining is positive. She is diagnosed with keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Which of the following layer of the tear film is deficient in this condition?
explanation: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is due to the deficiency of the aqueous layer of the tear film. In keratoconjunctivitis sicca, patients present with irritation and foreign body sensation. Marginal tear strip is reduced. The conjunctiva become dry and lustreless with positive Rose Bengal staining. Causes of keratoconjunctivitis sicca: Sjogren's syndrome (primary keratoconjunctivitis sicca) Non-Sjogren's keratoconjunctivitis sicca Primary age-related hyposecretion (most common) Lacrimal gland deficiencies - congenital, infiltration by tumors or sarcoidosis, surgical removal Lacrimal gland duct obstruction - old trachoma, burns, SJS Reflex hyposecretion (neurogenic causes) - Parkinson disease, 7th nerve palsy, reflex sensory block
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the phenol red test for dry eye?
options: It measures tear production based on the length of colour change in the thread
If color changes to blue, it depicts mucin deficiency.
explanation: Phenol red test measures the tear production according to the length of colour change in the thread. In phenol red test, the alkalinity of tears changes its colour to bright orange on contact. It doesn't require anaesthesia (unlike Schirmer's test). Three millimetres of a fine dye-impregnated 75-mm cotton thread is placed under the lateral one-fifth of the inferior palpebral lid margin for 15 seconds. Based on length of colour change, >20 mm - normal tear production 10 to 19 mm - borderline dry eye <10 mm - severe dry eye
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Identify the test shown below.
explanation: The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test which is used to check for dry eye. Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the eye characterised by loss of homeostasis of the tear film. Patients present with irritation, foreign body sensation and dryness. Treatment of dry eye includes medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) o surgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs). Other tests for dry eye include: Tear film break-up test is used to determine the interval between a complete blink and appearance of first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. A drop of fluorescein is instilled in the eye, following by examination in the cobalt-blue light of a slit-lamp. Rose Bengal staining is used for the detection of dry, dead epithelium in dry eye. Tear osmolarity test is performed with an osmometer. Other options: Option B: Ishihara plates are used to test colour vision. They help detect red-green colour blindness. Option C: Jones test is used in watering eye. It uses fluorescein dye. Option D: Goldmann's tonometry is used to measure intra-ocular pressure. It consists of a double prism mounted on a slit-lamp.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: You are conducting retrospective research on factors responsible for dry eye disorder. As a part of your study, you are looking through the files in the clinic of dry eye patients. Which among the following patients would not be included in your study?
options: A 26 year old patient showing decreased levels of lactoferrin in tear samples
A 20 year old patient showing tear film break up at 18-20 seconds
A 24 year old patient showing A pattern stain in Rose bengal staining
A 22 year old patient showing Schirmer test tear strip wet upto 9 mm
explanation: A patient with tear film break up at 18-20 seconds is considered to be normal. All the other patients have dry eye. Tear film break-up (BUT) time is the interval between a complete blink and the appearance of a first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears. Inference: 15-35 seconds - normal < 10 seconds- unstable tear film Other options: Option A: Tear samples can be assayed for the presence of markers known to be decreased (e.g. lactoferrin) or elevated (e.g. matrix metalloproteinase-9) in dry eye. This is known as tear constituent measurement. Option C: A patient with A pattern on Rose Bengal staining has severe dry eye. Option D: A patient with 9mm wet Schirmer strip has moderate dry eye.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The findings of a test done in a patient under evaluation for dry eye are shown below. Identify the test.
explanation: The image above depicts lacrimal scintigraphy. Lacrimal scintigraphy (dacryoscintigraphy) is used to assess the lacrimal drainage function. A radioactive tracer (technetium-99m) is instilled into the conjunctival sac. Its path is then visualised with an Anger gamma camera. It is useful for the evaulation of watering eye. Other tests for evaluation of watering eye include regurgitation test, syringing, fluorescein dye disappearance test (FDDT), Jones dye test and dacryocystography. Other options: Option A: In regurgitation test, steady pressure with the index finger is applied above the medial palpebral ligament. Option B: In dacryocystography, a radioopaque material is inserted into the lacrimal sac, following which X-rays are taken. Option C: The image shows the Jones dye test.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the site of blockage in congenital dacryocystitis?
explanation: The site of blockage in congenital dacryocystitis is the nasolacrimal duct. Congenital dacryocystitis occurs due to the stasis of secretions in the lacrimal sac due to congenital blockage in the nasolacrimal duct. Membranous occlusion at its lower end near the valve of Hasner is the commonest cause. The image below shows a neonate with congenital dacryocystitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A mother noticed the following finding in her 3-month-old child. There is a history of watering and discharge from his right eye since birth. Which of the following is the best next step in the treatment?
explanation: The image showing right-sided swelling in the lacrimal sac area along with watering of the eye is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis. Treatment for a 3-month-old child includes sac massage with topical antibiotics. Congenital dacryocystitis is chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac in newborn infants. It occurs due to congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. More than 90% of patients with undergo spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age. Treatment of congenital dacryocystitis depends on the age of the child: Less than 9 months: Massaging (Crigler’s massage which increases the hydrostatic pressure within the sac) and antibiotic eye drops 9 months to 4 years: Probing Older children (> 4 years): Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) gives the best result. In DCR, an opening is made into the nasal cavity from the lacrimal sac.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 60-year-old man presents with watering from the right eye for 1 year. Syringing revealed a patent drainage system. Rest of the ocular examination was normal. A provisional diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure was made. Which of the following test will help in the confirmation of the diagnosis?
explanation: Lacrimal pump failure can be confirmed with dacryoscintigraphy. Lacrimal pump failure means an inability of the lid muscles to push tears towards the punctum for drainage. It is also called functional obstruction and may be secondary to lower lid laxity or orbicularis muscle weakness (eg. facial nerve palsy. It is confirmed by dacryoscintigraphy, in which a radioactive tracer (technetium-99m) is instilled into the conjunctival sac and its path visualised with an Anger gamma camera. An atonic lacrimal sac is seen. Note: In cases of partial obstruction of the lacrimal apparatus, forced injection of fluid into the canalicular system (dacryocystography) can overcome the obstruction sites and point to a diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure. Thus, dacryoscintigraphy is better for the confirmation of lacrimal pump failure.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
explanation: The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) DCR involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. It re-establishes the lacrimal drainage and is hence the preferred surgery for chronic darcyocystectomy. Chronic dacryocystitis is a long-standing inflammation of the lacrimal sac. Streptococcus hemolyticus and Staphylococcus aureus are the most common etiological agents. Initial treatment is with antibiotics and anti-inflammatory agents. Sequelae include lacrimal fistula formation and mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis. Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy. Treatment of lacrimal fistula is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A patient with chronic dacryocystitis, refractory to the medical treatment, has been scheduled for dacryocystorhinostomy. Following the surgery, the sac would be draining into the
.
explanation: After dacryocystorhinostomy, the lacrimal sac drains into the middle meatus. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the most common ocular manifestation in mumps?
explanation: The most common ocular manifestation in mumps is dacryocystadenitis. Dacryocystadenitis, or inflammation of the lacrimal gland, is seen in mumps. It presents as a painful swelling in the lateral part of the upper lid.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor?
Adenoid cystic carcinoma
explanation: Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is also the most common epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland. Pleomorphic adenoma, or benign mixed tumor, presents commonly in middle age as a slowly progressive painless swelling in the upper outer quadrant of the eyelid. The bone is usually not invaded in these tumors. They are treated by surgical removal along with their intact pseudo-capsule. Malignant tumors of the lacrimal gland such as adenoid cystic carcinoma (option A), mucoepidermoid carcinoma (option C) and malignant mixed tumor (option D) generally occur in the elderly with a short history of appearance, rapid progression and pain. These tumors also present in the upper eyelid and are known to invade the adjacent bones. Radical surgical procedures and high dose radiotherapy are necessary for the removal of the tumor. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland. Both malignant and benign tumors are known to push the eyeball downwards and inwards while restricting the upwards and outwards movement of the eyeball. The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows: Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA) Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma Orbit Anatomy and Ocular Injuries
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following structures does not pass through the superior orbital fissure?
explanation: The optic nerve (2nd cranial nerve) passes through the optic canal, not the superior orbital fissure. Anatomy of the orbit Orbit is a pear-shaped cavity, the stalk of which is the optic canal. The volume of the orbit is 30 cc. The image below shows the bones forming the orbit. Wallsof the orbit Bonesforming them Roof Lesser wing of the sphenoidT he orbital plate of the frontal bone Lateralwall (strongest wall) Greater wing of the sphenoid Zygomatic bone Floor(most frequently fractur ed wall) Zygomatic boneMaxillary bo nePalatine bone Medialwall (thinnest wall) Maxillary boneLacrimal bone Ethmoid boneSphenoid bone The inferior orbital fissure lies between the greater wing of the sphenoid and the maxilla, connecting the orbit to the pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae. Through it run the maxillary nerve, the zygomatic nerve, and branches of the pterygopalatine ganglion, as well as the inferior ophthalmic vein.

question_text: You are volunteering in a medical camp held in an orphanage. You see a kid with hypoplasia of the zygoma and mandible along with antimongoloid slant of palpebral fissures as shown below. These findings correspond to which of the following syndrome?
explanation: The given findings correspond to Treacher–Collins syndrome. Treacher–Collins syndrome/Mandibulofacial dysostosis refers to a condition resulting from the hypoplasia of the zygoma and mandible. Ocular features: Indistinct inferior orbital margin Coloboma of the lower eyelid Anti-mongoloid slant of palpebral fissures Systemic features Macrostomia with a high-arched palate External ear deformity Bird-like face The image below shows features of Treacher–Collins syndrome. Craniofacial dysostosis/Crouzon syndrome refers to the premature closure of the coronal and sagittal sutures (brachycephaly—clover-leaf skull) associated with maxillary hypoplasia. Ocular associations include the following: Blue sclera Megalocornea Aniridia Glaucoma Cataract Ectopia lentis Optic nerve hypoplasia The image below shows a baby with Crouzon syndrome. Apert syndrome is the most severe form of craniosynostosis, involving premature closure of multiple cranial sutures (acrocephaly), along with syndactyly of the fingers and toes. The image below shows the hands of a patient with Apert syndrome.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient with a history of trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario plus the supportive CT image showing the "hanging drop sign" is suggestive of a blowout fracture of the orbital wall. Blow-out fractures are isolated comminunited fractures caused from direct trauma to the orbit that results in a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the intraorbital pressure. This causes a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall which is usually the posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone in the orbital floor. The second most common site for orbital blowout fracture is the medial wall of the orbit. The patient with blow out fracture usually presents with immediate periorbital edema and blood extravasation in and around the orbit. Proptosis of the eyeball secondary to orbital edema or hemorrhage with paresthesia along the infraorbital nerve are also very common. Imaging by a plain x-ray in water's view or by CT demonstrates depression of bony fragments and orbital contents herniating through the orbital floor into the maxillary antrum. This is called as the "hanging drop sign" or "tear drop sign". Definitive treatment is by surgical repair 10-14 days after injury with initial supportive management with analgesics and antibiotics. Le fort fracture- Is the term used to describe different types of maxillary fractures.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the most common site of an orbital blowout fracture?
explanation: The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit. Blow-out fractures are isolated comminunited fractures caused from direct trauma to the orbit that results in a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the intraorbital pressure. This causes a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall which is usually the posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone in the orbital floor. The second most common site for orbital blowout fracture is the medial wall of the orbit (Option A). The fractures of the roof(Option C) are relatively rare and most often do not require any treatment.The lateral wall(Option B) of the orbit is the most solid orbital wall and a fracture here is usually seen in injuries with extensive facial damage. The patient with blow out fracture usually presents with immediate periorbital edema and blood extravasation in and around the orbit. Proptosis of the eyeball secondary to orbital edema or hemorrhage with paresthesia along the infraorbital nerve are also very common. Imaging by a plain x-ray in water's view or by CT demonstrates depression of bony fragments and orbital contents herniating through the orbital floor into the maxillary antrum. This is called as the "hanging drop sign" or "tear drop sign". Definitive treatment is by surgical repair 10-14 days after injury with initial supportive management with analgesics and antibiotics. The below given CT image shows hanging drop sign. The below given X-ray image in water's view shows "hanging drop sign".

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding the clinical sequelae expected in a patient with orbital blowout fracture is false?
options: Anesthesia of the cheek is very common.
Emphysema of eyelids is more common with medial wall fracture.
Enophthalmos develops about 10 days after the injury.
Severe ocular damage is seen in most cases.
explanation: Severe ocular damage associated with a "blowout" fracture is rare. This is because a "blowout fracture" is nature’s way of protecting the globe from injury. C inical features of blow out fracture are as follows: Periorbital edema Paresthesia and anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve (lower lid, cheek, side of the nose, upper lip, and upper teeth) Emphysema of the eyelids-more frequent with medial wall fractures Proptosis-seen initially due to orbital edema and hemorrhage. After about 10 days, as the edema decreases, the eyeball sinks backward and somewhat inferiorly, resulting in enophthalmos and mechanical ptosis. Double diplopia- diplopia in upward as well as downward gaze
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Two people who got in a brawl are brought to the emergency department because of severe facial injuries. In one of those patients, there is periorbital ecchymosis and anesthesia over the cheek. Orbital blowout fracture is suspected. What X-ray finding will confirm this diagnosis?
explanation: The X-ray finding seen in an orbital blowout fracture is hanging drop/tear-drop sign. Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. The most useful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water’s view. The optimal time for surgery following a blowout fracture is 10–14 days. Indications for surgery in a blowout fracture are as follows: Diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma A fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum Incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in globe retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze Enophthalmos greater than 2 mm
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: All of the following are characteristic clinical findings that are associated with a history of blunt trauma to the eye, except:
explanation: Vossius ring, not Soemmering’s, is seen after blunt trauma to the eye Soemmering’s ring refers to a thick ring of after cataract, also known as "secondary cataract." It is the opacity that persists or develops after extracapsular lens extraction. Blunt trauma to the eye produces: Vossius ring - It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule. It occurs due to the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens. Rosette cataract - It is the most typical form of concussion cataract. Commotio retinae (Berlin’s edema) - It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a "cherry-red spot" at foveola.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the most common site of globe rupture following trauma?
explanation: The superonasal limbus is the most common site of globe rupture. This occurs due to the contrecoup effect—the lower temporal quadrant is the most exposed to trauma; hence, the effect is seen in the superonasal limbus, which lies on the opposite side.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In which of the following conditions is the following clinical finding seen?
explanation: The image shows bilateral periorbital ecchymoses, which is called the panda sign, and it is seen in bilateral anterior cranial fossa fracture. It is also known as panda eyes/raccoon eyes. The pooling of blood surrounding the eyes is most commonly associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. This finding is typically not present during the initial evaluation and is delayed by 1 to 3 days. If bilateral, this finding is highly predictive of a basilar skull fracture.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: C inical examination patients with which of the following conditions would show Dalen Fuchs Nodules?
explanation: Dalen Fuchs nodules are seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis and Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease (VKH) syndrome. These are local granulomas due to the proliferation of lymphocytes and epithelioid cells and are located between RPE and Bruch's membrane. The image below shows Dalen Fuchs nodules.

question_text: Which of the following views would you advise, so as to visualize the optic foramina?
explanation: The Rhese view in an X-ray scan helps in the visualization of the optic foramina. The optic foramen/optic canal transmits the optic nerve and ophthalmic artery. Rhese view: for optic foramen Other X-ray views of the orbit: Caldwell's view: Occipitofrontal Structures seen: Superior orbital fissure Greater and lesser wing of the sphenoid Ethmoid and frontal sinus Floor of the sella Water's view: Occipitomeatal: floor of the orbit is seen (important in "blow-out" fractures) Occipitomental: maxillary sinus and floor of the orbit Towne’ s view: Structures seen Dorsum sellae of the sphenoid bone Inferior orbital fissure

question_text: Heterochromia iridis may be caused by which of the following intraocular foreign bodies?
explanation: Heterochromia iridis may be caused by iron deposition. Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. In siderosis bulbi, the iris is first stained greenish and later turns reddish brown, causing heterochromia iridis. Chalcosis refers to the specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye. Clinical features include the following: Kayser–Fleischer ring- a golden brown ring that occurs due to the deposition of copper in the Descemet’s membrane of the cornea. Sunflower cataract- produced by the deposition of copper under the anterior capsule of the lens. It is brilliant golden green in color and arranged like the petals of a sunflower. question_text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to produce this finding on CT?
explanation: The CT image shows hyperostosis of the lateral wall of the left orbit. Hyperostosis causing lesions are: Sphenoid wing meningioma Fibrous dysplasia Metastasis from cancer prostate

question_text: Which of the following conditions does not presents as pulsatile proptosis?
explanation: Among the given options, hemangioma will not present with pulsatile proptosis. Causes of pulsatile proptosis: Pulsating vascular lesions: Caroticocavernous fistula- most common Saccular aneurysm of ophthalmic artery Transmitted cerebral pulsations in conditions with a deficient orbital roof: Congenital meningocele/meningoencephalocele Neurofibromatosis Traumatic or operative hiatus Causes of intermittent proptosis: Orbital varix- most common Periodic orbital edema Causes of reducible proptosis: Orbital varix Hemangioma Caroticocavernous fistula

question_text: A patient presents with unilateral non-pulsatile proptosis, which is compressible and increases on bending forward. No thrill or bruit is present. MRI shows a retrobulbar mass with enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The likely diagnosis from the above clinical scenario is orbital varix. The type of proptosis seen in orbital varix is non-pulsatile, intermittent, and reducible proptosis. On activities such as forward bending or lowering of the head, turning the head forcefully, hyperextension of the neck, and coughing, the varices fill up, causing proptosis, and then, they regress on shifting to a non-dependent position. All the other conditions listed, namely, carotid cavernous fistula, orbital encephalocele, and neurofibromatosis, present with pulsatile proptosis.

question_text:
A 26-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the head 2 months earlier presented with rapidly progressive swelling, pain, and diminishing vision in the left eye. The physical examination of the left eye revealed chemosis and pulsating proptosis. A bruit could be heard
with a stethoscope placed on the left temple. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of carotid–cavernous fistula. All the given options are causes of proptosis following trauma, but among these, only a carotid-cavernous fistula presents with the classic triad: Pulsatile proptosis Chemosis Bruit Selective carotid angiography is the investigation of choice. A carotid-cavernous fistula requires a definitive treatment, which currently involves the endovascular technique. The fistula can usually be occluded with a balloon or coil, without the sacrifice of the carotid artery.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following conditions will present with pseudoproptosis?
explanation: Buphthalmos causes pseudoproptosis. The other listed conditions, namely, pseudotumors, orbital hemorrhage, and cavernous sinus thrombosis, produce actual proptosis. Pseudoproptosis is a condition in which the eyeball appears to be proptosed, but there is no actual forward displacement. Causes of pseudoproptosis: Buphthalmos is the term used when the eyeball enlarges in children who develop congenital glaucoma before the age of 3 years. Axial high myopia- increase in the size of the eyeball in myopia causes pseudoproptosis Retraction of the upper lid Enophthalmos of the opposite eye

question_text: A 48-year-old lady presents with unilateral mild axial proptosis. On examination, the following nail and skin changes were seen as shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step of investigation?
options: CT scan to rule out meningioma
USG to rule out orbital pseudotumor
T3 and T4 measurement to check for thyrotoxicosis
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the image showing thyroid acropachy and dermopathy is suggestive of Graves' disease. The most appropriate next step of the investigation is T3 and T4 measurement to check for thyrotoxicosis. Thyroid ophthalmopathy is the most common cause of proptosis in adults, which may present as unilateral or bilateral, axial or non-axial, painful or painless proptosis.
