question_text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy. Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of both bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state. The main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy. Other options- Option A- Orbital pseudotumor presents with painful eye movements periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia. Option C- Orbital lymphoma usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant. Option D- Orbital cellulitis is usually a unilateral condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis. NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the most common clinical feature of Graves’ ophthalmopathy?
explanation: Dalrymple’s sign (retraction of the upper lids) is the most common clinical feature of Graves’ ophthalmopathy. It is caused by the overaction of Muller’s muscle. Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) recession surgery may be done to correct upper lid retraction. The image given below shows Dalrymple’s sign (retraction of the upper lids) in the right eye: NOSPECS classification by Werner reflecting the severity of thyroid ophthalmopathy. Class Definition 0 No physical signs or sympto ms 1 Only signs, no symptoms (sig ns limited to upper lid retract ion, stare, lid lag, and propto sis of up to 22 mm) Class Definition Class Definition 2 Soft tissue involvement (sym ptom and signs) 3 Proptosis 4 Extraocular muscle involvem ent 5 Corneal involvement 6 Sight loss (optic nerve involv ement) NOSPECS:No signs or sympt oms;Only signs;Soft tissue;Pr optosis;Extraocular muscle;C ornea;Sight loss
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 40-year-old male presents with heat intolerance and weight loss for the past few weeks. He has lost 10 kgs despite having an increased appetite. On examination, he has a fine tremor of the hands, and his thyroid is enlarged. Lab investigations reveal low TSH and elevated T3 and T4. What is the most common ocular motility defect seen in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Grave's disease. The most common ocular motility defect seen in Grave's disease is elevator restriction. It occurs due to the fibrotic contracture of the inferior rectus muscle. The inferior rectus muscle has to relax during the elevation of the eye. The fibrosis of the muscle restricts its relaxation and thus elevation of the eye is restricted. There is an inability to look up (in both adducted and abducted positions) along with esotropia (fibrosis of the medial rectus). Only the belly of the muscle is involved in thyroid myopathy; the tendon is characteristically spared. Ocular motility restriction in order of frequency is as follows: Elevation defect Abduction defect, due to fibrosis of the medial rectus Depression defect, due to fibrosis of the superior rectus Adduction defect, due to fibrosis of the lateral rectus
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is known as the infrequent blinking seen in Graves’ ophthalmopathy?
explanation: Infrequent blinking is known as Stellwag’s sign.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A lady is referred from the medicine department for an eye exam due to gritty sensation in her eyes. She is a known case of hyperthyroidism. Her ophthalmic examination shows the following finding along with the inability to look up. Which of the following is not a treatment modality for this condition?
explanation: The clinical scenario of grittiness in the eyes (due to ocular dryness), hyperthyroidism and the image showing exophthalmos are suggestive of Graves ophthalmopathy. Beta-blockers are not indicated in the treatment of graves ophthalmopathy, however, they are used in the symptomatic management of hyperthyroidism. Treatment of thyroid ophthalmopathy: Non-surgical management Systemic steroids- These form the mainstay of the treatment. Oral, intravenous or orbital steroid injections can be used depending upon patient indications. (Option B) Radiotherapy- Orbital radiation given in a dose of 2000 rads over 10-14 days can be considered in cases where steroids are ineffective/ contraindicated. It is contraindicated in cases of extensive thyroid eye disease as it can worsen it. (Option A) Teprotumumab (IGF-1R inhibitor)- is used for persistent, corticosteroid-resistant disease or non-response to first-line treatment. It is effective in reducing proptosis and clinical activity in patients. Surgical management: Orbital decompression- It may be required for an acutely progressive optic neuropathy and/or exposure keratitis, in patients not responding to aggressive steroid therapy. (Option D) Extraocular muscle surgery- Inferior rectus recession is the most commonly performed surgery. These should be performed after the orbital decompression since decompression may alter extraocular motility. Extraocular muscle surgery helps in achieving a binocular single vision in the primary gaze and reading position. Eyelid surgery- This is done to correct eyelid retraction. Various surgeries that can be performed are mullerectomy, levator recession/ disinsertion, scleral grafts with LPS recession, recession of lower eyelid retractors, and blepharoplasty.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause ?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis. Features of cavernous sinus thrombosis include early involvement lateral rectus palsy (abducent nerve involvement) since it runs through the cavernous sinus. Oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy occur later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. Other signs are proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in the mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil. Options A- Retinoblastoma occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint. Option B- Orbital pseudotumor presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids. Option C- Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 20-year-old man with a history of repeated pain over the medial canthus and chronic use of nasal decongestants presents to the OPD with high-grade fever and chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On further history, it is noted that the proptosis began in the right eye, and a few days later, the left eye was also affected. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis. Pain over the medial canthus and use of nasal decongestants indicate that the patient was suffering from sinusitis, which can spread to cause orbital cellulitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis, or panopthalmitis. The differentiating feature here is the presentation pattern and bilaterality of the proptosis. In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through intercavernous communication. Also, cavernous sinus thrombosis presents with high-grade fever with chills, rigor, and headache. On the other hand, orbital cellulitis and panophthalmitis are unilateral conditions. Differential diagnosis of acute inflammatory proptosis: Clinical features Cavernous sinus thrombosis Orbital cellulitis Panophthalmitis Laterality Initially unilateral but soon b ecomes bilateral Unilateral Unilateral Vision Not affected in early stage affected Complete loss of vision Cornea and anterior chamber Clear Clear Hazy Edema in the mastoid region Present(Pathognomonic of ca vernous sinus thrombosis) Absent Absent General symptoms with fever and prostration Marked Mild Mild
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Among the following, which muscle is affected first in cavernous sinus thrombosis?
explanation: The first muscle to be affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis is the lateral rectus. Ophthalmoplegia in cavernous sinus thrombosis occurs in the following sequence: 6th nerve palsy (lateral rectus palsy) occurring first of all as it passes through the cavernous sinus. 3rd and 4th nerves are involved later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: MRI of a patient revealed features of right cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient?
options: Constricted right pupil in response to light
explanation: Dilation of the pupil will be seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis due to the involvement of the 3rd cranial nerve.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A 40-year-old male presented with a 1-day history of fever, headache, and bilateral periorbital and mid-facial swelling. He had attempted to burst a furuncle in the inner margin of his right nostril 2 days back. On examination, marked facial and periorbital swelling with chemosis and proptosis are noted. MRI is suggestive of bilateral cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of
the following veins is responsible for this condition?
explanation: Infection from the dangerous area of the face (the area from the corners of the mouth to the bridge of the nose, including the nose and maxilla) spreads to the cavernous sinus via the ophthalmic veins.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A child is brought to the OPD with fever, severe pain, and swelling of the left eye. He was bitten by a dog over the eye a few days back. On examination, there is mild proptosis with restriction of ocular movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of orbital cellulitis. It is the acute inflammation of the soft tissues of the orbit behind the orbital septum. It can occur due to exogenous infection (penetrating injuries) or extension of an endogenous infection (dental infection). It presents with fever, severe pain, and eye swelling which increases with movement, chemosis, axial proptosis, and restriction of ocular movements. Complications include subperiosteal abscess, orbital abscess, cavernous sinus thrombosis, and general septicemia. The image shows orbital cellulitis in the left eye. Option B: Endophthalmitis is defined as the inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball, i.e., uveal tissue and retina, associated with the pouring of exudates into the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber. Option C: Panophthalmitis is an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball, including Tenon’s capsule. Option D: Preseptal cellulitis refers to infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum. In this condition, proptosis is absent and ocular movements are normal.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An 8-year-old child presents with fever and painful swelling of the left eye. He is being treated for acute ethmoiditis for 5 days. On examination, the visual acuity in the left eye is 6/12, there is chemosis, axial proptosis, limitation of ocular motility in all directions, and RAPD. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis of this patient is orbital cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis is the most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children. Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common cause of orbital cellulitis in children. Orbital cellulitis presents with pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis. Decreased ocular motility and elevated intraocular pressure can be seen. Systemic symptoms include malaise and fever. A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve. With posterior exenteration cavernous sinus thrombosis, subdural empyema, and intracranial abscess develop. WARNING SIGNS: Dilated pupil, marked ophthalmoplegia, loss of vision, afferent pupillary defect, papilledema, and violaceous lids.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What is the surgery of choice for panophthalmitis?
explanation: The surgery of choice for panophthalmitis is an evisceration. Evisceration gives a better cosmetic outlook after the surgery and is hence preferred. Enucleation is contraindicated in panophthalmitis due to the risk of meningitis through the exposed meningeal sheath of the optic nerve stump. Some definitions: Evisceration- removal of the contents of the eyeball, leaving behind the sclera. It is done in panophthalmitis. Enucleation- removal of the eyeball, with the maximum part of the optic nerve. Extraocular muscles are left behind. The length of the optic nerve removed is 10 to 15 mm. Absolute indications for enucleation are retinoblastoma and malignant melanoma. Exenteration- mutilating surgery in which all the contents of the orbits along with the periorbita are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading from the eyeball. Debulking- reduction of as much of the bulk (volume) of a tumor as possible. Nowadays, debulking of the orbit is preferred over exenteration.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 72-year-old female presents with normal visual acuity, diminished corneal sensation, and global impairment of ocular motility of the right eye. The patient also has a severe boring headache. The MRI shows an enhancing mass within the right cavernous sinus. The pain and ophthalmoplegia respond dramatically to corticosteroid therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The patient presents with acute ophthalmoplegia with the involvement of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve that responds promptly to steroid therapy. The most likely diagnosis is Tolosa-Hunt syndrome. It is an idiopathic, sterile inflammation that primarily affects the cavernous sinus. It is characterized by painful acute ophthalmoplegia with or without the involvement of the optic nerve and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. The pain is described as gnawing or boring and may precede ophthalmoplegia. The inflammation and pain in patients typically responds rapidly and dramatically to corticosteroid therapy. However, it is a diagnosis of exclusion.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is best made by the dysfunction of which cranial nerve?
explanation: The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is made by the dysfunction of the optic nerve (CN II). The optic nerve passes through the optic canal and does not enter the cavernous sinus. Patients with orbital apex syndrome manifest complete ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, decreased corneal sensation, and vision loss. They usually develop optic nerve signs such as relative afferent pupillary defect. Proptosis is often present, but patients do not always complain of pain.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A patient was being evaluated for retro-orbital pain in the ward. After multiple investigations, he was diagnosed with Tolosa-Hunt syndrome. Which of the following findings will not be seen in this patient?
Sensory loss over forehead
explanation: Ipsilateral lateral rectus palsy due to 6th cranial nerve involvement is seen in Tolosa–Hunt syndrome, not contralateral. Tolosa–Hunt syndrome refers to idiopathic, nonspecific, granulomatous inflammation, involving the superior orbital fissure and/or orbital apex and/or cavernous sinus. It is a unilateral eye condition. Clinically, it manifests as painful ophthalmoplegia and depending on the extent of involvement, it may present as superior orbital fissure syndrome or orbital apex syndrome. Superior orbital fissure syndrome is characterized by the following: Pain, typically labeled as retro-orbital ache Sensory loss/disturbances in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to the involvement of the 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerve involvement Ptosis, due to 3rd nerve paralysis Orbital apex syndrome includes the following: Features of superior orbital fissure syndrome described above Features of optic nerve involvement, i.e., early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect. Strabismus - Introduction, Symptomatology, and Evaluation
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following best describes the actions of the muscle marked in the figure?
explanation: The muscle marked in the above image is the superior oblique. Actions of the superior oblique: Intorsion Depression Abduction Longest extraocular muscle: Superior oblique Shortest extraocular muscle: Inferior oblique The primary action of a muscle is its major effect when the eye is in the primary position. Subsidiary actions are the additional effects; these depend on the position of the eye. The spiral of Tillaux is an imaginary line joining the insertions of the four recti and is an important anatomical landmark when performing surgery.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following pair of muscles are responsible for the intorsion of the eyeball?
explanation: The muscles producing intorsion of the eyeball are the superior rectus and superior oblique. Extorsion of the eyeball is due to the action of the inferior oblique (major) and the inferior rectus muscle.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Name the location of the nucleus supplying the muscle marked by the arrow in the image given below.
explanation: The muscle marked is the medial rectus. The medial rectus is supplied by the oculomotor nerve, the nucleus of which is situated at the level of the superior colliculus in the posterior midbrain. The oculomotor (3rd cranial) nerve nucleus consists of Single central nuclei for the levator palpebrae muscle of both the eyes Bilateral subnuclei with crossed projections supplying the contralateral superior rectus Bilateral subnuclei with uncrossed projections supplying the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, medial rectus in the dorso-ventral order. Bilateral subnuclei known as the Edinger-Westphal nucleus which provides parasympathetic input to the ciliary body and the iris sphincter. Option A: Superior olivary nucleus is an important relay station in the auditory pathway, it is responsible for detection of direction and localization of sound. Option B: Inferior colliculus- The trochlear(4th cranial) nerve nucleus lies in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus. The trochlear nerves leave the midbrain from its posterior surface and decussate before supplying the contralateral superior oblique muscle of the eyeball. Option D: Facial colliculus- the facial colliculus is located in the cranial part of the pons. It is produced by the facial nerve(7th cranial nerve) winding around the nucleus of the abducens nerve (6th cranial nerve).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following pairs constitute yoke muscles?
options: Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR)
Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior oblique (IO)
Right medial rectus (MR) and left medial rectus (MR)
Right medial rectus (MR) and right lateral rectus (LR)
explanation: Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR) are the yoke muscle pair for levodepression. The term "yoke muscles" refers to contralateral synergists. Includes a pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contract simultaneously during version movements. Examples are: Right MR and Left LR for levoversion Right LR and Left MR for dextroversion An easy method to determine other yoke muscle pairs: Just take the opposite of each word- Left  Right Superior  Inferior Oblique  Rectus “Left SO and Right IR” are a yoke muscle pair. Similarly, the following are yoke muscle pairs: Right IO and Left SR - Levoelevation Right SR and Left IO - Dextroelevation Right IR and Left SO - Dextrodepression
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus in dextroversion is the .
explanation: The yoke muscle of the Right lateral rectus in right dextroversion is the left medial rectus. Yoke muscles also known as contralateral synergists include a pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contract simultaneously during version movements. Versions are simultaneous movements of both eyes in the same direction, such as dextroversion in which both the eyes move to the right. Hence, in dextroversion, the right eye is in abduction due to the action of right lateral rectus and the left eye is in adduction by the action of the left medial rectus. An easy method to determine yoke muscle pairs: Just take the opposite of each word- Left  Right Superior  Inferior Oblique  Rectus “Left SO and Right IR” are a yoke muscle pair. Other examples of yoke muscles are: Right MR and Left LR for levoversion Right IO and Left SR - Levoelevation Right SR and Left IO - Dextroelevation Right IR and Left SO - Dextrodepression [IO-inferior oblique;SO-superior oblique;SR-superior rectus;IR-inferior rectus;MR-medial rectus;LR-lateral rectus]
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: During ocular motility, increased flow of innervation to the contracting muscle is accompanied by a decreased flow of innervation to the relaxing antagonist muscle. This statement describes which law?
explanation: The above statement elucidates Sherrington's Law of reciprocal innervation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: You are an intern posted in the ophthalmology department. You are asked to check the cardinal fields of gaze to check the range of extraocular movements. How many cardinal fields are there?
explanation: There are six cardinal positions (fields) of gaze. These are the positions that allow examination of each of the twelve extraocular muscles. They are as follows: Dextroversion (right lateral rectus and left medial rectus) Laevoversion (left lateral rectus and right medial rectus) Dextroelevation (right superior rectus and left inferior oblique) Laevoelevation (left superior rectus and right inferior oblique) Dextrodepression (right inferior rectus and left superior oblique) Laevodepression (left inferior rectus and right superior oblique) Note: There are 3 other positions, namely, normal primary position, supraversion, and infraversion. These are, however, not cardinal positions as the action of the muscles causing these positions can be elicited by the 6 cardinal positions themselves. The image below illustrates the 6 cardinal positions of gaze.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following best defines saccades?
explanation: Saccades are sudden, jerky eye movements that occur as the gaze shifts from one object to another. They are performed to bring the image of an object quickly on the fovea. The image below shows saccadic movement of the eyeball Eye movements that have a supranuclear control: Saccades Pursuits- smooth eye movements Vergence movement system- slow, disconjugate movements Vestibular eye movement- compensate for the effects of head movements Optokinetic system- during sustained head rotation Position maintenance system- consist of rapid micromovements such as flicks and drifts
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An ophthalmologist tests a particular phenomenon using the instrument shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the same?
options: The phenomenon is a physiological one
Frontal lobe controls the slow pursuit movement
Reversal of optokinetic nystagmus, in congenital motor nystagmus
explanation: The given image shows an optokinetic drum used to elicit optokinetic nystagmus (OKN). The parieto-occipital lobe controls the slow pursuit component, whereas the frontal lobes control the saccadic component. OKN is normal physiological nystagmus in response to motion/continuously moving objects. It occurs in response to a repetitive visual stimulus moved across the visual field. The slow phase occurs in the direction of the moving stimulus; the fast phase occurs as a saccadic refixation movement in the opposite direction. In patients with congenital motor nystagmus, a reversal of the OKN response may occur. An OKN response elicited in a person who feigns visual loss indicates that visual input is present and is a malingerer.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is not a nystagmoid movement?
explanation: All are nystagmoid movements except optokinetic. Optokinetic nystagmus is a physiological nystagmus. Nystagmoid movements: Ocular flutter Ocular bobbing Opsoclonus Superior oblique myokymia
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 24-year-old woman presented with progressive diminution of vision, headache, and unsteadiness of gait. A comprehensive clinical evaluation revealed coarse, left-beating nystagmus with leftward gaze and a fine primary-position right-beating nystagmus which increased on rightward gaze, consistent with Brun's nystagmus. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
explanation: Bruns nystagmus is an unusual type of bilateral nystagmus most commonly occurring in patients with cerebellopontine angle tumors. It is caused by the combination of slow, large-amplitude nystagmus (gaze paretic nystagmus) when looking towards the side of the lesion, and rapid, small amplitude nystagmus (vestibular nystagmus) when looking away from the side of the lesion. Option A- Cerebellar lesions and Arnold–Chiari malformation: downbeat nystagmus Options C and D- Arnold–Chiari malformation and demyelination syndromes: periodic alternating nystagmus (left beating nystagmus->null phase->right beating nystagmus->null phase).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is a wrong statement regarding diplopia?
options: Anisometropia is a cause for binocular diplopia.
Crossed diplopia occurs in convergent squint.
Incipient cataract is a cause for uniocular diplopia.
Harmonious diplopia refers to uncrossed binocular diplopia.
explanation: Crossed diplopia is seen in a divergent squint, as in medial rectus paralysis. Binocular diplopia: Simultaneous perception of two images of a single object when seen by both eyes. Causes: Anisometropia Paralysis of extraocular muscles; commonest Mechanical restriction of movements Types: Uncrossed—Harmonious False image on the same side of the deviation Seen in convergent squint Crossed—Unharmonious False image on the opposite side of the deviation Seen in divergent squint Uniocular diplopia: Simultaneous perception of two images of a single object when seen by a single eye. Causes: Subluxated clear lens Subluxated intraocular lens (IOL) Double pupi Incipient cataract Keratoconus
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Hirschberg test is used to detect which of the following?
explanation: The Hirschberg test is used to detect squint. The Hirschberg test gives a rough objective estimate of the angle of manifest strabismus. A pen torch is shone into the eyes from arm’s length, and the patient is asked to fixate on the light. The corneal reflection of the light will be (more or less) centered in the pupil of the fixating eye but will be decentred in a squinting eye, in the direction opposite to that of the deviation. The distance of the corneal light reflection from the center of the pupil is noted; each millimeter of the deviation is approximately equal to 7°.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
As an intern posted in the ophthalmology department, you are performing Hirschberg's test on a patient who is being evaluated for strabismus. The finding observed is shown below.
What is the angle of deviation in this patient?
explanation: From the given image of a Hirschberg test, it can be inferred that the patient has 90 prism dioptres (PD) of exotropia. On the Hirschberg test, if the light reflection is on the nasal limbus, it means 45° exotropia. One degree is equal to 2 PD (prism dioptre). Therefore, 45° exotropia would mean 90 PD exotropia in the right eye.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: You are evaluating a case of strabismus in a 3-year-old child. Which of the following tests would you use to assess binocular single vision?
explanation: Binocular single vision is tested by a synoptophore. Binocular single vision is the state of simultaneous vision, which is achieved by the coordinated use of both eyes so that separate and slightly dissimilar images arising in each eye are appreciated as a single image by the process of fusion. The synoptophore compensates for the angle of squint and allows stimuli to be presented to both eyes simultaneously. It can thus be used to investigate the potential for binocular function in the presence of a manifest squint and is of particular value in assessing young children (from age 3 years), who generally find the test process enjoyable. It can also detect suppression.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which grade of binocular vision does the following image represent?
explanation: The given image depicts Grade II of binocular vision, fusion.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: You are an intern posted in the ophthalmology department where you are observing a patient subjected to the Worth’s four-dot test. The patient is suffering from left suppression. Which of the following images would he most likely see?
explanation: The patient will see 2 red lights as shown in image C as he is suffering from left suppression. Worth's four-dot test is a sensory function test. A box is viewed which has four lights: one red, two green, and one white. The patient has to wear red-green goggles. Inference: A: Normal—All 4 lights seen B: Abnormal retinal correspondence—All 4 lights seen in the presence of manifest squint C: Left Suppression—2 red lights seen D: Right suppression—3 green lights seen E: Diplopia—5 lights seen (2 red, 3 green)
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: While evaluating a case of squint, an ophthalmologist does a forced duction test. What is the use of this test?
explanation: Forced duction test (FDT) is done to find out ocular muscle palsy. It is performed to differentiate between the incomitant squint due to paralysis of the extraocular muscle and that due to the mechanical restriction of the ocular movements. Forced duction test: Positive in cases of incomitant squint due to mechanical restriction Negative in cases of extraocular muscle palsy
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Identify the test being shown below.
explanation: The test shown is the cover - uncover test.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true?
options: Direct cover test is helpful in detecting presence of heterophoria.
Alternate cover test helps to differentiate concomitant squint from paralytic squint.
Cover-uncover test confirms the presence of manifest squint.
In direct cover test, the squinted eye is covered and normal eye is uncovered.
explanation: Alternate cover test helps in differentiating concomitant squint from paralytic squint is a true statement. In a concomitant squint, the eye moves rapidly to fixate, whereas in a paralytic squint, the eye will not move to fixate.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A patient presented to an ophthalmologist with complaints of crowding of words, while reading for long hours. The results of the test that was performed are shown below What is the most likely diagnosis?

Orthophoria
explanation: The given test is a Maddox rod test, and the pattern of the appearance of white dot/light in relation to the red line denotes a case of left eye exophoria. In the given image, the above image refers to the examiner's view and the below image refers to the patient's view. The Maddox rod can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo-deviations. Interpretation: To test for horizontal deviations, the Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye (for this example, the left eye) with the cylinders in the horizontal direction. The patient fixates a point source of light and then sees a vertical red line with the left eye and white dot/light with the right eye: Orthophoria: if the light/dot superimposes the line. Exo-deviation/exophoria: In this example, light/dot is on the left side of the line (rod placed on eft eye) Eso-deviation/esophoria: if the light was on the right side of the line (rod placed on left eye) Maddox Rod Test involves the use of a Maddox rod and the Maddox tangent scale. It uses a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. The optical properties of the cylinders cause the streak of light to be situated 90° to the orientation of the parallel cylinders. In the image given below, the interpretation of the result is based on how the patient visualizes it. It would appear to be crossed to the patient. Pictorial representation of the eyes are as seen by the examiner. Imagine you are looking through a Maddox rod over your left eye while interpreting the images. Strabismus - Types and Treatment
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A child is brought by her parents to the OPD with complaints of crossed eyes as shown below. By doing a simple torchlight test you conclude that the child has pseudostrabismus and the inter-pupillary distance is normal. Which of the following can be associated with the child's condition?
explanation: The child has pseudoesotropia (apparent convergent squint) which is associated with negative angle kappa and epicanthal folds. Pseudostrabismus—apparent squint (visual axes are parallel, but eyes seem to have a squint) Types: Pseudoesotropia Apparent convergent squint Prominent epicanthal fold Negative angle kappa Pseudoexotropia Apparent divergent squint Hypertelorism Positive angle kappa - due to retinopathy of prematurity, hypermetropia Few definitions: Orthophoria- implies perfect ocular alignment in the absence of any stimulus for fusion Heterophoria ("phoria")- implies a tendency of the eyes to deviate when fusion is blocked (latent squint) Heterotropia ("tropia")- implies a manifest deviation in which the visual axes do not intersect at the point of fixation Hypertropia- upward displacement of one eye relative to the other is termed as hypertropia and a latent upward imbalance, a hyperphoria Hypotropia- downward displacement is termed a hypotropia and a latent imbalance, a hypophoria
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A child presents to the OPD with a mild squint. The rest of the history is quite insignificant. On examination, Hirschberg's corneal reflex test is found to be normal. All other eye parameters are also normal except for hypertelorism. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pseudoexotropia. Features of Pseudoexotropia: Normal Hirschberg's corneal reflex test Apparent divergent squint Associated with hypertelorism/a positive angle kappa.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with diplopia?
explanation: Latent squint does not always present with diplopia. Heterophoria (Latent squint) is a condition in which the tendency of the eyes to deviate is kept latent by fusion. When the influence of fusion is removed, the visual axis of one eye deviates away. Types: Esophoria-convergent Exophoria-divergent Hyperphoria-deviation upwards Hypophoria-deviation downwards Cyclophoria-rotation around AP axis Symptoms: Usually asymptomatic-compensated type. In cases where there are symptoms-decompensated type Headache Eye ache Photophobia Intermittent diplopia (only under fatigue – temporarily)
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common type of squint seen in children?
explanation: Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint seen in children. Most common type of squint overall: accommodative esotropia Second most common overall: congenital/Infantile esotropia Most common type of exotropia: primary exotropia
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding comitant squint?
options: No co-relation between primary and secondary deviations
explanation: In comitant squint (concomitant), the primary deviation is equal to the secondary deviation. Primary deviation = Deviation of the squinting eye Secondary deviation = Deviation of the normal eye under cover when the patient fixes with the squinting eye. In incomitant (paralytic and restrictive squint), secondary deviation > primary deviation due to Herring's Law of equal innervation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A mother noticed that her child has had malaligned eyes since birth but she couldn't afford treatment due to financial constraints. She now presents at 2-months of age and the child has the following finding on examination. An ophthalmoscopic examination under full cycloplegia reveals no abnormalities in refraction and media. Cranial nerves are intact. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
options: Angle of deviation is large and constant.
Amblyopia develops in 90 % of the cases.
It is associated with latent vertical nystagmus.
Correction by spectacles is the treatment of choice.
explanation: The age at presentation, esotropia, no refractory error, no media opacities, and no cranial nerve palsies suggest a diagnosis of essential infantile esotropia. The angle of deviation in infantile esotropia is fairly large (> 30°) and constant. Infantile esotropia, also known as non-accommodative esotropia is the most common type of congenital esotropia. Clinical features: Comitant convergent squint Age of onset- 1 to 2 months Angle of deviation- large and constant Amblyopia- develops in 25–40% of cases Associations include: Inferior oblique overaction Dissociated vertical deviation (70%) Latent horizontal nystagmus Treatment: Surgery- treatment of choice Amblyopia correction measures: Patching of normal eye Recession of both medial recti Timing: Preferably before 1 yea
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A surgeon decides to resect a part of a muscle while operating on a case of strabismus. This action would lead to which of the following?
options: No change in strength of the muscle
explanation: In squint surgery, muscle resection leads to the strengthening of the muscle. The main types of procedure in squint surgery are as follows: Weakening to decrease the effective strength of action of a muscle. Recession slackens a muscle by moving it away from its insertion. It can be performed on any muscle except the superior oblique. Disinsertion (or myectomy) involves detaching a muscle from its insertion without reattachment. It is most commonly used to weaken an overacting inferior oblique muscle. Posterior fixation suture: The principle of this (Faden) procedure is to suture the muscle belly to the sclera posteriorly so as to decrease the pull of the muscle in its field of action without affecting the eye in the primary position. Strengthening, to enhance the pull of a muscle. Resection shortens a muscle to enhance its effective pull. It is suitable only for the rectus muscle. Tucking of a muscle or its tendon is usually confined to the enhancement of the action of the superior oblique muscle. Advancement of the muscle nearer to the limbus can be used to enhance the action of a previously recessed rectus muscle. Vector adjustment procedures have the primary aim of altering the direction of muscle action. Transposition refers to the relocation of one or more extraocular muscles to substitute for the action of an absent or severely deficient muscle. The most common indication is severe lateral ectus weakness due to acquired palsy of the 6th cranial nerve palsy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia?
options: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.
explanation: Accommodative esotropia is associated with a high degree of hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D). Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint. Typically presents around 2 to 3 years of age. Types: Refractive Associated with high hypermetropia Fully correctable by spectacles Non-refractive type Abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio Fully corrected by bifocal glasses Miotics useful in cases where glasses are unsuitable Echothiophate causes iris cyst Prevention of iris cysts- Phenylephrine drops Mixed type The accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio is defined as the amount of convergence measured in prism diopters per unit (diopter) change in accommodation. The image below shows accommodative esotropia with and without correction.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is the best line of treatment in a 3-year-old child presenting with a recent onset of 15-degree accommodative esotropia?
explanation: The best line of treatment in accommodative esotropia is a refractive correction. Esotropia for distance is corrected by the treatment of hypermetropia: convex glasses Esotropia for near is corrected by +3DS lens. Algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows: R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: for amblyopia O: Operative correction: for non-accommodative component P: Prism correction: for remaining erro
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Charlie, a 5-year-old boy with crossed eyes received his first eye exam from a primary care ophthalmologist. Examination, including cycloplegic refraction and dilated fundus exam, resulted in diagnoses of constant right esotropia, and amblyopia in the right eye. By what age should his amblyopia be corrected?
explanation: Strabismic amblyopia should be corrected before 8 years of age. The sensitive period during which acuity of an amblyopic eye can be improved is usually up to 7–8 years in strabismic amblyopia and maybe longer (into the teens) for anisometropic amblyopia when a good binocular function is present. In the absence of an organic lesion, a difference in best-corrected visual acuity (VA) of two Snellen lines or more (or >1 log unit) is indicative of amblyopia. Treatment of amblyopia: Occlusion of the normal eye, to encourage the use of the amblyopic eye, is the most effective treatment. Penalization, in which vision in the normal eye is blurred with atropine, is an alternative method.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 5-year-old female patient presented for her first complete eye examination after a school vision screening found unequal visual acuity. Her parents have not noted any eye problems. Visual acuity in the right eye was 20/20 and the left eye is 20/80. The rest of the examination was unremarkable and glasses were prescribed. She was diagnosed with anisometric hyperopia and amblyopia of the left eye when her visual acuity at a return appointment was found to be 20/20 RE and 20/60 LE at a distance while wearing her new glasses. What is the treatment of choice?
explanation: Occlusion of the normal eye is the treatment of choice for amblyopia. Amblyopia is an uncorrectable decrease in vision in one or both eyes with no apparent structural abnormality seen to explain it. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. Generally, a difference of two lines or more on an eye chart test of visual acuity between the two eyes or a best-corrected vision of 20/30 or worse would be defined as amblyopia. For example, our patient has 20/20 vision with the right eye and only 20/80 with the left and the left eye even after best-corrected vision couldn't achieve <20/30 vision, the left eye is said to be amblyopic. Clinical features: Decreased contrast sensitivity Diminution of vision Sunglass effect- brightness is less compared to the normal eye Crowding phenomenon- slipping of images Treatment of choice: Occlusion of the normal eye (4 to 6 hours/day) using patches. Penalization: Blurring of vision using atropine. Prism correction is not the right treatment as the child doesn't have strabismus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 3-year-old child presents with a right convergent squint of 6 months duration. Choose the most appropriate treatment strategy.
options: Immediate surgical correction followed by amblyopia therapy
Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction
Prescription of spectacles and defer surgery until 5 years
Botulinum toxin injection followed by occlusion therapy
explanation: The appropriate management in this case would be proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction The algorithm for management of accommodative squint is as follows: R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: For amblyopia O: Operative correction: For non-accommodative component P: Prism correction: For remaining erro
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In which of the following conditions should an ophthalmologist prescribe miotics?
explanation: Miotics are used in the management of accommodative esotropia. The use of miotics in convergent strabismus is based on the peripheral spasm of accommodation caused by the drug. The accommodation triad involves convergence. An increased accommodative effort increases the amount of convergence. Pilocarpine would produce accommodation spasm and eliminate the accommodative convergence that would otherwise occur when the patient looks at a near object. It is useful in cases of an abnormal AC/A ratio as in, accommodative esotropia.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Paralytic squint presents with all except
explanation: In squint, the deviation of the eye results in two vastly different images. The brain is unable to fuse them. Hence, there is no stereopsis. Features of paralytic squint: Symptoms: Diplopia Confusion Nausea, Vertigo Ocular deviation Signs: Primary deviation < Secondary deviation Compensatory head posture–Ocular torticollis False projection or orientation In adults- no amblyopia In children <6 years- amblyopia can occur

question_text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the ■squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation and a negative forced duction test. The squint may be either comitant or incomitant. Comitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes. Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes. The differences between comitant and incomitant squint are shown in the table below: The incomitant squint is further divided into two main types: Paralytic and restrictive. Paralytic squint occurs due to the paralysis of extraocular muscle while restrictive squint is due to the mechanical restriction caused by tight or fibrosed muscle. Forced duction test(FDT) differentiates between these two types. In this test, the eye is moved mechanically with the help of a forceps. The test is negative if there is no resistance to the movement. It is seen in a paralytic squint. The test is positive if there is resistance to the movement. It is seen in a restrictive squint. question_text: Identify the condition.
explanation: The patient has left eye esotropia in primary gaze which is suggestive of left abducent (6th) nerve palsy which innervates the left lateral rectus muscle.

question_text: A patient complains of difficulty in climbing down the stairs due to double vision. On examination, you notice his right eye has deviated upward and the deviation becomes more pronounced on the left gaze. The remaining extraocular movements are intact. Which nerve is most likely involved?
explanation: The affected nerve in the given clinical scenario is the right trochlear nerve. The right trochlear nucleus actually innervates the left superior oblique and vice versa. However, the nerve decussates at the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus. So, lesions of the trochlear nucleus lead to contralateral palsy. While that of trochlear nerve peripherally lead to ipsilateral palsy. In this patient, the right-sided symptoms could be due to a lesion in the right trochlear nerve (ipsilateral) or left trochlear nucleus (contralateral). He complains of diplopia while climbing down the stairs because the normal eye can look down but the paralytic eye has deviated. There is also a limitation of depression due to superior oblique palsy, and hence the eye is deviated upward due to overaction of the inferior oblique. The obliques exert maximum force in an adducted position and hence the deviation becomes more prominent on the left gaze when the right eye is adducted.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient suffers head trauma following which he complains of diplopia. His extraocular motility testing in the 9 gazes is as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario suggests a left oculomotor nerve palsy. It is evident by the upper lid ptosis and down and out deviation of the left eye, as seen in the primary position of gaze (central image).

question_text:
An 18-year-old destitute woman reports to a free eye camp with vision problems.
Best-corrected visual acuity was 6/12 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left eye. Elevation in the right eye was absent. Her right eye showed 14–16 prism diopter (PD) hypotropia. Bell's phenomenon was absent in the right eye. Diagnosis of right eye double elevator palsy was made. Which of the following muscles are affected in her?
options: Levator palpebrae superioris and Muller muscle
Levator palpebrae superioris and superior rectus
explanation: In double-elevator palsy, the muscles involved are superior rectus and inferior oblique. It is commonly associated with ptosis or pseudoptosis.
