question_text: A patient reports to the OPD with complaints that he feels dizzy on lateral gaze. His range of movements is shown below. Jerky movements are also observed in the left eye on the left gaze however convergence is normal. Which of the following structures is most likely affected?
explanation: Lesion to the medial longitudinal fasciculus causes internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). The right gaze is normal but on the left gaze, there is an inability of right eye adduction and in the left abduction is possible but with nystagmus. This along with normal convergence are all in favor of diagnosis of a lesion in right medial longitudinal fasciculus(MLF) leading to internuclear ophthalmoplegia. INO is seen in multiple sclerosis The image below depicts internuclear ophthalmoplegia due to a lesion of the right MLF. Total ophthalmoplegia All extraocular and intraocular muscles are paralyzed. Paralysis of 3rd, 4th, and 6th nerve Seen in orbital apex syndrome, cavernous sinus thrombosis External ophthalmoplegia All extraocular muscles are paralyzed Lesions at the level of motor nuclei Sparing of Edinger Westphal nucleus
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Identify the condition
explanation: The image shows Duane’s retraction syndrome type 1. Paradoxical innervation of LR where it gets innervated by some fibres of III nerve instead of VI nerve. On impulse for abduction via VI nerve there is no abduction limitation. On impulse for adduction via III nerve both LR and MR contract thus causing retraction of globe (as the antagonist LR instead of relaxation, starts to contract) Duane’s retraction syndrome (DRS) is a cause of restrictive squint There is a failure of innervation of the lateral rectus by a hypoplastic sixth nerve nucleus, with anomalous innervation of the lateral rectus by fibers from the third nerve. Retraction of the globe on attempted adduction. Widening of palpebral fissure on attempted abduction Classification by Huber: Limitation of abduction- type 1 Limitation of adduction- type 2 Limitation of both- type 3 Note: DRS is an exception to Sherrington's law of reciprocal innervation.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An eleven-year-old girl presented with a history of squint and poor vision. She had visual acuities of 6/24 and counting fingers in her right and left eyes respectively. There was a left hypotropia in the primary position of gaze with associated marked restriction of elevation in adduction and a positive forced duction test. A diagnosis of Brown syndrome was made. The pathology involves which of the following muscles?
explanation: Brown syndrome occurs due to mechanical restriction caused by a congenitally tight superior oblique sheath or by the impaired movement of the superior oblique tendon through the trochlea. It may be acquired in some cases. Contracture of the superior oblique leads to restriction of its antagonistic muscle, the inferior oblique and that is why the patient presents with absence of elevation in adduction.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Brown’s syndrome simulates which muscle palsy?
explanation: Brown’s superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome simulates palsy of inferior oblique muscle. In both of these cases, there is a limited elevation of the eye in adduction. Brown’s superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome is a cause of restrictive squint.The forced duction test is positive. Differential diagnoses of Brown's syndrome: Inferior oblique palsy- differentiated by a positive head-tilt test (negative in Brown's syndrome) and a negative forced duction test (positive in Brown's syndrome) Primary superior oblique overaction- differentiated by negative forced duction test (Positive in Brown's syndrome)
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Identify the condition.
explanation: The given image classically depicts an A pattern esotropia. Relative convergence on upgaze (esotropia increases on upgaze) is a feature of A-pattern esotropia. A or V pattern heterotropia: "V" or "A" patterns occur when the relative contributions of the superior rectus and inferio oblique to elevation, or of the inferior rectus and superior oblique to depression, are abnormal, esulting in the derangement of the balance of their horizontal vectors in up and downgaze. Oblique muscle dysfunction is the commonest "V" pattern is said to be significant when the difference between upgaze and downgaze is 15 . "A" pattern is considered significant if the difference between upgaze and downgaze is 10 . The image below shows A and V pattern heterotropia
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia. This increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved?
Right superior oblique
explanation: Right superior rectus palsy is the cause for the given clinical scenario. The three-step test, also known as the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, is a diagnostic test used to identify which muscle is paralyzed in the case of an acquired hypertropia. This method uses the cover-uncover test, with or without the Maddox rod to measure the amount of deviation in different head positions. The three-step test may also be used to diagnose the less common inferior oblique or vertical rectus muscle palsy. It is designed for the diagnosis of a single paretic vertical muscle and is unreliable when there are multiple paretic muscles or in restrictive strabismus. This test may also help in identifying if a superior rectus palsy is true or simulated in a patient with an inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist. Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario: Step 1. Which eye is hypotrophic? The eye hypotrophic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eye elevator or left eye depressor. Right superior rectus Right inferior oblique Left inferior rectus Left superior oblique Step 2.Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze? The hypotropia increases in right gaze. Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action is elevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action is depressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectus both have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be the paretic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primary action of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique and the right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible paretic muscles. This leaves us: Left superior oblique Right superior rectus Step 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt? The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt and decreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus is implicated as the paretic culprit. Disorders of Visual Pathway and Pupillary Reflexes
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following forms the third-order neurons in the visual pathway?
explanation: Third-order neurons in the visual pathway are the ganglion cells. The afferent neuronal impulses are carried in the following manner: Photoreceptors (I)  Bipolar cells (II)  Ganglion cells (III)  Lateral geniculate body (IV).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 41-year-old woman with a known pituitary microadenoma presented with sudden-onset visual disturbances, headache, and hypotension during the second trimester of pregnancy. What is the visual field defect this patient is most likely to experience?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pituitary apoplexy in pregnancy This acute onset event is almost always associated with compression at the level of optic chiasma causing heteronymous hemianopia (bitemporal hemianopia). Pituitary apoplexy results from hemorrhagic infarction of a pre-existing pituitary adenoma or within a physiologically enlarged gland, which is well documented in pregnancy. The nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma. Slow-growing microadenomas compress lower nasal optic fibers causing superior temporal quadrantanopia initially, before progressing to bitemporal hemianopia. However, an abrupt infarction or hemorrhage of a pre-existing pituitary adenoma will lead to rapid progression of the visual defect. Heteronymous hemianopia is the loss of half of the visual field on different sides in both eyes. It is separated into two categories: Binasal hemianopia – the loss of the fields surrounding the nose Bitemporal hemianopia – the loss of the fields closest to the temples. Common causes of bitemporal hemianopia due to central chiasmal lesions are as follows: Suprasellar aneurysms Tumors of the pituitary gland Craniopharyngioma Suprasellar meningioma Glioma of the third ventricle Other visual defects according to the site of the lesion are as follows:
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following cannot be tested with monocular visual field testing using a pin with a red pinhead?
explanation: Central scotoma, paracentral scotoma and temporal field defects can be tested by monocular visual field testing with a red-headed neurological pin. A patient who has central scotoma will either not see the pinhead in the centre of the field or perceive it black. This can be defined by moving the pin outwards in four different directions until the patient sees the pinhead as being red. Placing the pin in each of the quadrants close to the centre and checking if the patient sees the red pinhead can detect a paracentral scotoma. This can also detect temporal field defects.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A lesion in which of the following structures is most likely to result in congruous homonymous hemianopia?
explanation: Congruous homonymous hemianopia is most suggestive of a lesion in the occipital cortex. Homonymous hemianopia involves vision loss on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. This type of visual field loss is suggestive of a lesion posterior to the optic chiasma in the visual pathway. Complete homonymous hemianopia involves the complete visual hemifields of both eyes and can occur with any large enough lesion posterior to the optic chiasma. Visual field examination alone cannot further localize the lesion in such cases. Incomplete homonymous hemianopia is due to smaller lesions in the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasm. They are further divided into congruous and incongruous depending on the extent to which the defects in the two half fields match each other exactly. Because of a relative disorder among axon bundles in the immediate post-chiasmal region, diseases in this location produce rather incongruent lesions. More posteriorly, the axon bundles of the corresponding areas of the two hemifields are more closely aligned and hence, lesions of the occipital cortex produce congruous homonymous hemianopia while incongruous homonymous hemianopia is more likely seen with optic tract lesions.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a persistent headache for the past few months. On evaluation, her vision on Snellen's chart was 6/6 in both eyes. The fundus also appears to be normal. Visual field charting shows a bitemporal visual field defect. Site of the lesion is
explanation: The site of the lesion is optic chiasma. Lesions at the chiasma characteristically produce bitemporal field defects due to the decussation of nasal fibres. In retrochiasmal lesions, homonymous hemianopia is seen. Further, in cortical lesions, macular (central) vision is spared.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A young patient with visual disturbances was found to have a brain tumour. He was referred to ophthalmology for a complete visual field assessment before planning his resection.
Humprey analyzer revealed the following plot. What is the most likely site of the lesion?
explanation: The visual field defect shown is the typical "pie in the sky" defect or superior quadrantic hemianopia. They are produced when the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe (Meyer's loop) are involved. "Pie in the floor" defects refer to inferior quadrantic hemianopia. It is seen in the involvement of the superior fibers of optic radiations in the parietal lobe (Baum's loop).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The primary visual cortex is located in the .
explanation: The primary visual cortex( Brodmann area 17) is located in the posterior part of the calcarine sulcus in the occiptal lobe. Accessory visual areas are area 18 (secondary) and area 19 (tertiary). Image: Brodman areas
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 72-year-old lady was brought by her son with bilateral loss of vision for 3 days, associated with slurred speech. It was preceded by an occipital headache. Despite her obvious blindness, illustrated by her walking into objects, the patient denied visual loss. MRI revealed bilateral occipital infarcts. Which of the following statement is true regarding the given condition?
options: Direct and consensual reflexes are absent in both eyes.
Direct and consensual reflexes are present in both eyes.
Direct reflex is present but consensual reflex is absent.
Consensual reflex is present but direct reflex is absent.
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cortical blindness with visual anosognosia (Anton syndrome). Since anterior visual pathways are not affected in cortical blindness, direct and consensual light reflexes are preserved. Cortical blindness is usually associated with bilateral occipital infarcts where it is supplied by the posterior cerebral arteries and these infarcts usually involve both the primary visual cortex and visual association area. It is secondary to damage to the visual pathways posterior to the lateral geniculate nuclei; anterior visual pathways are intact. Visual field defects can vary depending on the extent and location of the infarct. Direct and consensual reflexes are present in both eyes in cortical blindness as pupillary light reflex fibers exit the visual pathway at the level of the superior colliculus. They exit the optic tract before the lateral geniculate body (LGB) to reach the center for pupillary light reflex- pretectal nucleus at the midbrain. Note: Anton syndrome is visual anosognosia (denial of loss of vision) associated with confabulation (defined as the emergence of memories of events and experiences which never took place) in the setting of obvious visual loss and cortical blindness.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A neurology resident is demonstrating spinal reflexes in a comatose patient. When he pinches the skin over the side of the patient's neck, there is a rapid dilatation of the ipsilateral pupil. Which of the following forms the efferent limb of this reflex?
explanation: The given scenario describes cilio-spinal reflex. Sympathetic fibers of cervical ganglion form the efferent limb of this reflex. Cilio-spinal reflex: Afferent inputs of this reflex are carried by the trigeminal nerve or cervical pain fibers (latera spinothalamic tract). It synapses at the ciliospinal center of Budge, located at C8 to T2 in the intermediolateral (IML) horn of the gray matter of the spinal cord. The efferent branch of the reflex consists of: Preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the upper thoracic and lower cervical spinal cord which goes to the cervical sympathetic chain and its three ganglia. The postganglionic sympathetic fibers pass on the surface of the internal carotid artery and join the ophthalmic nerve at the cavernous sinus. Here, it passes through the nasociliary nerve to reach the ciliary body and innervates the dilator pupillae muscles, causing dilatation of the pupil. This reflex is absent in Horner's syndrome and in lesions involving the cervical sympathetic fibers and it is enhanced in patients with cluster headache and barbiturate-induced coma.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is not part of the pupillary light reflex pathway?
explanation: The lateral geniculate body is not a part of the pupillary reflex pathway. It is part of the accommodation reflex and the visual pathway. Pupillary light reflex pathway: First neurons (sensory) connects each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the evel of the superior colliculi. Second neurons (internuncial) connects each pretectal nucleus to both Edinger–Westphal nuclei. Third neurons (preganglionic motor) connects the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion. Fourth neurons (postganglionic motor) leaves the ciliary ganglion and passes in the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae. Image: Pupillary reflex pathways
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A patient presented with diplopia to the casualty. On examination, the left pupil was dilated. Both direct and consensual light reflexes were lost in the affected eye. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical situation suggests that the patient has III nerve (oculomotor nerve) palsy. Absence of contraction of the pupil in both direct and consensual reflex suggests a lesion in the efferent pathway of the affected eye. This is III nerve/oculomotor palsy. Light reflex consists of direct and consensual reflexes. When light is shone in an eye, Constriction of the pupil of the same eye is called direct reflex. Constriction of the contralateral pupil is called consensual reflex/indirect reflex For the light reflex, Afferent nerve fiber is the II cranial nerve (optic nerve). Efferent nerve fiber is the III cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve)-Bilaterally In II nerve palsy, there will be a loss of direct reflex in the affected eye and loss of consensual light reflex in the opposite eye.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago. Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the following will be seen on exposure of his pupils to light?
options: Pupils react but do not accommodate.
Pupils accommodate but do not react.
explanation: The patient most likely has acquired syphilis due to unprotected sex and has developed neurological and visual disturbances secondarily as a complication of neurosyphilis. Argyll-Robertson pupils(ARP) are seen associated with neurosyphilis where the pupils accommodate but do not react to light. Argyll Robertson pupil is attributed to a dorsal midbrain lesion of neurosyphilis that affects the pupillary light pathway but spares the more ventrally placed pupillary near reflex pathway(Accomdation pathway), thereby causing a light-near dissociation. Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) include: Bilateral small, irregular pupils in dim light Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP)- The eye accomdates by constricting the pupil for a near target. Light Reflex absent: pupils do not constrict when exposed to bright light. Cocaine eye drops(mydriatics) induced mydriasis. Other clinical features in neurosyphilis: Fleeting and repetitive lancinating pains, primarily in the legs acute abdominal pain with vomiting(visceral crisis) Tabes dorsalis with Ataxia and gait disturbances due to loss of position sense Loss of reflexes in the legs Paresthesias, bladder disturbances Other causes of light-near dissociation are: In unilateral eye Adie pupi Herpes zoster ophthalmicus Aberrant regeneration of the third cranial nerve In bilateral eyes Neurosyphilis Type 1 diabetes mellitus Myotonic dystrophy Note: Adie's pupil more commonly manifests in young women with unilateral large regular pupil(Anisocoria) with absent light reflex and sluggish and tonic accomdation reflex. It is caused by post-ganglionic parasympathetic pupillary supply damage and is usually associated with absent knee jerk. Adie's pupil constricts with weak pilocarpine (0.1%) drops, while normal pupil and Argyll robertson pupil does not.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following would you suspect in a patient who presents with small pupils?
explanation: Pontine hemorrhage is associated with small pupils. The remaining options, namely, carbon monoxide poisoning, ethylene glycol poisoning, and Holmes–Adie pupil, cause dilation of the pupils.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 67-year-old woman finally decides to get glasses, about thirty years after she actually needed them, and goes to an optometrist for an eyeglass prescription. Her eye examination reveals some unexpected findings. The pupils were small. When a pen-light is shone on to her eyes, neither pupil contracts. However, when the optometrist brings his fingers towards her face, both pupils constrict dramatically. What is the given condition?
explanation: The given clinical situation of bilateral small irregular pupils with light-near dissociation suggests a diagnosis of Argyll Robertson pupil. Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP): Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP) Light Reflex absent Constricted pupi An example of light near dissocation. Seen in neurosyphilis Option A: Anisocoria is when the pupils are not of the same size. Option B: Adie's tonic pupi Light reflex absent or sluggish. Near reflex: Slow and tonic Pupil is larger Constricts with weak pilocarpine. Option C: Ophthalmoplegia interna Dilated paralyzed pupi Does not respond to light or accommodation
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is due to a lesion in the .
explanation: Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is due to a lesion in the optic tract. The optic tracts contain both visual and pupillomotor fibers. The visual fibers terminate in the lateral geniculate body, but the pupillary fibers leave the optic tract anterior to the lateral geniculate body, projecting through the brachium of the superior colliculus to terminate in the pretectal nuclei. An optic tract lesion may, therefore, give rise to an afferent pupillary conduction defect. Characteristically, the pupillary light reflex will be normal when the unaffected hemiretina is stimulated and absent, when the involved hemiretina is stimulated (i.e., light is shone from the hemianopic side).
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma?
explanation: Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage. Marcus Gunn pupil also known as relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease as seen in optic nerve neuritis or primary open-angle glaucoma(POAG). RAPD is caused due to a defect in the afferent pathway (optic nerve) of the pupillary light reflex in one eye. It is diagnosed by the swinging flashlight test where the flashlight is swung to and fro, and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils constrict when any one eye is stimulated (due to direct and consensual light reflex). In the presence of RAPD, both pupils will abnormally dilate when the affected eye is stimulated. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil. Causes of RAPD: Optic nerve lesions (e.g.All types of optic neuritis, glaucoma) Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction) Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment) Maculopathy (macular degeneration ) Other options: Option B: Adie tonic pupil is a unilateral dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor nerve supply damage. In these patients the light reflex is absent and the accomdation (near) reflex is sluggish. It is commonly seen in young females and is associated with absent knee jerk. Option C: Argyll Robertson pupils are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation. It is commonly seen in patients with neurosyphilis. In these patients the pupillary reflex is absent but the accommodation reflex is present (ARP). Option D: Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial mass lesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The casualty intern noticed that a patient had unequal pupils. The anisocoria was greater under light. Which of the following drugs would be helpful in quickly differentiating between the potential causes?
explanation: Anisocoria greater in the light indicates the large pupil to be abnormal due to poor pupillary contraction from a parasympathetic abnormality. Among the given options, 1% pilocarpine and 0.1% pilocarpine can be used to differentiate fixed dilated pupil. Mydriasis due to neurologic origin (3rd nerve palsy) responds readily to 1% pilocarpine, whereas there will be no response if the dilation is due to anticholinergic causes. Pupillary constriction to 0.1% pilocarpine diagnoses Adie's pupil (due to denervation hypersensitivity). Application of 0.1% pilocarpine shows no response in other conditions or in the normal eye. Example: A person presenting with dilated pupil following accidental application or inadvertent rubbing of atropine or antimuscarinic alkaloids from wild plants into the eye will not constrict in response to topical application of 1% Pilocarpine. But the patient showing dilation due to 3rd nerve palsy shows pupillary constriction in response to pupillary instillation of 1% pilocarpine. Note: Cocaine and phenylephrine are used in anisocoria that is greater in the dark to diagnose Horner’s syndrome. In these patients, the small pupil fails to dilate even after the instillation of cocaine.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 55-year-old lady with advanced spondylosis underwent cervical vertebral fusion surgery. In the post-operative room, the resident noted that her pupils were unequal. Which of the following features would rule out the possibility of Horner's syndrome in this patient?
explanation: Horner's syndrome causes all the following except mydriasis. It causes miosis. Horner's syndrome (oculosympathetic palsy) The majority of the cases are unilateral. Causes of bilateral involvement include cervical spine injuries and autonomic diabetic neuropathy. Painful Horner syndrome, especially of acute onset, should raise the possibility of carotid dissection. Clinical features Mild ptosis (usually 1–2 mm) as a result of weakness of Müller muscle Anisocoria is accentuated in dim light Pupillary constriction to light and near stimuli is normal. Hypochromic heterochromia (lighter color iris on affected side); in congenital cases. Mild ptosis (Mullers muscle is affected) Reduced ipsilateral sweating (only if the lesion is below the superior cervical ganglion) Pharmacological tests Hydroxyamphetamine and adrenaline may be used to differentiate a preganglionic from a postganglionic lesion. Phenylepherine (1%) Result: In an established (10 days) postganglionic lesion, the Horner pupil will dilate and ptosis may be temporarily relieved. A central or preganglionic Horner pupil and a normal pupil will not dilate or will dilate minimally. Explanation: In postganglionic Horner's syndrome, the dilator pupillae muscle develops denervation hypersensitivity to adrenergic neurotransmitters due to its dysfunctional local motor nerve. Apraclonidine (0.5% or 1.0%) Result: A Horner pupil will dilate, but a normal pupil is essentially unaffected. Explanation: Alpha-1 receptors are upregulated in the denervated dilator pupillae. Cocaine (4%) is instilled into both eyes Result: The normal pupil will dilate, but the Horner pupil will not. Explanation: Cocaine blocks the re-uptake of noradrenaline secreted at the postganglionic nerve ending, which accumulates and causes dilatation of a normal pupil. In Horner's syndrome, there is no noradrenaline being secreted, so cocaine has no effect.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Where is the cell body of the second-order neuron in the sympathetic pathway for the pupil?
explanation: The cell body of the second-order neuron in the sympathetic pathway for the pupil lies at the ciliospinal center of Budge (C8–T1). The sympathetic pathway to the iris muscles consists of a chain of three neurons: The first neuron arises from the hypothalamus along the brain stem to synapse in the intermediolateral column of the spinal cord—the ciliospinal center of Budge (C8-T1). From here (C8-T1), the second-order neuron arises. This joins the cervical sympathetic chain and synapses at the superior cervical ganglion. The third-order neuron arises from the superior cervical ganglion and travels through the cavernous sinus along with the internal carotid artery. Sympathetic fibers join the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve and pass through the ciliary ganglion to the nasociliary and short ciliary nerves.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A simultaneous lesion in both sympathetic and parasympathetic supply of the eye leads to which of the following?
options: Mydriatic pupil that reacts to light
Constricted pupil that reacts to light
Mid-sized pupil that doesn’t react to light
Mid-sized pupil that reacts to light
explanation: Simultaneous lesion in both sympathetic and parasympathetic supply of the eye leads to mid-sized pupil that doesn’t react to light. Pupillary dilation is achieved by sympathetic innervation of dilator pupillae. Therefore, any lesion of the sympathetic supply of the pupil leads to constricted pupil. Pupillary constriction is a parasympathetic function. Lesions in this pathway leads to dilated pupil and failure to constrict. A mid-sized unreactive pupil due to a lesion of both parasympathetic and sympathetic supplies is seen in aneurysms of the internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: During the neurological examination of a patient, on shining light in his left eye, the left pupil does not constrict but the right pupil does. On shining light in his right eye, the right pupil constricts and left doesn’t. The defect is in:
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of left eye efferent (oculomotor nerve) defect. The loss of pupillary light reflex (both direct and consensual) in the left eye associated with a preserved direct pupillary response in the right eye is characteristic of an efferent pupillary defect.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common feature of third nerve palsy, in a case of long-standing, uncontrolled diabetes?
explanation: The most common feature seen in diabetic oculomotor palsy among the given options is ptosis. In the anatomical arrangement of the nerve fibers of the 3rd cranial nerve, the fibers controlling the pupillary reflex are present superficially and are thus spared from diabetic ischemia-induced injury which starts from the central nerve fibres. Thus, pupil sparing is commonly seen in diabetic patients. The etiology of diabetic neuropathy is hyperglycemia-induced damage to nerve cells and neuronal ischemic change due to microvascular angiopathy. Involvement of the third cranial nerve is most common and it often presents with early features of ptosis and diplopia with pupil sparing. The involvement of levator palpebrae superioris muscle of the eyelid manifests as ptosis and the involvement of extraocular muscles such as medial rectus,inferior rectus and inferior oblique presents as opthalmoplegia with diplopia. All the muscles mentioned above are supplied by the Occulomotor nerve. Note: Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery is an important cause of isolated third nerve palsy with involvement of the pupil. This is because the aneurysm impinges on the superficial pupil nerve fibres of the 3rd cranial nerve.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 60-year-old man was brought to the OPD by his daughter with complaints of drooping of his left eyelid and double vision. The pupillary examination was normal. What is the likely cause?
explanation: Ptosis and double vision with no other features suggest an acquired, isolated 3rd nerve palsy with pupillary sparing. This is seen in ischemic conditions such as diabetes. The vasoneurium supplies the nerve from outside to inside. As the somatic fibres are located in the inner part of the nerve, these fibres are affected more in the setting of ischemia. The parasympathetic pupillary fibres which run on the outside can remain unaffected (resulting in pupillary sparing). In compressive lesions, the parasympathetic fibres are affected before any disruption of the motor fibres. So pupillary sparing is not seen. Isolated 3rd nerve palsy Causes Microvascular disease associated with systemic risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes is the most common cause of third nerve palsy. Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery at its junction with the internal carotid, both direct and secondary to subdural hematoma with uncal herniation. Episodic- migraine, compression, ischemia, and alterations in intracranial pressure Miscellaneous- tumour and inflammatory diseases such as syphilis, Lyme disease, and sarcoidosis; giant cell arteritis; and vasculitis associated with collagen vascular disorders. Signs Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out") Normal abduction as the lateral rectus is intact Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness Limited elevation due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
The patient presented with the following appearance when asked to look straight. What is the probable diagnosis?

3rd nerve palsy
explanation: The above image shows adduction of the right eye due to paralysis of the right lateral rectus, indicating right abducens (6th) nerve palsy. The nucleus of the sixth (abducens or abducent) nerve lies at the mid-level of the pons. Nuclear lesion: A nuclear sixth nerve lesion also causes the failure of horizontal gaze towards the side of the damage due to the involvement of the adjacent horizontal gaze center (paramedian pontine reticular formation). Foville (inferior medial pontine) syndrome is most frequently caused by vascular disease or tumors involving the dorsal pons. It is characterized by the following: Ipsilateral involvement of the fifth to eighth cranial nerves Central sympathetic fibers (Horner syndrome) Horizontal gaze palsy Millard–Gubler (ventral pontine) syndrome involves the fasciculus as it passes through the pyramidal tract. As well as ipsilateral sixth nerve palsy, there is contralateral hemiplegia and often an ipsilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) facial nerve palsy. Clinical features: Esotropia in the primary position due to relatively unopposed action of the medial rectus Limitation of abduction on the side of the lesion Normal adduction of the affected eye A compensatory face turn is towards the side of the paralyzed muscle in unilateral palsy Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: The longest part of the optic nerve measures .
explanation: Intraorbital part is the longest part of the optic nerve. It measures from 25 mm to 30 mm. Length of the optic nerve ranges from 3.5 cm to 5.5 cm. 80% of the fibers originate from the macular region. Parts of optic nerve: Parts Lengt h Intraocular part 1 mm Intraorbital part 25–3 0 mm Intracanalicular part 5–9m m Intracranial part 10–16 mm
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of papilledema?
explanation: Disruption of neurofilaments is not a feature of papilledema. Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head secondary to raised intracranial pressure (ICP). "Disc swelling" and "disc edema" are non-specific terms that include papilledema but also indicate a disc swollen from other causes. All patients with papilledema should be suspected of harboring an intracranial mass. Features of papilledema: Raised ICP Edema of the optic nerve head Blockage of axoplasmic flow Axonal swelling Collection of extracellular fluid Painless progressive loss of vision Enlargement of the blind spo Color vision, visual acuity, and pupillary reaction are normal, until optic atrophy sets in.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A resident notes the following fundus picture in a patient referred to the ophthalmology OPD with visual complaints. What does it suggest?
explanation: The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive of papilledema. Ophthalmoscopic features of papilledema: Early-stage: Obscuration of the disc margins (nasal margins first) Absence of spontaneous venous pulsation at the disc Mild hyperemia of the disc The blurring of the peripapillary nerve fiber layer Established papilledema: The disc appears to be enlarged and elevated (mushroom or dome-shaped) Macular fan appears Paton’s lines- circumferential greyish white folds may develop due to the separation of nerve fibers Visual fields show enlargement of the blind spo Veins become tortuous and engorged Multiple cotton-wool spots and superficial hemorrhages Chronic or long-standing (vintage) papilledema: The optic disc gives the appearance of the dome of a champagne cork Small drusen-like crystalline deposits (corpora amylacea) may appear on the disc surface Atrophic stage: Secondary optic atrophy
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following conditions show ipsilateral optic atrophy and contralateral papilledema?
explanation: Ipsilateral optic atrophy and contralateral papilledema are seen in Foster–Kennedy syndrome. Weber syndrome (superior alternating hemiplegia) is a form of stroke characterized by the presence of an ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia. Millard–Gubler syndrome is a lesion of the pons. It is also called ventral pontine syndrome. Benedikt syndrome, also known as paramedian midbrain syndrome, involves the fasciculus of oculomotor nerve as it passes through the red nucleus and is characterized by ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral extrapyramidal signs such as hemitremor.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination, the eye is white and there are no obvious signs on ophthalmoscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis. There are 3 types of optic neuritis: papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis. The common causes of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease). Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss. Ocular movements are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be impaired. On examination, Marcus Gunn pupil or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is usually noted due to asymmetric involvement. The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecal scotoma. The image below shows papillitis. Type Retrobulbar neuritis Papillitis Neuroretinitis Pathology Inflammation of the optic n erve behind the disc Inflammation of the optic n erve head Inflammation of the optic n erve head and the macula Fundus appearanc e Optic disc appears normal Hyperemia and oedema of the optic disc with or witho ut peri-papillary flame-sha ped hemorrhages Macular star (due to exudat es that form around macul a) Prevalence Most common in adults Most common in children Least common type Associated conditio ns Strong association with de myelinating disorders like MS, NMO Weak association with dem yelinating disorders Cat-scratch disease, Lyme disease, Syphilis etc. The image below shows macular star appearance in neuroretinitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 33-year-old patient has come to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints that her vision becomes temporarily blurry after a hot bath in the evening. This resolves by itself after a few hours. She has a past history of an episode of painful unilateral optic neuritis, 3 months back which resolved with steroids. What is being described here?
explanation: Episodic, transient obscuration of vision on exertion or on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat in an isolated optic neuritis patient is called Uhthoff phenomenon. It is commonly associated with multiple sclerosis (MS). Option A: Pulfrich’s phenomenon is an illusion of depth perception. It is seen in MS. Option C: Lhermitte’s sign refers to passive neck flexion causing an electric shock-like sensation radiating to the spine and shoulders. This is a result of the increased sensitivity of the myelin to stretch or traction; it is also seen in MS. Option D: Riddoch phenomenon refers to ability to perceive kinetic but not static targets. It is seen in cortical blindness.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In a patient with multiple sclerosis, which of the following visual field defects is most likely?
explanation: Central scotoma is more likely to occur with multiple sclerosis. It is also seen with retrobulbar neuritis and macular pathology. Option A: Optic chiasma compression causes bitemporal hemianopia Option C: Enlarged blind spot occurs with papilloedema Option D: Tunnel vision occurs in glaucoma, retinitis pigmentosa and Retinal pan photocoagulation
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Optic neuritis is a common presentation in which of the following diseases?
explanation: One of the common presentations of MS is optic neuritis. Multiple sclerosis (MS) results from demyelinating plaques in the central nervous system. Option A: Myasthenia gravis is the autoimmune destruction of the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. Option B: Guillain–Barré syndrome is the postinfectious autoimmune-induced destruction of peripheral nerves, resulting in an ascending paralysis. Option D: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a disease of the motor nerve fibers of the lateral columns and anterior horns of the spinal cord that results in progressive muscular atrophy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with steroids. She also has a history of transverse myelitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical vignette of a patient presenting with decreased visual acuity and a history of transverse myelitis which is treated with steroids is indicative of Neuromyelitis optica (NMO). Neuromyelitis optica also known as Devic's disease is an autoimmune demyelinating disease in which antibodies are formed against Aquaporin 4 present in the cell membranes of Astrocytes. It is characterized by the findings of unilateral or bilateral optic neuritis developing within a few weeks of transverse myelitis(demyelination of the spinal cord). The disease may be monophasic or recurrent. Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD): Diagnostic Criteria for NMOSD associated with AQP4-IgG At least 1 core clinical characteristic A positive test for AQP4-IgG using the best available detection method (cell-based assay) Exclusion of alternative diagnoses Core Clinical Characteristics: Optic neuritis is usually bilateral and causes severe visual loss. Acute myelitis- may be severe, transverse and typically longitudinally extensive involving three or more contiguous vertebral segments. Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting Acute brainstem syndrome Symptomatic narcolepsy associated with NMOSD-typical diencephalic MRI lesions For acute cases of NMO, high-dose glucocorticoids or plasma exchange is used. Mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, and glucocorticoids with azathioprine are used for prophylaxis against relapses. The FDA has approved satralizumab, a humanized IgG2 monoclonal antibody, for the treatment of NMO spectrum disorder with AQP4 antibody positivity. Eculizumab, a complement inhibitor, and inebilizumab, a B-cell depletion agent, are two more new drugs that have recently been approved for use in NMO attack prevention. A history of transverse myelitis with optic neuritis(decreased visual acuity) rules out Multiple sclerosis(option D). It is an autoimmune inflammatory and demyelinating disease of the CNS that affects both upper motor neurons (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN) with involvement of sensory system, ocular system and bowel and bladder function. Ocular manifestations of MS include Optic neuritis(usually retrobulbar)- decreased visual acuity, internuclear ophthalmoplegia and nystagmus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A middle-aged man with suspected optic neuropathy is being evaluated for visual field defects. Goldman perimetry reveals bilateral centrocecal scotomas. Which of the following is most likely to be the causative agent?
explanation: Centrocecal scotoma is most commonly seen in tobacco-induced amblyopia. It is also seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. Tobacco amblyopia is caused by excessive smoking and chewing of tobacco. The toxic agent involved is cyanide found in tobacco. It is characterized by bilateral and gradually progressive impairment of central vision. The classic visual field defect is a centrocecal scotoma, often involving both the blind spot and the macula. Option B: Ethanol amblyopia is similar to tobacco amblyopia but often presents with peripheral neuritis and a "central scotoma". Option C: Methanol amblyopia often results in complete blindness. Option D: Quinine amblyopia results in near-complete blindness with associated deafness and tinnitus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: An anxious, young man came to the ER with complaints of having sudden trouble seeing with his left eye and a recent history of tripping over things. There was no associated pain or difficulty moving the eyes. An ophthalmology consultation was requested. On perimetry, the following visual field defect was picked up. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The perimetry result depicts altitudinal hemianopia, which is most commonly seen in anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION). Altitudinal hemianopia can also be seen in suprasellar tumors and occipital lobe lesions, but the frequency is very low compared to that of AION. Hence, AION is the single best answer. The two types of AION are as follows: Arteritic AION- caused by giant-cell arteritis Non-arteritic AION (NAAION)- more common Clinical features: Note: Corticosteroids are not proven to be effective in NAAION. The image given below shows pale disc edema of Arteritic AION. subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: What does the given fundoscopic picture suggest?
explanation: The given fundoscopic image clearly depicts cupping, thinning of the neuroretinal rim, and nasal shifting of vessels. This are characteristic of glaucomatous optic atrophy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with optic atrophy?
explanation: Leprosy is not associated with optic atrophy. All the other given conditions can cause optic atrophy. Causes of optic atrophy: Primary optic atrophy Optic neuritis Compression by tumors and aneurysms Hereditary optic neuropathies Toxic and nutritional optic neuropathies Trauma Secondary optic atrophy Chronic papilledema Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy Papillitis Consecutive optic atrophy Extensive retinal photocoagulation Retinitis pigmentosa Prior central retinal artery occlusion Glaucomatous optic atrophy
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 24-year-old man with a history of pernicious anemia was referred to ophthalmology for complaints of gradually progressing visual disturbances. On perimetry, which of the following defects is most likely to be seen in him?
explanation: The given scenario of pernicious anemia with gradually progressive visual disturbances is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. B12 deficiency is known to cause centrocecal scotoma and it is an important cause of nutritional optic atrophy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 15-year-old boy has bilateral optic atrophy with diabetes mellitus and diabetes insipidus. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests Wolfram syndrome. It is due to WFS1 gene mutation. The presentation is usually between the ages of 5 and 21 years; diabetes mellitus is typically the first manifestation, followed by visual problems. It has a poor prognosis. Clinical features are: (DIDMOAD) Diabetes insipidus Diabetes mellitus Optic atrophy Deafness (sensorineural type) Option A: Kjer's optic neuropathy is an autosomal dominant condition. It presents with vision loss in early childhood and no significant systemic features. Option B: Behr syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition. Clinical features include optic atrophy, pyramidal tract signs, ataxia, intellectual disability, urinary incontinence, and pes cavus Option D: Leber's congenital amaurosis is an autosomal recessive condition. It usually presents with significant vision loss in infancy and nystagmus.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of amaurosis fugax ?
explanation: Amaurosis fugax is a sudden and transient monocular blindness, which is reversible. It is a marker of advanced carotid artery atherosclerosis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Champagne cork disc is seen in which of the following conditions?
explanation: Champagne cork disc is seen in chronic papilledema. The optic disc gives the appearance of the dome of a champagne cork. Small drusen-like crystalline deposits (corpora amylacea) may appear on the disc surface. The most reliable sign to differentiate between papillitis and papilledema is pupillary reaction. Pupillary light reflex is normal in papilledema whereas it is sluggish in papillitis.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following defects is implicated in Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy?
explanation: In Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), the defect is a mutation of maternal mitochondrial DNA. Therefore the condition has a maternal inheritance. LHON causes bilateral, subacute painless loss of vision. The characteristic visual field defect is a centrocaecal scotoma. Pupillary light reflex is relatively preserved until the late stage of the disease. Optic neuritis and optic atrophy start in one eye and goes on to involve the other eye subsequently. It typically affects males between the ages of 15 and 35 years. The diagnosis of LHON should be considered in any patient with bilateral optic neuropathy, irrespective of age. Prognosis is poor, although some visual recovery may occur in a minority of cases even years later. Note: LHON plus refers to rare variants with additional manifestations such as neuromuscular dysfunction.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: A 34-year-old man developed a painless diminution of vision in his right eye 6 months ago but did not seek medical attention. Two weeks ago, he started to notice mild blurring in his left eye and has now come for evaluation. According to him, his elder brother and maternal uncle also had similar vision problems. Which fundus finding would point towards Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy in this patient?
options: Hyperemic optic disc with telangiectatic capillaries
explanation: Hyperemic optic disc with telangiectatic capillaries would be suggestive of LHON. LHON is related to a mitochondrial DNA mutation. This results in impaired mitochondrial adenosine triphosphate production, which affects the highly energy-dependent optic nerve. In the acute phase, the optic disc is hyperemic and swollen with telangiectatic capillaries. However, the optic disc does not leak on fluorescein angiography. Later stages may show primary optic atrophy.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: In order to diagnose a case as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, which of the following features is not necessary?
options: Elevated opening pressure on lumbar puncture
explanation: Papilledema is not a mandatory criterion for the diagnosis of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri) is a diagnosis of exclusion. Obstructive, compressive, and infiltrative CNS lesions must be excluded by neuroimaging studies. Papilledema, although present in 90% of the patients, is not necessary for diagnosis. Elevated CSF opening pressure on lumbar puncture is the hallmark of IIH. Risk factors of IIH include: Female sex Obesity Nalidixic acid Tetracycline Vitamin A Oral contraceptives Use of or withdrawal from corticosteroids
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following is the most reliable sign to clinically differentiate between a case of papillitis and papilledema?
explanation: The most reliable sign to differentiate between papillitis and papilledema is pupillary reaction. Pupillary light reflex is normal in papilledema whereas it is sluggish in papillitis. Visual acuity and colour vision are also relatively more preserved in papilledema compared to papillitis. The other three disc signs seen on ophthalmoscopy are present in both papillitis and papilledema.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text:
A patient evaluated for dizziness and visual disturbances was found to have down-beating nystagmus. A brain lesion was suspected and the patient was referred for an MRI. What is the
most likely site of the lesion?
options: Pineal region and the dorsal midbrain

question_text: An RTA patient with severe head trauma is admitted to the surgical ICU for observation. On examination, nystagmus was noted. His CT scan reveals a transverse fracture of his left temporal bone. Which of the following statements is true regarding the nystagmus?
options: Slow phase is towards the left and fast phase towards the righ
Slow phase is towards the right and fast phase towards the lef
It is an up-beating type of nystagmus
It is a down-beating type of nystagmus
explanation: Fracture of the temporal bone causes vestibular injury resulting in a horizontal nystagmus with slow phase towards the affected side and fast phase towards the opposite side. Peripheral vestibular nystagmus occurs in lesions of the labyrinth or vestibular nerve. Normally, there is tonic input to the brainstem vestibular nuclei from the periphery. Loss of the tonic input from the left vestibular nerve leads to deviation of the eyes towards the left side, which is the slow phase of the nystagmus. The cortical correction brings the eyes back to the centre in the primary gaze which is the fast-phase directed towards the right side.

question_text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
explanation: In internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) the lesion is at the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). In INO, there is impaired adduction on the ipsilateral side of the lesion, and nystagmus on abduction on the contralateral side. When the gaze is initiated in the motor cortex, the horizontal gaze center or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements. The PPRF has two outputs. The first is to the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus which causes abduction of the ipsilateral eye. The second output is to the contralateral MLF which sends an impulse to the contralateral 3rd cranial nerve nucleus causing contralateral adduction. These two outputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side. Therefore, a lesion in the right MLF leads to failure of the right eye adduction. The left eye, however, abducts normally. This is called internuclear ophthalmoplegia. The following image shows the pathway for horizontal eye movements as described above.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: You are evaluating an elderly patient in the stroke ICU, who was admitted three days back with a history of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and gait abnormalities. The visual examination showed conjugate horizontal left gaze palsy. He could maintain gaze near mid-position but could not cross the midline to the left side. His MRI is likely to show involvement of which of the following brain areas?
explanation: Horizontal gaze palsy can occur due to a lesion in parapontine reticular formation (PPRF). Horizontal gaze: It involves 2 muscles- the ipsilateral lateral rectus and the contralateral medial rectus. Center for this pathway is parapontine reticular formation (PPRF). From here, they move to the ipsilateral 6th nerve nucleus. Next, they pass through the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) to the contralateral medial rectus subnucleus. Lesions affecting the abducens nuclei will also cause ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy, because of damage to motor neurons and internuclear neurons originating from the nuclei. Lesions involving the PPRF will lead to horizontal gaze palsy, as PPRF acts as a relay centre that connects the frontal eye fields in the cerebral cortex to the abducens nuclei. Conjugate horizontal gaze palsy can also be caused by lesion(s) involving both the abducens motor fibres and the MLFs preceding the abducens nucleus. Bilateral horizontal gaze palsy will be caused if lesion(s) involve both abducens nuclei or bilateral PPRF. Isolated damage to the MLFs will cause the classic INO where eye abduction is preserved, however, the ipsilateral eye will not be able to be adducted on conjugate horizontal gaze. Conjugate eye movements Binocular movements in which the eyes move synchronously and symmetrically in the same direction. Main types Saccades: They are fast movements controlled by the contralateral frontal lobe. Pursuits: They are slow following movements controlled by the ipsilateral occipital lobe. Image: The Horizontal gaze pathway Lesions in this pathway Horizontal gaze palsy: Due to lesion in the PPRF of the same side Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO): Caused by lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) One and a half syndrome: Caused by lesions in both MLF and PPRF of the same side Vertical gaze palsy Center is located in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the dorsal midbrain (riMLF). The important types of vertical gaze palsy are as follows: Parinaud's syndrome: Upgaze palsy Steel–Richardsons syndrome: Downgaze palsy

question_text: A patient has normal vertical saccades. On attempted left gaze as shown in the image below, the patient develops left jerk nystagmus. Where is the most likely location of the lesion?
explanation: The most likely location of the lesion according to the given clinical scenario and the image is the right medial longitudinal fasciculus. The image depicts an attempted left gaze and concludes that there is an adduction deficit in the right eye. This causes jerk nystagmus in the abducting left eye. This is most likely due to a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) ipsilateral to the side of the adduction deficit. Hence, this is a case of a right MLF lesion or Right Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO).

explanation: Ophthalmoplegic migraine refers to headache associated with third, fourth, and sixth nerve palsy. Ophthalmoplegic migraine almost always involves the third nerve. Rare cases of sixth nerve involvement, and even rarer cases that involve the fourth nerve, have also been reported. Clinical criteria for the diagnosis of ophthalmoplegic migraine include: A prior history of typical common or classic migraine headaches Ophthalmoplegia that occurs during (or, rarely, just before) an established migraine attack Exclusion of other reasonable causes by clinical and radiological studies Tumors of Eye

explanation: Malignant melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.

explanation: The most common primary malignant tumor of the lid is basal cell carcinoma. The second most common tumor of the lid is squamous cell carcinoma

question_text: Which of the following is the most common lid malignancy in HIV patients?
explanation: Kaposi sarcoma is the commonest malignancy of the lid and conjunctiva in HIV patients. It appears as a violaceous non-tender nodule on the eyelid or conjunctiva. It is a rapidly growing acquired neoplasm composed of malignant stromal cells densely vascularized by blood vessels of capillary size. The typical lesion appears as an expanding, bright red subepithelial mass that projects through and replaces the overlying conjunctival epithelium. Spontaneous bleeding leading to bloody tears or a subconjunctival hematoma is relatively common. Conjunctival Kaposi’s sarcoma can be treated by excision, cryotherapy, radiation therapy (external beam or contact therapy), chemotherapy, or topical or intralesional interferon-.
subject: Ophthalmology

question_text: Which of the following cannot be used in the management of the clinical condition shown below?
explanation: The image shows a capillary hemangioma involving the left upper lid and periocular area. Interferon beta is not used in the management of capillary hemangioma. However, note that interferon alfa-2a is used in resistant cases. A capillary haemangioma is the most common tumor of the orbit and periorbital area in childhood. It may present as small isolated lesions or large masses that can cause visual impairment (due to mechanical ptosis and the resulting sensory deprivation amblyopia), systemic effects (severe thrombocytopenia), or exist as part of PHACE syndrome (Posterior fossa anomalies, Hemangioma, Arterial lesions, Cardiac abnormalities, Eye or Endocrine abnormalities) 30% of lesions resolve by the age of 3 years and about 75% by the age of 7. Indications for treatment are: Visual (amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion, strabismus) Cosmesis Optic nerve compression Exposure keratopathy Treatment options include: Beta blockers- oral propranolol, topical timolol. Steroids- intralesional triamcinolone or betamethasone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids. Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine- for steroid-resistant sight-threatening lesions Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser.

question_text: An 8-year old child presented with right-sided proptosis. Biopsy of the orbital mass was done and histopathological examination revealed this picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS). Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. 40% of rhabdomyosarcomas develop in the head and neck, and they are the most common primary orbital malignancy in children but are still a rare condition. The older age of the child presenting with proptosis suggests rhabdomyosarcoma (average age 7 to 8 years) than retinoblastoma (average age at presentation is 18 months). The histopathology shows elongated to round spindle cells with features of skeletal muscle at different stages of maturation with highly eosinophilic cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei – the embryonal type of rhabdomyosarcoma Immunohistochemistry is useful in identifying skeletal muscle proteins, such as alpha-actin, myosin, desmin, and myoglobin Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and hematogenous and lymphatic metastases. Decision-making for management is based on histopathologic confirmation as well as the staging of orbital RMS, which includes imaging (MRI of primary tumor, chest-CT, Tc bone scan), pathology, and work-up for metastases(bone marrow biopsy). Treatment options include chemotherapy (vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and actinomycin D) and radiotherapy.

question_text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on angiography?
explanation: The clinical vigenette is of a patient presenting with painless dimunition of vision and metamorphopsia with the right fundus showing choroidal melanoma superotemporal to the optic disc and involving the macula. In this patient a “Double circulation” pattern consisting of an internal circulation within the lesion and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina will be seen on angiography. Although collar stud(Option C) appearance is pathagnomic for choroidal melanoma, it can be seen on B-scan and not on angiography. Choroidal melanoma is a primary intraocular malignancy in adults that peaks around 60 years of age. Symptoms include a range of visual disturbances such as painless decrease in vision and metamorphosia when macula is involved. Other features of Choroidal melanoma includes: A solitary elevated subretinal grey-brown dome shaped mass Clumps of orange pigment are common over the mass Collar stud appearance on B-scan (option C): It is pathagnomic of choridal melanoma. It is seen if the tumour breaks through the Bruch's membrane into the subretinal space . Associated haemorrhage Smoke stack pattern (option A) and ink blot (option B) pattern is seen on FFA in central serous retinopathy (CSR). CSR is the spontaneous serous detachment of the sensory neuroretina in the foveal region with or without retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) detachment. This occurs due Choroidal vascular hyperpermeability. On FFA it is initially seen as an ink-blot pattern or smoke stack pattern of hyperfluorescence which then spreads to take the configuration of mushroom or umbrella pattern. question_text: Retinoblastoma arises from which of the following structures?
explanation: Retinoblastoma (also called glioma retinae) arises from the neurosensory retina. It is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally. Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm. It is of 4 types: Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment Mixed type Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated

question_text: Which of the following is the most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma?
explanation: The most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma is leukocoria plus strabismus. Clinical features of retinoblastoma: Present within the first two years of life Leukocoria Strabismus Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre-septal cellulitis. Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases. Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular involvement is rare. Signs: An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification. An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel. An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment. Investigations: Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria. Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope MRI of the orbit + brain

explanation: The histology showing Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and clinical history of white reflex point towards a diagnosis of retinoblastoma. question_text: Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of which of the following?
explanation: Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of retinoblastoma. Knudson's hypothesis can be stated as follows: Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB are required to produce retinoblastoma. In familial retinoblastoma, one of the pair of alleles of RB1 is mutated in all the cells of the body. When a further mutagenic event ("second hit" according to the "two-hit" hypothesis proposed by Knudson) affects the second allele, the cell may then undergo malignant transformation. A large majority of these children develop bilateral and multifocal tumors. In sporadic cases, both RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits). Familial retinoblastoma patients also have a predisposition to non-ocular cancers because of the presence of the mutation in all cells, such as pinealoblastoma (usually before the age of 5 years), osteosarcomas, soft tissue sarcomas, and melanomas. Note: Trilateral retinoblastoma = Pinealoblastoma + Bilateral retinoblastoma

question_text: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?
explanation: The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellens chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes. Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points. Snellens chart is used for Visual acuity assesment. In snellens chart the alphabets decrease in size as we move from above-downwards and these lines, from above-downwards should be read at 60, 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, 6, 5 and 4 m respectively. At these distances, the respective letters subtend a visual angle of 5 minutes. Hence, the largest alphabet that should be read at 60 m subtends a visual angle of 5 minutes in the eye.

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

question_text:
Photostress test is used to differentiate between:
Macula and optic nerve disease
explanation: Photostress test is used to differentiate between the disease involving the macula and optic nerve. This test is of particular use in early macular diseases such as central serous retinopathy. In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again, and the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye. In normal people and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. Whereas, in patients with macular disease the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process. Eye Signs in Systemic Disease

question_text: Which of the following deficiencies would you suspect in a patient with acute retrobulbar neuritis?
explanation: Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause acute retrobulbar neuritis. Nutritional optic neuropathy is characterized by bilateral, symmetric, cecocentral scotomas and disturbance of color vision. Fundus morphology is usually normal. Deficiencies in the following vitamins are primarily responsible for the damage caused to the optic nerve: B1 (thiamine), B6 (pyridoxine), B9 (folic acid), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins are cofactors for many metabolic reactions and their deficiency leads to toxic byproduct accumulation within cells, which inhibits the electron transport chain and depresses mitochondrial function. Depletion of ATP leads to nerve dysfunction and eventual nerve death. Chronic alcohol abuse is a commonly associated risk factor and a cause of malnourishment.

question_text: A 10-year-old girl with neurological manifestations was referred from the pediatric OPD. Her ocular examination findings is as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows the Kayser–Fleisher (KF) ring, which is a characteristic finding of Wilson’s disease. KF ring consists of the deposition of copper in the Descemet membrane of the cornea. The rings are usually golden-brown and are visible only under the slit-lamp. They do not impair vision. They disappear on treatment with anti-copper drugs and reappear with disease progression. They are a characteristic sign of Wilson’s disease but are not pathognomonic. They can also be seen in: Primary biliary cholangitis Primary sclerosing cholangitis Cholestasis. Sunflower cataract is a rare finding of Wilson's disease. It occurs due to the deposition of copper in the centre of the lens. It consists of a greenish central opacity with spoke-like radial opacities and is visible only under the slit-lamp. question_text: Which of the following conditions can occur as an ocular manifestation in a patient with dengue?
explanation: Cataract is not an ocular manifestation of dengue. Dengue has varied manifestations, in different organ systems, mainly of inflammation and bleeding. Until recently, apart from retro-orbital pain, eye involvement was not recognized as a common feature of dengue infection. Potential pathogenic mechanisms include a direct viral effect on the eye, an immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements. Ocular manifestations of dengue: Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir. Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage. Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

question_text: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-wine stain on the right side of her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows a leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlying condition?
explanation: The given clinical picture of a young child presenting with unilateral port wine stain in the region of trigeminal nerve supply and leptomeningeal angioma as seen on MRI is indicative of Sturge-Webber syndrome (SWS). Glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation of SWS. Sturge weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder(phakomatoses) that is characterized by unilateral capillary malformation at the region of trigeminal supply known as port wine stain or nevus flammeus, ipsilateral diffuse cavernous hemangioma of the choroid and ipsilateral leptomeningeal hemangiomatosis, which causes seizures and mental retardation. Ocular manifestation of SWS include: Glaucoma - most common ocular manifestation. It develops anywhere between infancy to adulthood. When developed in infancy it presents as buphthalmos. Diffuse choroidal hemangioma Serous retinal detachment Visual field defects- homonymous hemianopia due to the leptomeningeal hemangiomas affecting the optic tract or occipital lobe. Heterochromia of the iris Episcleral and conjunctival lesions Option A: Uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue of the eyes. It can be associated with a number of systemic conditions such as sarcoidosis, behcet's disease, ankylosing spondylitis, reiter's syndrome,Toxoplasmosis and Posner–Schlossman syndrome (PSS). Option B: Retinitis pigmentosa is an inherited or acquired pigmentatory retinal dystrophy affecting the rods more. The earliest manifestation is worsening of night blindness which gradually progresses to tunnel vision and ultimately loss of central vision. The classic triad of findings in RP comprises bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation and waxy disc pallor. Systemic Associations of RP include: Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome Cockayne's syndrome Refsum's syndrome Usher's syndrome Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome The below given image shows the classical triad findings of Retinitis pigmentosa. Option C:Keratitis is the inflammation of cornea which is characterised by corneal edema, cellular infiltration and ciliary congestion. It can be either infectious or non-infectious in nature which includes allergic keratitis, neurotrophic keratitis, exposure keratitis and peripheral ulcerative keratopathies such as Rosacea keratitis and Mooren's ulcer.

question_text: A 70-year-old man presented with complaints of diminution of vision in both eyes for the last 6 - 8 months. On examination, bilateral cataracts were seen. Incidentally, you also note iris pearls. Which of the following conditions should you suspect in this patient?
explanation: Iris pearls are pearly-white nodules seen on the iris in leprosy. They are asymptomatic, 0.3 to 1.0 mm in diameter, dull yellowish-white in colour, and are seen at an early stage of the disease. It is not associated with any inflammatory changes in the anterior chamber. Histologically, it consists of lepromatous bacilli packed within mononuclear cells or acid-fast material with accompanying foreign body reaction. Inside the eye, leprosy bacilli preferentially lodge in the iris and ciliary body, due to the relatively cooler temperatures and high vascularity.

question_text: An elderly patient admitted with multiple comorbidities in the ICU, developed exposure keratitis and ulceration. An ophthalmology opinion was sought. Incidentally, on fundoscopy, the resident found the following picture. What is this most likely due to?
explanation: The given image suggests a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The hallmark of Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization. Abnormal new vessel formation, which occurs on the inner (vitreous) surface of the retina and may extend into the vitreous cavity, can cause vitreous haemorrhage. Neovascularization is often accompanied by pre-retinal fibrous tissue, which, along with the vitreous, can contract, resulting in traction retinal detachment. In addition, tiny microaneurysms can also be seen.

explanation: The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is an ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt). It is a form of minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage. Ex-PRESS glaucoma implant is a small stainless steel device. It is inserted under a scleral flap during a modified trabeculectomy. Complications such as hypotony are lower than with standard trabeculectomy. Glaucoma drainage devices are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. While these devices were traditionally reserved for high-risk patients, or after trabeculectomy had failed, they are becoming increasingly popular. The commonly used devices are as follows: Shunts using episcleral explants Ahmed glaucoma valve: Silicone Molteno implant - Polypropylene plate and silicone plate Baerveldt implant - Silicone Mini-shunts Ex-Press™ Mini-Shunt: Stainless stee iStent® - Titanium
